The mood among those gathered turns, as they watch his slow progress, from jubilant to--what?--surprised, disappointed, depressed: Wonka's not what they'd expected; he's not vibrant; he's sad. Then of course he lets on that it was an act. He in fact is vibrant. But he's demonstrated in this simple, affecting scene that there is something a little off about him. The new movie aims to create a similar mood and a similar effect, but its makers go big: there are songs and animotronic puppets and fire to greet those arrived at the factory. Wonka's audience is appropriately dismayed, but it's nowhere near as effective as Wilder's limp. It's just too much.

(2) Similarly, there is the boat scene. In the original Wilder makes the too-fast boat ride genuinely scary just with his acting, by his quickening speech/song, because his behavior is erratic enough that you're worried about whether he can be trusted. In the new version the boat ride is made less scary with more work--special effects. Again, less is more. (And granted Depp's character has erratic behavior to spare, but somehow his Wonka is not as frightening here as Wilder.)

Finally, the new movie takes the Wonka story farther than the book or movie do. With Charlie's help, Willy resolves his problems with his dentist father and loses his family issues: an absurd and unnecessary addition to the story.

In closing, I'll return to what I said in the opening paragraph, that Depp's Wonka is not likable. As portrayed by Wilder, Willy Wonka, however odd his behavior, was a nice man. When he behaved badly you were upset because he'd disappointed you. It's not the grand prize that Charlie is sad to lose in the original: it's Wonka himself. But when this new Wonka behaves badly--when he in effect denies Charlie the chocolate factory--one is not disappointed with him; one is more apt to think "good riddance."

title: Wasted My Time
review:
Okay, I tried hard not to comment on this movie, since I have almost NOTHING good to say about it. First off, I have never read the book, but if you make a movie that has already been made, IT'S A REMAKE. This is not different enough to constitute a retelling. **SPOILERS** from here on. IF this follows the book so closely, the author is a true visionary. The OOMPA LOOMPAs were performing Janet Jackson and Kiss/Hard Rock moves and video displays. My guess NOT IN THE BOOK. There is a total lack of character build up. The only decent actor, was Charlie (very good). Grandpa, no connection. Charlie wins the ticket and Grandpa Jumps around. I had NO feeling he was bed-ridden or had difficulty walking prior to that. The whole movie talked down to the audience. EVERYTHING WAS EXPLAINED. 'Charlie only had one present a year, and that was a WONKA BAR' Boy, I wonder what he's getting this time. If it wasn't a five year old could have figured it out. Burton has been overrated for years, I know that goes against the mainstream, but I like to think for myself. Stop with the drab colors already, You've DONE THAT, MOVE ON. Johnny Depp, also overrated, played his best Michael Jackson (I think that was pointed out in other posts) and during the Oompa Loompa flashback, Jim Carrey (Blatant). He hates kids and doesn't want to be near them, yet in one scene, he sticks his hand right in the middle of them and leaves it there. Next scene, ewww kids. Poor attempt at trying to show motivation to Willie's love for chocolate. And if he wore those S&M braces for so long, why does he have such an overbite? The build up of the golden tickets fell short too. Where was Charlie's psych when he opened the bar. Instead of "I wish you could go Grandpa," It's who shall I take "ME" he yells. Call that connection? What about DAD? Running out of time so I will cut to the big LOSER. NO GOBSTOPPER villain. They introduced it and that was it. Charlie won the factory because he was the least-bad-kid. There was no relationship with him and Wonka. Just because he refused it for family and Depp had another LAME flashback, everyone talks about the relationship factor. Relationships build not appear.

Sorry for wasting too much space

title: Burton's bold step toward maturity through his own "style" self affirmation
review:
First of all let me state that to Hollywood's mainstream aesthetics Burton is certainly the most disturbing and utterly wicked artistic approach representative, he is plainly as freaky as it gets and sports such reputation with evident pride.

Although one could easily name at least a handful of directors with a, by far, more edgy film  making style, few have been able to establish a truly own stylistic universe with enough attractive and cohesion to let them forge an artistic career based upon continuous explorations and exposes of such iconoclasm and paraphernalia. Moreover, if anything has contributed Burton into achieving this, it has been both stating and repeating over and over certain themes and tunes (openly dark, ghoulish, with the recurring bitter childhood, Halloween, Christmas, sense of exclusion, awkwardness themes) , the Burtonesque typecasting (one can almost associate actors like Depp, Bonham Carter, Walken, Keaton, De Vito with his most representative work), and the creation of an overall gloomy and depressive mood with the help of Danny Elfman's brilliant scores. Those elements have let Burton create a bizarre "factory" of imagination, art and nightmares, all faithful to his personal and unique sensibility. Now we can easily find this entire ensemble of element within "Charlie and The Chocolate Factory".

The movie itself, since Burton overtook the directorial duties, distanced widely and openly from the first book adaptation (Gene Wilder's "Willy Wonka and The Chocolate Factory") but wanted to stay faithfully close both to Burton's style and Dahl's Book. And it certainly does with fairly nice results.

This movie has not been marketed as a kid's flick, and it is not just that,we are promptly warned about that, this movie contains adult humor, witty and sometimes sarcastic remarks, deep psychological overtones, a moral (well they could have just skipped this one, but it wouldn't have been completely true to the novel's spirit nor to the unavoidable Hollywood canons), a significantly relevant emotional sub  plot that aware "grown ups" may relate with and a vast gamut that is certain to delight most of the audience for it is a true feast for the senses, however twisted into Burton's own fashion.

A key element and pivotal role is played by Wonka, rather than Charlie, who indeed does a neat job as a bridge between the adult and the kids world, where Willy Wonka seems to be happily lost in opposition to Charlie himself who appears to have the moral schemes of adult people; lots of people have noticed that Depp's portrayal of Wonka may have been a little too freaky and disturbing, so let's get into that aspect.

Johnny Depp masterfully leads us into a world of madness and isolation, where colorful child fixations may have more than one simple meaning as we will discover as the film advances. The nasty, spoiled kid, misanthropist, dark and strikingly silly but lucid way Deep has chosen to characterize Willy Wonka is gonna shock most people and will make them doubt about the true good intentions of such iconography that, with the wardrobe and all just reminds one of a certain Jackson guy who apparently had the same interests and personality traits as the factory owner. One thing is quite obvious, Wonka is, perhaps not consciously, a reference to MJ and that is evident in certain lines and points, rather than in the mannerism and some attitudes by WW; like the "We have so much in common" line , the father issues, and so on. However be not afraid, kinds in general won't notice this and probably only older wicked teens and grown ups will giggle and maliciously laugh at those aspects. It must not be an element that makes you not go to the movie.

Closing this comment I should mention the overall good performances and characterizations, thanks to the effective but not outstanding script, happily supported by a nice cast where both Christopher 'Count' Lee, "Grandpa Joe", "Mike TeeVee" should be recognized alongside Depp (the best here) and "Charlie" (close second); they all offer convincing and engaging acting.

Finally just let me remember you this movie is not supposed to be a creative milestone, nor a character driven powerhouse story, less "Oscar Marketed Material, so go to the cinema with the right expectations and you'll not be disappointed but surprised; it is a movie aimed toward the family segment but would surpass the simple "box office bait" appellative for it is a nice and enjoyable movie with quite some substance underneath. Don't ever forget this one is a Burton film, that is utterly important, otherwise you'll be shocked by some of his nightmare like representations; try to forget the previous film, at least while watching this one, it will help a lot because they are so wildly different that they could be anymore alike. This movie works well on many levels, your kids will enjoy it, teenager will be amused by its witty remarks and sarcasm, grown ups will have plenty of maturity to bestow upon, Burton fans will find plenty of what they look for in his films, novel fans won't be disappointed, previous film fans will rejoice with how different the approach can get to be, gossiping people could chat about MJ references, so there is something for everyone here.

However if you don't like Tim Burtons aesthetics don't go, if you don't have an open mind avoid watching it, you could find it disturbing and controversial for your taste, but just don't miss one of the most, if not the most, interesting "family" films I've seen this year and let this warm, deep, visually stunning, plain fun flick seduce you and take you into the "factory".

title: Why?
review: This was unbelievably horrid rendition of this originally wonderful and imaginative film. Somehow Burton manages to take a playful and dreamy movie and makes it into a contrived, dreadful and sinister mockery of one of the great children's films. Depp plays a character that looks and acts insane and bizarre and is not at all the right actor for this film. Frankly, he is difficult to watch and there is significant focus on him throughout the film, so be prepared to be annoyed throughout the film. If you must sit through this film, do your best to wipe out any memory of the original film or you will be sure to be very disappointed.

title: A Lovely Burton Rendition!
review:
At first I was skeptical of the new "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory," with all of its changes and adaptations. I thought the movie wasn't going to be as great as Gene Wilder's performance, but having it been a Tim Burton rendition, I decided to see it.

I loved it! This Version of the movie gives a deeper meaning, as well as an explanation to why Willy Wonka is the way he is. "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" contains the little details mentioned in the book by Roald Dohl. In a comparison between the original and the new, I would recommend this version. Johnny Depp's performance proved to defy my expectations!

title: A spectacle of sight and sound.
review: This movie brought the mastery that Tim Burton is famous for and the talent that is the cast to life. Not only with amazing leading actors, like Johnny Depp and Freddie Highmore, but also a spectacular supporting cast including David Kelly, Helen Bonham Carter, and Noah Taylor. With wacky scenery and costumes with provide as much delicious eye candy as a Wonka Bar ever could. I also believe that this movie had to be a success due to its similarity to the book, using the original lyrics and following more closely than the Gene Wilder version. Johnny Depp shows that he will never take a normal role, and I hope he never doesn't, bringing hilarity to the big screen. A visual masterpiece, a work of art for all ages. This movie will make you laugh, and believe in the goodness of an innocent heart. Not just for kids. Great for everyone anytime.

title: New Charlie And Chocalate Factory
review:
When I left to go see this film I has in the back of my mind the thought "Will this be as good as the original" and worried that it would not compare. Although having seen it I see that there is no way that the two can be prepared. This new make of the book has been created with completely different ideas of how Wonka behaved and how the factory looked. The Creators have revolutionised the film into the 21st Century.

Along with new added parts to the movie and some parts taken away, this movie has become a colourful and funny film to watch. Jonny Depp fitted Willy Wonka to a perfect T. He was funny and gave all the right facial expression and comedic quirks at just the right time in the right style to make you chuckle. Along with Charlies character who played the shy poor boy that was just lucky and happy to be places with his family. The actor was quiet although not too quiet he made you feel his presence within the right scenes where he wished to be noticed.

Different things brought into this films are the change in the Umpa Lumpa's songs and you get an in-site of flash backs from different characters explaining the background to all their stories.

Despite the fact that all the character had an English accent (even Depp who intentionally aimed to do so) the scrips was still including American words of which you would not hear during an English film. Although despite that this is a highly enjoyable film and a good choice to take your children or to go with your friends to see!!! 8.5/10

title: Awesome!
review: This movie was incredible! I was quite young when I saw the first one, and frankly was scared by the weirdness of it. Several of the scenes were flat out...strange. Johnny Depp did an amazing job (as always) as Willy Wonka, and it's definitely worth seeing! Though one problem I did have was that the movie was missing the original Oompa Loompa song; nonetheless, the were still very cute, and absolutely hilarious! One thing I liked though was being able to see what had happened in Wonka's past, how he became a choclateer, etc. Anyway, the movie was not nearly as...odd as the first one, which in my opinion, is a plus. I definitely recommend this movie!

title: Excellent!
review: This is the best film that I have seen in a very long time. Jonny Depp is wonderfully funny in this and looks great, sexy as usual, even though he looks remarkably similar to Michael Jackson to some, but oh well. The Oompa Loompahs (sorry for spelling) provide the most amazingly funny humour to those of all ages. This film makes you smile all the way through. Then there's the fact that this film shows the book as it was actually written - it is not a smile, happy little story for the little children, it is actually quite a dark and mysterious book with lots of underlying meanings. And the film has lots that the book didn't have too. It gives the most wonderful history to the character of Willy Wonka and that is a great thing to see.

title: Playing Devils Advocate
review:
I personally thought that this film was amazing. Although i could see the points of criticism that some people make of it. I loved the original film but this is spectacular in its own right and from the directing to the acting i was enticed every minute.

But The portrayal of Wonka could be seen as a little distant and a little more freaky than that of Gene Wilder. I think that Jonny Depp played it well and with a deeper dimension than some people have seen. But i think a lot of people were expecting a remake rather than a new film, so have judged it too much on its predecessor.

The factory itself is amazing and with the enhancement of graphics it looks wonderful beyond your wildest dreams (which it is supposed to be). Though you could comment that on occasion it is a little too graphically produced and the om-pa lumpas(cant spell sorry!) were a little frustrating. Their songs were funny but they all looked the same which for me was one of the only disappointing bits, and made them nearly as bad as the bright orange ones!!!! Just to add the only other annoying part is that Charlie doesn't steal and show the element of a bad little boy in this film which i thought was an important dimension that was missed.

Overall though i think that it is a good film for all ages and maybe even more so for younger children who haven't seen the first adaptation. I took my brothers and the older ones thought it was rubbish and the younger ones though that it was magical. And for me that is the aim of the book so it achieved its purpose.

title: Wonderful!
review: This is my first time to submit a comment on any movie but I saw this last night and was compelled to do so! This movie is wonderful. There is absolutely no point in drawing comparisons with the original WWATCF. This is so different, so much darker. I'm a huge Johnny Depp fan anyway and, once again, he has displayed his phenomenal talent to totally become the character he's playing. Depp's Wonka is quite freaky especially in relation to his reactions to the children. I went to see this movie with two adult friends and we enjoyed it as much as all the children in the audience. There was a spontaneous round of applause when the movie ended. I'm already planning to see it again this weekend! The reason I rated it 9 out of 10 instead of a perfect 10 was because of the oompa loompa's - I just could not hear the words of their songs and found this really annoying.

title: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory
review:
A Adventure/Comedy/Family/Fantasy about a young boy Charlie Bucket(Freddie Highmore,Finding Neverland)who finds one of the five golden tickets that.Pirates of the Caribbean Willy Wonka (Johnny Depp,Pirates of the Caribbean) sent out all over the world hidden in his candy bars.The golden tickets are a invitation to come to Willy Wonkas famous chocolate factory that know body has been in since Willy fired all of the personal because his competition was stealing his ideas by sending in spies.

Johnny Depp(Willy Wonka)gave a absolutely perfect performance I cant think of one other person who could have made a better Willy Wonka.Usually children actors either hurt the film or just don't add anything to it but that is not the case in this movie all of the kids in the cast were pretty good actors they all added to this movie.Tim Burton what a director!! he took everything good about the old movie and put it in to this movie and he took everything bad out of the old movie and made it perfect and then put it into this movie and then he added a few other things that made the movie a little more crisp.The screenplay was very entertaining there was a couple lines that were a little off but most of the time it was pretty good.The storyline is far better then the original unlike the first this one has a detailed past to it.

Best actor/actress-Johnny Depp

A vast improvement compared to the original-Jake Hyden

I gave this movie a 8 out of 10

Rated-(PG) for quirky situations, action and mild language.

8/10

title: Magical, hilarious and unmissable
review:
When I heard that they were making another Charlie and the chocolate factory movie, my fist thoughts were that it was just another idea to make more easy money, and would probably turn out awful. Yet these views were blasted straight out of my head when I heard that it would be another product of the dream-team (Depp and Burton). I loved all three of their previous movies together, and the thought of another was so exciting - it became my most anticipated movie for ages - I was not disappointed.

As soon as it started, that trademark Burtonness that is impossible to explain hit me and I was gripped. The whole film was visually stunning, and every actor and actress was perfectly cast, especially Johnny Depp. He delivered one of the best performances, truly taking Wonka to another level. Although Gene Wilder played Wonka well in the 1971 movie, Depp was much more disturbing and funny, yet oddly more lovable - and revealed himself towards the end as being quite vulnerable. Deep Roy was perfect as the Oompa Loompas - freaky, disturbing and funny, and sending creepy shivers down your spine when the children meet their sticky ends and they start singing excitedly, this is then all topped off with Wonka's obvious delight at their suffering (you MUST NOT miss the squirrel scene when Veruca meets her end, its, well, of want of a better word, FABULOUS.)

The whole film was pure art from beginning to end, beautiful, colourful and surprisingly Gothic, and manages to keep perfectly to the spirit of the book, which the 1971 version sadly missed. It was dark with a heartwarming centre, then coated with sugar - a perfect, faultless movie and a rare gem - you would rather die than miss this, and it would be a crime for it not to be a classic. Roald Dahl must be grinning his head off.

title: An in-depth remake of the already wonderful original.
review: What to say, what to say? Well, I already love Johnny Depp, and Tim Burton is a genius with fantasy/sci-fi movies. But Charlie and the Chocolate Factory? That was the best Johnny Depp/Tim Burton movie I have ever seen. The fact that the writers went past the portrayal of Willy Wonka in the original classic so far as to explain how Wonka became a chocolateer was amazing. And introducing the audience to Wonka's father, brilliant. I liked the Oompa Loompas in this movie better because they didn't look like clowns (I am terrified of clowns). What upset me about them, though, is that they were all the same. That was disappointing. But, other than that, I give it two thumbs up.

title: Massive disappointment.
review:
About 30 minutes into the film the Oompa-Loompa's sing for the first time. Anyhope this film deserves to be mentioned in even the same breath to the 1971 original goes out of the window. One particular Oompa-Loompa sequence, just after Violet Beauregarde has been turned into a giant blueberry, is so bad it is actually probably the worst thing I have ever seen in a film that I have paid to see. But its not just the Oompa-Loompa's that will leave anyone with a genuine love for such a classic story cold.

Depps fans won't like to admit it, but his performance is completely wrong. His pale skin, unclear motives and childish behaviour (giggling, for example) bring to mind a rather more famous man child of recent times. In fact, Depp would only have had to burst into 'Black Or White' and I would have been convinced this was Michael Jackson and the Chocolate Factory. Where is the slightly eccentric uncle with a secret past that Wilder played so perfectly in the original? Instead we are given an incredible inept attempt to explain Wonka's past which removes any sort of interest the viewer might have in the character by explaining away the myth (although Christopher Lee's turn as Wilbur Wonka is brilliant).

The script on the whole is awful, falling on clichés and uninspired, dull dialogue and focusing too much on Wonka. This is meant to be a film about Charlie NOT Willy, hence the CHARLIE in the title (it's ironic that 1971's Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory manages to focus on Charlie more. Its also far to Americanised - if Charlie must be offered dollars at every opportunity, told to 'clean his pants' and we hear 'jerk' bandied around Willy nilly then set the film in America... don't create some strange hybrid Eng-America where your too lazy or stupid to localise the script properly.

The acting (apart from the two mentioned earlier) is mostly unremarkable, though special mention must go to the kids who all manage to be terrible, especially Julia Winter whose acting is stilted and unconvincing. No wonder, as a whole, the children spend so little time on screen. Also why has Violet Beauregarde suddenly become a karate expert? I'm all for updating the ideas to fit in with the modern world (Mike Teevee's obsession switch from TV to Videogames is a good example of this) but don't do it at the expense of the story.

Good points? There are some - the whole world is wonderfully realised, exciting and imaginative and some of the special effects are genuinely special and Burton's trademark direction is there helping to create a film that is, at least, a visual treat. In fact, its only because of him that the film has managed to score as high as a 3.

Yes it REALLY is that bad.

title: A famous candy-maker, Willy Wonka, sends out a contest. A poor boy named Charlie finds the final ticket and gets to go on a wild tour of Willy's giant and famous factory.
review: I thought this movie was the best! It is definitely a must see. Hey, I liked it so much, I saw it twice! Johnny Depp is amazing in this film. He did a great job on twisting Gean Wilder's version of Willy Wonka. Actually, they're total opposites! Freddie Highmore did a great job as well. He played Charlie perfectly! This movie is also hilarious! There are some really funny parts. I quote them all the time and we laugh 'till it hurts! The Oompa-Loomas are awesome in this film! In the other film the orange skin with green hair is a little too much. These Oompa-Loopas are SO much better. The music in this film is really cool. It's a mix of different genres. Like the Oompa- Loompa songs are different mixes of funk, rock'n'roll, jungle and a hint of classical in the main title. I loved the music SO much I bought the soundtrack. I listen to it all the time. This movie is really really cool, funny, weird and it's touching, too. The moral to the story is there is no sweeter candy than family.

title: Better than the original
review: Tim Burton's take on this story is far better, in my opinion, than the original movie. Johnny Depp is the perfect Wonka. This Wonka is absolutely hilarious. His eccentricity (sp?)makes up for his being kinda creepy looking. LOL. And you get to see flashbacks of his childhood. The script is funnier than the original and there's less singing (Thank God) The songs that are in it are amusing. Another new thing is the origin of the Oompa Loompas. The sets are amazing, typical Tim Burton sets. The kids in the movie were perfect for the parts. I particularly liked the girls who played Violet and Beruca. And the new scenes with Wonka's father were great!

title: Brilliant
review: Anyone not thinking this is purely mad. I have heard many comments such  as "well its nothing like the old one!". It's not meant to be. Tim  Burton has brought the real Charlie an the Chocolate Factory to life  and has done an outstanding job of it. I really loved every minute of  it. Jonny Depp in the role of Willy Wonker is pure genius. He's funny  charismatic, rather creepy and full of mystery which is exactly how i  feel Ronald Dahl wrote this character. The children all added their own  mark on each character and Julia Winter i feel brings the easiest  character to copy into her own right. I would suggest watch it before  you take your own children as you'll definitely want to see it again  and some scenes may scare younger children.

title: An awesome adaptation
review:
I am a huge fan of Roald Dahl's work and I think that this was an awesome adaptation; yes, there are some major things that weren't on the book (as well as a lot of minor details, like the fact that in the book, both of the parents of every child, except Charlie visit the factory as well); but in general (I think) it's better than the 1971 film.

The performance of Johny Depp as Willy Wonka is way much better than the one that Gene Wilder did once. This new Willy Wonka is more interesting while the one Gene did was very cold. Also, the performance of the children is less cheesy now. The background they gave to Wonka wasn't really necessary but it gave a new spin to the story, when in the end, Wonka won't allow Charlie's family into the factory.

Another thing that shows how well adapted is this new version, is the fact that they respected Dahl's lyrics and gave them incredible music (well, I couldn't expect less form Danny Elfman).

One thing that worried me was the Oompa-Loompas, because everybody had the image of the 1971 film; but the performance of Deep Roy is simply amazing and it was such a bright idea to put him as every Oompa-Loompa.

So, it is a marvelous movie, I would say flawless. I dare to say that it is as good as the book.

title: Johnny at his Top
review: I have seen many movie's containing Johnny Depp and I have to say this is one of his best. Since he teamed up with Tim Burton, they both have caught my eye as creating masterpiece's. Charlie and the Chocolate Factory shows that Johnny can go beyond his expectations as an actor and give a performance that is memorable and suitable for all ages. This comment will consist of two things. A congrates to both Johnny Depp, and Tim Burton. (And the rest of the cast, and crew of the film.) and to the creation itself, I have seen it twice and am awaiting the third. People say I am crazy about the movie but I find this masterpiece, this work of art to be both entertaining and educational. I want to be a director someday, and seeing how Tim Burton works and how the actors/ess find him able to work with, makes my dream a lot easier because I have seen a master creature and am able to work off his leads and brilliant creations to find my path and my mark. I will never say this enough: CHARLIE AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY IS THE BEST MOVIE I EVER SAW! Energetic, thrilling and always can make me smile. Thanks for a great form of entertainment.

title: Read on and you'll find out
review: Ah (breathes in as if he began a new life) where to begin with this movie...? This is a fantastic movie, yes i am telling the truth, nope there is no abrupt punchline or derogatory statement to come; in fact there is no derogatory statement at all about this movie i loved it to bits, seriously! Well to get into the nitty gritty (trying not to spoil as well) the story is better; a young idealistic boy dreams of better things - all surrounding a giant chocolate factory (well he is a young boy) that sits a top the (presumably) mountain he lives on; at the top of the street. His name is Charlie and he is not a very well off creature, and in life he isn't really well of either; not very fast and indeed not that smart, apparently. An only child he lives in a small rickety and slanted house(whats with Tim Burton and casting Helena Bonham Carter in slanted houses...{BIG FISH})he lives with his mother, the kindly Helena Bonham Carter and father Noah Taylor who works in a dismal job and brings home little money, if any. As in the book and the books' previous 1971 incarnation the grandparents all still live (although they just look like corpses)in the bed in the centre of the house; although its more of a biggish room than house. To get on with the story quickly; Willy Wonka a once world-wide famed chocolateer, now a recluse is opening his factory to five lucky children; i do suppose you have heard and know this story, obviously. Anyway now to the story' presentation. Obviously this movie is going to be of Gothic twist because Tim Burton the master of Gothic slapstick (almost) is directing, with his favoured pet Johnny Depp who brings with him his favoured child star Freddie Highmore. This is a beautiful movie, the set pieces (esp. the actual chocolate-factory, where the chocolate is smoothed down to a frothy and foamy taste by waterfall) are brilliant and have that sharp Burton-esquire feel to them. The children are cast excellently. The story is far more in depth and just better than the previous 1971 release (although i am not comparing the two; because they are completely different takes of Roal Dahl's classic. Depp's version of Wonka is firstly superior to Gene Wilder's in the 1971 classic. Secondly, you really get a feel for Depp's Wonka. In the 1971 one Wilder is basically preying upon his own odd personality. Depp has created an entirely new (and better) Wonka in the form of a broken man, never truly a child but never truly and adult either. In summary casting; excellent - overall cosmetic presentation; excellent - acting; excellent - everything; excellent. And now to the best bitDeep Roy as the Oompa Loopmas, yes all of them. The computer generated munchkins of Wonka-land were a highlight for me in this movie from their quirky, funky yet so damm good and catchy tunes to their freaky, cool uniforms. I really enjoyed this movie and I know other people will. Hopefully people that aren't very cynical, because if you are you probably won't like this movie (what I mean is that the story can seem like pulp I suppose although I got carried away with the story and movie and so didn't mind at all, but try not to be too cynical because you mightn't like it if so  although I am kinda cynical and I thoroughly enjoyed this movie! I so have one bad thing to point out, Christopher Lee's character, I'll try not to ruin the movie whilst saying this, but I love Christopher Lee so much (in a purely plutonic way of course) but he is great in movie's and he playswell something that I dislike a lot, but still he was great in the role. That's the only fault. Everything is better, more vibrant and just brilliant. Another excellent notch on Tim Burton's movie-belt.

title: Awesome!
review:
I have heard numerous negative comments about this movie before it came out but when I saw the trailer, I couldn't wait until it came out. The first time I saw it I was amazed. Depp plays the part of Willy Wonka better than Wilder in the phsycedelic 1971 movie. What many people don't understand is that Willy Wonka is SUPPOSED to be crazy, odd, weird, or whatever you prefer.

While Wilder went for sweet and kind he was completely unfaithful to the book. Now, the oompa loompa's aren't SUPPOSED to be green and orange either, like they were in the other movie.

I think Deep Roy did a good job as the oompa loompas, though the digital superimposing of him to make the effect of many loompas was a bit dodgy in parts.

The songs were very funny indeed. Danny Elfman did a great job, for in some scenes, the powerful music gave me chills. All in all this is the best movie I've seen. By the way, I've seen it 6 times. I'm going for ten this weekend. ^_^

title: Well done! Entertaining, and stays true to the book!
review:
I was kinda on the fence about this movie. I respect Johnny Depp and Tim Burton quite a bit, and was a HUGE Roald Dahl fan as a child (James and the Giant Peach and Fantastic Mr. Fox were my personal favs), but I wasn't a big fan of the Gene Wilder movie. Oh I liked it, but it was too...whimsical. I never felt Willy Wonka was a happy, jolly man who sings songs. I thought he was a bit creepy, and more than a little nuts.

So, imagine my surprise when someone crawls into my head and makes the Charlie movie I always wanted.

There are so many times I laughed in this movie, I can't count them. And for a children's movie, this one was blessedly free of fart jokes, and toilet humor - thank god, or I would have revoked my Johnny Depp Fan Club membership for making that movie.

This isn't a movie everyone is going to enjoy - there are some disturbing parts (not sick-disturbing, or overly scary-disturbing, but he IS a creepy man), and its not the way a lot of people apparently imagined Wonka to be. But the children are all PERFECTLY cast, and the best scenes from the book are all here, in very grim and very excellent detail.

The movie adds a few scenes, but these are well done and in keeping with the story they were trying to tell. Its not a "purist's" favorite thing, but they work.

Well worth seeing in the theater. This was the first Hollywood movie I saw in Imax, and I don't regret that one bit - this movie was GREAT on Imax, and gave the whole thing a "larger than life" feel that wound perfectly with the theme of the movie.

See it. Even if you don't like it, you should still feel it was worth your time. Its a lot of fun!

title: Johnny Depp sounds like Michael Jackson, looks like Geena Davis
review:
The first film to be based on the book Charlie and the Chocolate Factory lives so strong in peoples minds that comparisons are unavoidable. The book isn't actually very long, and the setting (ie The Factory) is so static that scenarios are replayed identically, but not as well.

The film is badly constructed and badly edited throughout - the whole opening sequence is cliché and uninspired. The section where the visitors first enter the factory and wander up the shrinking hallway is poorly handled. One minute they're at one end, the next by a tiny door. No middle ground. No "is this hallway getting smaller?" moment. And no-one bats an eyelid when they get there. There's a problem with people's reactions to events throughout the entire film. As the dreadful dullards get knobbled off during the factory visits, their parents appear not to care less. 'Oh dear, Augustus has just gone up a shoot, where do I fetch him?'. And zooming about in the Great Glass Elevator didn't faze the characters one bit.

The film does very little to improve on the originals visuals. I was expecting great things from Burton's factory setting, but I gasped when we eventually got there - it looked exactly the same as it did in 1971! Slightly more colourful, perhaps - but no imagination had gone into the design whatsoever. Same with the chocolate river boat ride. 5 minutes of swooshing about hither and thither will never replace the truly disturbing visuals the original enforced upon the boat occupants; especially the chicken decapitation.

Helen BC's teeth - what's that all about? The acting is uniformly bad. The kids are dreadful. There must be thousands of pretentious pre-teen moppets who could play pretentious pre-teen moppets, but the girl cast as Veruca Salt is flat and lifeless.

I liked the Oompas, and thought there songs sounded great (Dahl wrote the lyrics as part of the story, so there's really no getting away from musical numbers) except, I couldn't hear the lyrics. If you're gonna have songs, let's hear them! I couldn't believe that David Kelly (Grandpa Joe) was still alive, and I though he might peg out on screen. Thankfully (?) he wasn't given very much to do.

Can someone with a better memory for the book confirm for me that there is a soppy side story involving Willy Wonkas estranged dentist father uprooting his terraced house to the Yorkshire moors, with Charlie acting as the catalyst for their emotional (read: vomit-inducing) reunion? I just don't remember it - or else I blocked its insipidness out of my mind.

Where is the film supposed to be set? It looked like England, but there was a lot of talk of dollars, and candy and band-aids.... the generic-euro setting of the first film is much better handled.

All in all a wasted opportunity.

title: A film for the weird... FINALLY!
review: If you are one of those people who are wonderfully weird in every way then this is the movie for you. It is much brighter, more colourful and more weird than the first version and I agree with the Dahl family that Roald would have preferred this to the first version. Johnny Depp's portrayal of Willy Wonka is more true to the Willy Wonka in the book than Gene Wilder's and still manages to look sexy while at the same time a bit creepy. I liked Tim Burton's modernisation of Mike Teavee that instead of watching t.v he's playing video games, a small change but effective. The oompa loompa are funny and their songs are very catchy. A great film, the best I've seen in ages!

title: Suspense (full of Spoilers)
review:
Watched this last night. As a film in it's own right it's pretty good, but is not anywhere near as good as the 1971 version.

What disappointed me most was how everything seemed so rushed. There was no suspense whatsoever. Every bar Charlie opened, he did fast. It didn't seem like a child who only gets 1 bar per year. The wait to enter the factory was non-existent, as soon as they got there they were allowed in. In hindsight, suspense is what made the 1971 one so good.

There was also a real lack of characterisation. Once in the factory most of the guests rarely speak, and if anything Charlie is the most outspoken. There is little conversation between the guests. There's too much concentration on Wonka being wacky. Also, why has Mike TeeVee got an interest in video games, not TVs.

Some of the "laughs" are also very poorly done. Grandma Josephine (?) who comes out with random comments - typical old person who can't hear, hilarious, not seen that before. Wonka walking into glass elevator, better do it twice in case no-one laughed the first time. Mike TeeVee "mumbling", just the three times for that one.

Also the Oompa Loompas were not particularly easy to understand. Old ones were miles better.

Now onto the ending, what's with all this family nonsense? This isn't in the book.

What's with Charlie offering to sell his ticket? Nonsense.

Not a bad film in all, but it's been hit by the American bug of making a film unnecessarily cheesy. Why didn't Wonka invite the whole family to the factory like in the book? Disappointing.

title: A fun movie for the whole family.
review:
Better than I had expected. It remained faithful to the book (I'm also a Roald Dahl nerd), which I was happy about, but one of the biggest problems was the SONGS. That could have remained faithful to the '71 movie. As an Oompa-Loompa for Halloween, I am very attached to the old Oompa Loompa songs. ;-) And the old tunes are very catchy, as compared to the new ones, not catchy and NOT REPEATED. *groan* But anyway, one of the best parts of the movie was Willy Wonka. Because you see, in the Roald Dahl book, Willy Wonka is very...well, batty. He is very strange and not at all paternal, unlike the way he is in the '71 version. The children were very good, very bratty. One thing that could have been improved (yet this is from the book, not the movie) is that you obviously knew who the winner is going to be from the very beginning. It would have been better if you had maybe a few moments of doubt. I liked Missi Pyle as Mrs. Beauregarde; she's a funny actress, and overall most of the cast was pretty good. So...10/10. Though it wasn't always done perfectly as I'd like it, it was done very well.

********** 10/10

title: An amazingly humorous and cute film!
review: A couple of weeks ago I had the pleasure of watching Charlie and the chocolate factory, and let me tell you I loved it! I thought it was soo cute, when I first thought of seeing it, I was all "Great. I am going to see a kids movie!" But it turned out to be so much more, Johnny Depp is a FANTASTIC actor. He did an amazing job.:) I was watching and at first I didn't think he really was good enough for the legendary role of Willy Wonka, but now I think he is the best! He was such an amazing character. I loved him, and I am so in love with this movie that next Sunday I am going to see it again. I think that it shouldn't have been called Charlie & the chocolate factory just because of the ending, because through the whole movie I was like its not really focused on charlie to much, its mostly about the wonders of Willy Wonka's chocolate factory. Thank you very much for reading, Krista

title: Excellent movie classic for the whole family!!!!!!!!
review: I recently went to see Tim Burton's "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" I thought it was EXCELLENT! It was all about a poor boy named Charlie Bucket who finds a golden ticket and gets to see Willy Wonka's chocolate factory and he's the only one who's not a brat, I must say so Wonka gives him the factory! Its a great movie for kids and even adults to watch! Johnny Depp did a great,but a little weird job playing Willy Wonka. Freddie Hingmore is an excellent cute little child actor and the rest of the kids, Julia Winter, Annasophia Robb, Jordan Fry etc were awesome! Fun for the whole family from chocolate river Agustus,to gum chewing Violet, to bratty rich Veruca, to game kid Mike, and then to the nicest of all Charlie.

title: Well i like it!
review: I love the movie, its funny and the music is great, it could have added a few more interesting things from the book, its a shame they didn't! Oh well, I still love it! I think Jim Carey would have been a great Willy Wonka but Johnny Depp did a great job too. Freddie did a great job at being Charlie, I don't know if Charlie's supposed to be English...? Annesophia was really good, she must have been if she annoyed me that much acting as Violet Beaureguard!! The Oompa Lumpas were great and the songs were really good! At least in this movie, they had the words from the book in the songs unlike the 1971 version. I've always loved Roald Dahl books and the movies are always great! I love it!

title: What a Wonderful Movie
review: I really loved this movie a lot. From the beginning until the end. The graphics were beautifully done, the storyline from the book was wonderfully followed. The songs will definitely have you bouncing in your seat! For anyone who hasn't seen it, you need to go in with the mind set that it is NOT A REMAKE OF THE LAST FILM. Tim Burton has said this movie was his view on the book. For all of the time he put into this movie, i think it was worth it. Tim Burton did a great job making this film to appeal to all generations, and it was definitely a movie ill be seeing again and again in the theaters. I've already seen it three times! ^^

title: Wonderfully Childish
review:
I'm a bit young to remember Gene Wilder's famous performance in Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory, but I found myself smiling throughout this particular version of the story. Note that I use the word "childish" here quite a bit. This is by no means a bad thing in this movie.

Johnny Depp does a wonderful job in the movie, giving us a glimpse of a mildly mad eccentric. The character has something of a childishness that is extremely nice, with a fairy tale styled faith that is uplifting and bright. At the same time, there is an almost sinister element to Willy Wonka. This element is perfectly played, however, and it adds depth to the character (and to certain scenes) that I considered most welcome

Freddie Highmore is wonderful as the charming and exceedingly kind-hearted Charlie. This movie is worth seeing with your children for the simple example of altruism and sweetness that this character evokes. Such children as Charlie are far too rare these days, and his gratefulness and his familial loyalties are exquisitely played.

What Charlie and the Chocolate Factory provides is a sense of wonder and childish excitement. To examine such a film with a critic's eye is precisely the antithesis of what the movie's theme is. The movie IS candy. Appreciate it for the childish joy and the lessons about the various vices that the children (aside from Charlie) display. Go in and enjoy a fairy tale type of magic, where you get to see things that would make your most childish dreams come true.

title: Enjoyed very much
review: My wife, my 6 yr old daughter, and myself really enjoyed the movie extremely. We love the Tim Burton/Jonny Depp take on the story. I have not read the book, but I hear this version follows the book closer than the Gene Wilder story. Please, don't get me wrong, I also very much enjoyed the Gene Wilder version. I don't feel the two can be compared. I feel they are two different, very well told takes on the same story. We liked the look back into Willy Wonka's childhood, and introducing us to his father. I also believe the advancement in special effects helped a lot in making the movie as good as it is. My next task is to read the book.

title: Loved this movie
review: I was at first skeptical to see this movie based on the original, Gene Wilder version, because I thought nothing could compare. Well, was I ever wrong. I enjoyed every minute of this movie from the time it started until the last credit (which, I might add, were LOOOOOONG, with no special afterword's, so don't bother staying). I loved it, loved it, loved it. I wanted to cry, and just when I thought "if I see one more scene" I will cry, I laughed my head off for the rest of the movie. I loved the fact that Willie Wonka's childhood was reviewed (which explained a lot) and I also loved the fact that Charlie's family was so well portrayed. MUST SEE, MUST SEE. Bravo, Johnny Depp. Bravo, again, Tim Burton.....

title: Fantastic stuff
review:
I have seen this film twice, and have loved it both times, and I am going back for more. This movie is as true to the book as you could probably get, and the stuff referring to Wonka's dad brings you closer to him, to know what he went through.

I've read some negative comments about this movie, and I don't understand why ? This film was brilliant, Depp as Wonka couldn't have been better, all eccentric and crazy. Excellent. And then Freddy as Charlie. What a kid, he is such a great actor for his age, and really made me feel for him. The Oompa Loompa's were also great, with just the right amount of songs throughout the movie, and the right ones, straight from the book. Danny Elfman is a great composer, and he put the right music in the right places to make the audience feel like they should, sympathetic, happy, sad and many others.

The fact that there was only one part with Slugworth mentioned, pleased me a lot. There was too much of him in the original and it just spoiled it to have such a bad character in the original.

All those Burton and Depp fans out there, go and see this. In fact, everyone go and see it. You will love this just as much I do. Hopefully.

title: Charlie Bucket wins one of five golden tickets to tour Willy Wonka's amazing chocolate factory.
review: Enjoyed this film immensely, largely because of Johnny Depp's amazing performance as Willy Wonka and the wonderful visuals, true eye candy, that Tim Burton offered up. Actor Deep Roy CGI duplicated dozens or hundreds of times as all of the Oompa Loompas was such an example that comes to mind. An added little bonus of great casting was the wonderful elderly, talented actor Christopher Lee (now 83 and still going strong from what I can tell), playing a stern dentist. Some of the musical numbers were fun and imaginative, while a few weren't anything to write home about. The movie is a bit disturbing in places for young children, but well-done overall.

title: "WoW"
review:
What a great movie. Johnny Depp really dose a great job, and Tim Burton also dose a bang up job. This one is more true the book, or so I hear, I myself have not read the book but to my friends I have they say is more close to it. The music was 5 stars. Danny Elfman is just one of the best.

So over all the movie is great, it funny, good in almost every way but nothing is perfect. So let me hit up a few of the negatives. The CGI was great, but i think some parts could of been better. I kinda felt that some parts of it where rushed and overall the movie should of been longer.

But over all, great movie and you really should stop reading and get up and go see it.

title: Best Family Film of the Summer
review: Tim Burton and Johnny Depp have done it once again in this amazing adaptation of the Dahl classic book 'Charlie and the Chocolate factory'. From the snowy streets of Britain, to the crazy jungles of Loompa-Land, all the way to India, to the dentist's office, and inside the factory with witty and eccentric Mr. Willy Wonka (Johnny Depp) and Oompa Loompas (Deep Roy, Deep Roy, Deep Roy (X about 500)!)) So this summer join four nasty kids, one good kid, an amazing chocolateer (young and old) and his dentist dad, oompa-loompas, squirrels, and a Prince for the wild ride of the summer which will have you saying "SWEET!"

title: Absolutely awful film
review:
*** Possible spoilers *** I took my two teenage nieces to see this movie and we all absolutely hated this movie with a passion. I can not see how people say this is not a remake of the first. Almost everything is exactly the same with exception to the beginning and the end.

Sure, this movie adds more history to what made Wonka the way he is, but at the same time that's all this movie is about is Wonka. The children and parents in this movie were horrid, their acting was terrible. Now I know it's not the children themselves, but rather the directing and script, which is sad. This movie could have been so much more than it was.

The Oompa Loompa was down right disgusting. The stupid songs trying to be cool where nothing more than pathetic and annoying. I was not put off by the new look of the Oompa Loompa, but just rather the singing bits which again were stupid.

Johnny Depp playing Willy Wonka... well, at first I didn't like the way he looked or talked, but by the end of the movie I thought it sort of fit the part, especially with the new background of his childhood. He was however still too creepy and weird and should have been a little more Gene Wilderish at times. I think somewhere between the two character portrayals is the way Wonka should be, sort of strange, yet mysterious and spooky.

They should have focused just a little more on Charle and his grandfather. I sort of felt cheated with regards to them. I thought the little boy who played Charlie was really good when he was on screen. He really did make a good Charlie and I did like how he was so loyal towards his family, which is something Wonka didn't have nor could understand.

At times the CGI was okay, but other times it made you want to throw your popcorn at the screen hoping to make it look better. I did however like the room with the chocolate waterfall. I think Burton did a great job with that and the boat ride was okay, sort of dead though after the kooky one from the first movie.

If it weren't for my two nieces I would have probably walked out on this movie. It is really not worth your time nor money to go see. It's so bad I wouldn't even wait for it to come out on DVD to rent. This is a pretty harsh movie to watch and coming from me its even more difficult to speak about. I usually enjoy all movies and rarely will I get the disgusted, hateful feeling I did while seeing this movie. I wouldn't call it trash, but rather a HUGE disappointment that Tim Burton should be ashamed of.

But hey, to each his/her own. Each person is different, perhaps you will enjoy it and think its great, but I know we all thought it was terrible.

title: Very enjoyable and interesting
review: Well, I just saw it and it was pretty good. Johnny Depp did a great job as Willy Wonka. The way he portrayed Wonka's twisted love for candy was simply amazing. It was eerie, yet you'd expect it. Gene Wilder's portrayal of Wonka was okay, but that was merely just a childish appreciation of candy. As for Depp's portrayal, he was driven to the point to acknowledging candy to be the root of all reasoning. And Burton's style was clearly evident throughout the movie and totally helped strengthen the movie. A couple things that got to me was the Grandpa, the scene where he was dancing kind of annoyed and disappointed me. I was kinda of scared when I saw him do that... Also, I personally didn't like the songs the Oompa Loompas sang. They just weren't as cool as the originals. The cast for the kids were chosen and played very well. The only thing I'm currently basing this on is the movie, because I still have yet to read the book. The flashbacks were great though, by doing that Willy Wonka is developed to the point where you can realize what's driven him to do the things he has done. All in all, it was a very enjoyable film and just plain good fun.

title: A Magnificent Treat!
review:
I was trembling with excitement to hear that once again Johnny Depp and Tim Burton were to combine their unique talents together once again to film the remake of Charlie and the Chocolate Factory.

I am,admittedly, a huge fan of Johnny Depp and Tim Burton as both a combined team and alone and was eager to be one of the first to see it when It came out in the cinema. I was one of the lucky people as I was in America when it was released in the UK but still managed to go and see it two days earlier than any of my friends back home.

Anyway, more of the movie. The attention to detail is spectacular as Depp lends his quirky personality to the character of Willy Wonka and creates a wonderfully weird true-to-the-book chocolatier for whom the audience empathises with and recoils from simultaneously.

In short I believe that this movie is possibly the best I will see this year and the genius to include Johnny Depp as Willy Wonka himself is a spectacular feat. I give two up to Tim Burton and Johnny Depp and eagerly await the release of the duo's next cinema adventure, Corpse Bride.

title: Choc-Factory remake is a non-success for me!
review: Recently watched the remake of Charlie And The Chocolate factory with eager anticipation. As a Child I loved Roald Dahl books and also the 1970's version was magical to me. So in retrospect the new one had a lot to live up to! Unfortunately in my eyes it failed to deliver the goods. Johnny Depp is a fantastic actor, no one can deny that, his portray of Capt Jack Sparrow in Pirates of the Carribbean was nothing short of pure genius. Depp's Wonka, however, is wrong. Gone is the magical and mysterious Wonka portrayed by the charismatic Gene Wilder, here is some-kind of camp, feminine version more Michael Jackson than anything. Depp's Wonka has an great deal less presence and stature in the movie, far far far to cheerleader-like - this would surely have had old Dahl turning in his grave! To sum up, the new movie is far less entertaining and colourful than the 70's original - as a boy it was more so believable and amazing - it still is, but unfortunately this version is too dark and uncomfortable for me. There are some funny moments - particularly when the ooompa loompa's (played by one actor - very clever trick photography) are involved - but the changing of certain key story lines and Depp's portrayal of Wonka was the negative aspects. He could have done it so much better!

title: Very Well Casted, Directed, and Just Brilliant!
review:
Charlie and the Chocolate Factory: Freddie Highmore, Johnny Depp, Missi Pyle, Annasophia Robb.

Directed By: Tim Burton 10/10

Since this was Tim Burton, the guy who directed many brilliant cartoons and such I thought to see this, it was an excellent movie, this was better than the version with Gene Wilder because Tim Burton made this movie seem all real and made it more active and comedic than the old version itself. It was better cast and directorial because it related to the book and not just another non remake. If everyone read the book believe me this is the real thing.

title: its great
review: yeah it's not based on the original its based on the book, BASED, that doesn't mean exactly the same! so if your gonna moan about it being nothing like the original or the book then don't bother go to see it, i myself think its better then the first! and Johnny Depp is just ace as Willy Wonka, so funny. it just follows the storyline of the book not word for word! Tim Burton films are ace to start with anyway so that makes it already a great film! i think that it is way way better then the first and most people will not be disappointed by it. only one Oompa Lumpa is in it and yet he does a great job. so get your self out there and enjoy the film!!!!!

title: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is a fun film for the whole family!
review:
If you have read the book and/or seen the Gene Wilder film then the premise of this film is familiar to you. It is the story of an eccentric candy maker who gives a tour of his factory to five lucky children. Four of the children are brats and then there's Charlie. Charlie Bucket is portrayed in this film by Finding Neverland's Freddie Highmore, who delivers a solid performance. If this young performer continues at this rate he could end up a respected actor like his fellow Finding Neverland co-star, Johnny Depp. Depp, of course, plays Willy Wonka in this film. It is his fourth collaboration with director Tim Burton. Similar to the previous collaborations, Depp and Burton try their best to do something different. And, like their previous collaborations the final product is a success.

The film I felt was very well done. It was fun and I think the whole family will enjoy. The songs by Danny Elfman were very funny and I think could earn Mr. Elfman another Oscar-Nomination. And, like every Tim Burton film it features amazing production designs and solid cinematography.

The big question, however, is if it's better than the 1971 adaptation of the Dahl's classic children's book. While this film remained closer to the book and improved in certain areas, I felt the original is superior. Most of it has to do because of Gene Wilder's interpretation of Willy Wonka. Depp does a very well job, but he can't compete with Wilder's Wonka. That was the magic of the original film.

RATING: 4 (****) out of (****)

title: This is the best movie!
review: This movie is one of the best I have ever seen. All Johnny Depp/ Tim Burton films are awesome. After I went to see this movie, I went back to my friends house and watched Edward Scissorhands and Sleepy Hollow, both of which are brilliantly written, hilarious, and cine graphically beautiful. It's just the way that all the scenes look pseudo-modern times, like in The Series of Unfortunate Events. The Victorian references are dazzling. And I want Willy's outfit so bad. The hat, the gloves, the coat, it's all working. My absolute favorite part of the movie is in the Chocolate River Room. " Everything in this room is eatable, Even I'm eatable. But that's called cannibalism children, and is frowned upon in most societies." Greatness!

title: Hits the Sweet Tooth.
review: I just got back to the first viewing of this at my local cinema, and I was blown away by this sickly-sweet treat! I was so eager to see this, as I love the Gene Wilder original, however after watching the remake I fell in love with it even more than I had fell in love with the original. It certainly stayed more faithful to the book than the original did, for example this film keeps the squirrel scene, where Veruca is proved to be a bad nut, and is then thrown down the garbage chute, and there are also extra scenes which we never see in the original, such as Oompa-Loopma-Land, however it added a dark and eerie story about Willy Wonka's childhood, which was certainly an interesting addition. I had to say in my opinion too, that I enjoyed the Oopma-Loompa songs in this remake far more than I enjoyed the ones from the original, and the fact that only one actor played every single Oompa-Loompa was a good chuckle too. I thought Freddie Highmore and Johnny Depp stole every scene with their quality acting, and Depp was excellent, as a dark, twisted, witty Willy Wonka. The film is certainly more twisted than the 1971 version, but it is still eye-pleasingly colourful and fun, both for children and adults alike. I highly recommend this sweet trip to Willy Wonka's factory. Dare to venture into his wonders, and indulge in the sweet, sweet hilarity and madness. You won't be unsatisfied.

title: Good from an objective point of view; poor when compared with possibilities
review:
I would have enjoyed this movie much more had I not become a huge fan of the 1971 version of Charlie a long time ago. However, when I went to see Burton's take on it, I spent the whole movie comparing the two. As many other people said, it doesn't do either justice to try and decide which one is "better". Neither is genuinely true to the book, so die-hard book fans will probably still be left unhappy (although I must admit that Burton stayed much closer to Dahl's original, despite the sub-plots that the movie threw in). This is a good movie to see if you come in unprejudiced or if you didn't like the other version, but otherwise, it will seem like a mediocre shade of the '71 movie/book.

My first problem with this film is Johnny Depp. I, personally, found him extremely annoying, but perhaps not so much because of his acting as because of the script. Having grown up with Gene Wilder's version, I never saw Willy Wonka as aloof and rude. Sure, Depp had his funny moments, but when he wasn't being funny, I wanted to strangle him. I saw no connections, no opinions from him about the kids except dislike. It just didn't seem right to me. I thought Wonka was childish, not petulant. Even if his performance wasn't based off of Michael Jackson, it sure came off that way.

The children were a mixed bag. Augustus was good, given the limited time he had. Veruca and Charlie were fine, not too overdone. But every time Violet or Mike came on screen, I wished for the movie to suddenly skip until they were gone. Violet has been updated to be an snobby overachiever instead of just a gum chewer (which I never found anything too bad about, personally; her only problem was that she was greedy and obstinate and just took Wonka's gum without asking). People like that are bad enough in real life, and I really don't want to go to movie-fantasy-world just to see more of them. Mike Teevee became an arrogant hacker-type who didn't really start to really get on my nerves until later on. Personally, I hate to pay in order to watch a movie that annoys me, although it does have some redeeming humorous moments.

I could go on for a while, but most of the other problems are minor and fade into the background. One addition, though, that many people have griped about, was Wonka's background, not present in the book. I found that to be one of the few good qualities of the movie. At least it wasn't changing something that had already been done; it just filled up a black hole that was never there. And while Depp is butchering Wonka anyways, why not go the whole way? I found it quite funny, actually. It also helped me deal with Depp's unsympathetic Wonka more. While the book version and Wilder's take didn't really need sympathy, Depp did. He really, really did.

Final Take: Go to this movie if you are in a good mood and you don't expect to be easily annoyed; avoid if you're a die-hard fan of Dahl or Wilder, unless you want to go to vindicate your belief that this will be a horrible mess. It's fun for a while, better than doing nothing and definitely better than most kids' movies. 6/10

title: A Poor Boy Wins An Opportunity, A Strange Man's Imagination Takes Candy As Its Form, An Artist Sits In The Director's Chair, This Film Cannot Go Wrong...And It Didn't
review:
After I heard the news that Tim Burton and Johnny Depp were working together again on a film called Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, I knew that this film could not fail audiences; particularly myself.

I'm sure most of you know the story of the film from its musical originator, Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory from 1971; so I won't bother giving you an idea of this story's plot. I very much enjoyed the story of the film, where director Tim Burton added a few things to make it more fun to watch; which I won't say.

I have an opinion on both leading roles of the film. Like everyone says, the film was very quirky and Johnny Depp's interpretation of the fabulous chocolatier Willy Wonka was thought by many to be creepy. In my opinion, Depp's vision as Wonka was far more original than I'd thought it would be. The new Wonka was more eccentric, childlike, emotional, and above all more quirky.

The second leading actor, Freddie Highmore as Charlie Bucket, impressed me a little more on a different level. Highmore's portrayal of the title character was also far more original that I had expected. His character had very much of a heart of gold and Highmore was talented enough to make all of Charlie's feelings and intentions genuine. I am impressed by these acting skills from a boy his age.

As for director Tim Burton, I was just as impressed with his performance on the film's production than I was with Depp's. I've always thought that Burton's visions of his past films were very creative and inspiring. So it was no surprise that I'd count this as his best film up to date. I think that Burton visualized exactly what author Roald Dahl was thinking of when he wrote the children's novel. Heck, he might've been the only man on Earth able to do it! The chocolate factory was filled with adventure in every corner, the Oompa-Loompas were very animated, and everything was just incredible. Danny Elfman's musical score of this film was very powerful and the "heaviest notes" were very inspiring.

I am grateful that I got the chance to watch this at IMAX theaters. I most definitely recommend this mind-blowing and heart-warming film for the entire family. I certainly hope this review is helpful to you all.

Regards,

J.C. Urbina

title: Another Summer Bummer
review:
Burton's version of this classic '70's flick is just another stink bomb in the bummer summer of 2005.

Mr. Depp is a great actor, and one who has voiced his love of playing odd roles, and he pulls out a real doozy with his version of Willy Wonka. But do we really like this character? My answer is a clear no. He's way too creepy, and his motivations for having the golden ticket contest are never made believable in this picture.

Freddy Highmore as Charlie is one of the few bright spots in this current retelling.

The "new and improved" Oompa Loompas were a total bust. The new songs were the worst and I had no idea what the lyrics were even saying.

This version may be more faithful to the book, don't know as I never read it, but it sure makes for a lame movie.

The 1970's version clearly lacked the visual pizazz of the Burton flick, but it made up for that ten-fold by packing the story with heart. The Gene Wilder Wonka had a warmth, the Slugworth character gave Charlie and the other kids a much clearer dilemma. And many moments like the one where a kind-hearted Charlie momentarily tricks his grand folks into thinking he has the Golden Ticket because he wanted to see them all happy, are sadly missing from the new flick.

But worst of all this new version of the famous chocolate factory movie lacks "pure imagination", and I mean that in all its meanings.

I'm Tex Nickle and I seriously doubt this new version will live on in anyone's hearts and minds.

title: Lots of flashing lights and pretty colors, not much else
review:
I wasn't too happy when I heard that Tim Burton was remaking WILLY WONKA, or should I say, re-adapting Roald Dahl's book CHARLIE AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY, and the initial previews didn't make me feel any better. But, I went to see it with an open mind, and was pleasantly surprised.

At first.

The first twenty minutes are great. The introduction of all the characters is often hilarious, even surpassing the original movie at times. Violet and Mike are somewhat re-vamped, while Augustus and Veruca are basically identical, but the kids who play them are all very funny.

But when we finally get to the Chocolate Factory, things immediately go downhill. There are some amusing effects and cool set design, but the spirit of the original movie, and Dahl's original story, are absent. The movie just moves from one bigger, more elaborate version of the original set-pieces to the next, with no inspiration and no new spin.

Johnny Depp's portrayal of Willy Wonka is mind-boggling. What is this character supposed to be? An adult child? A clueless shut-in? Or just a generic weirdo? Depp brings nothing to the character, he just talks like Mr. Rogers' psycho cousin and makes a lot of funny faces, somehow managing to come off as wooden. Gene Wilder played the character like a mysterious genius who knew more than he was telling his guests. Depp plays the character like a goofy buffoon who's simply a poor host.

The actor who plays all of the Oompa-Loompas is funny for about one minute, then that joke grows increasingly tiresome. By the time he's dressed up like a rock star doing pinwheels, it's just plain stupid.

The screenplay is very lazily written. Situations pop up in the story which then go nowhere, such as Violet and Veruca sharing a private glance at the mention of Ever-Lasting Gobstoppers, but then nothing coming of it. It's as though the writer decided to get rid of anything he felt was extraneous to the plot; in other words, he wanted to get to the next special effects sequence quickly, and keep that pesky plot as bare-to-the-bones as possible. It's obvious the filmmakers feel that their audience wants flashing lights and pretty colors, not an interesting story.

And that is the problem with CHARLIE AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY. There's no shortage of things to look at, but once the novelty of that wears off, there's nothing more to it. Even a subplot involving Chirstopher Lee as Wonka's father is thrown in almost as an afterthought, then tossed aside as soon as it's served its purpose. Like so many Hollywood extravaganzas, there's a lot of CGI pizazz and mumbo-jumbo, but no soul.

The best I can say for CHARLIE AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY is that it is better than Burton's PLANET OF THE APES. Then again, so was PLAN 9 FROM OUTER SPACE.

title: A real ride!
review: I couldn't stand the first film adaptation of Dahl's book, so I was a bit reluctant to see the newer one. I ended up loving every second of it. It's hardly disturbing at all, and crazily fun to watch. Even the Oompah Loompahs were cool. I totally recommend this movie and give it nine out of ten stars (the missing star is for the continuity mistakes, which thankfully aren't very noticeable). Johnny Depp does a great performance as Willy Wonka, and I was very pleased overall with the "dark atmosphere" that Tim Burton's directing gave to it. Dark, but not disturbing or scary--that's the way to do it! There's even some humorous scenes to lighten the mood. Needless to say I walked out with a craving for chocolate.

title: wow!
review: I've seen it a couple of days ago and I loved it!!!! I thought Johnny D could never play Willy Wonka as good as Gene Wilder did in the old version. Actually i thought it would be a rip-off of some kind that it would be just the same as the old one but with new actors. I was wrong. I went because a friend and I wanted to go to a movie but there wasn't something really exciting in the cinema close by so alright, why not, it's a nice day for a movie so we'll just go. We laughed a lot because it was pretty funny. I think Johnny D did great. It's not like the old version, they've changed a lot. I saw it in dutch because it didn't play in English yet, normally I don't like movies spoken in dutch but this time i did. Good movie. An 8 at least!!!!!

title: It Melts In Your Mouth!
review: I saw Charlie & The Chocolate Factory today and it was very good. I guess the only real major downside was that you pretty much know what's going to happen if you saw the original movie. Johnny Depp was a bit Michael-Jackson-like as I'd heard, but it didn't spoil the movie or anything. Tim Burton didn't disappoint as far as visuals go. The kids in the movie were all great, and very well cast. The new songs were cool, and I liked the flashbacks to Willy Wonka's childhood. They helped flesh out his origin, and that was a nice touch. They changed a few story elements around a bit. Charlie's Mom & Dad are alive, and Grandpa once worked at the chocolate factory. There was no Mr. Slugworth trying to buy secrets from the kids. There was also no scene where the kids had to sign a contract, or a scene where Charlie and Grandpa disobey Willy Wonka's rules. It was very well done.

title: Best Remake I've EVER Seen
review: I've already seen this movie twice in the theaters and I'm amazed at how faithful it is to one of my favorite books. Charlie and The Chocolate Factory. Freddie Highmore, David Kelly, Johnny Depp and many more of the acting was just spectacular! The older 70s film was no where near as good as this film. Johnny DEpp and Deep Roy mad me bust a gut! The ending was great with the stories of Willie and his father the strict candy-hating dentist. I could go on and on and bore all the IMDb users about how much I like this film but I'm going to stop and leave you with these four words.GO SEE THIS MOVIE!!! P.S. See it twice like me!

title: Austin Movie Show review
review: This is definitely the most "interesting looking" movie of the summer. The production design will blow your mindbut nothing else will. Tim Burton is a genius at creating timeless, magical, mystical, and absurd realities (like he did in Edward Scissorhands and the first two Batman movies), and his interpretation of the famous chocolate factory is other-worldly. But besides great visuals, there's not a whole lot more to Charlie and the Chocolate Factory. Even Johnny Depp, as the Great Willy Wonka himself, was pretty forgettable. The greatest performance, hands down, was that of Freddie Highmore who played Charlie Bucket. He has such natural talent, but unfortunately he didn't have much of a script to work with  no one did. Also disappointing were the Oompa Loompas (all played by a single actor, Deep Roy). I liked the idea of their almost Amazonian / tribal background, but their songs were ridiculous and musically bad. A forgettable remake.

title: Tim Burton drops the ball!
review: I disagree with most of the comments I have read, although the movie was kind of dark, anyone who knows Tim Burton movies, will know that he is a strange individual and this is normal movie making for him. The movie is just fine for kids, as a matter of fact, your kids will enjoy the movie more than you will. You will have trouble staying awake, especially during the musical scenes. Having said that, their where many problems with this film. First, growing up seeing Willie Wonka (Gene Wilder) was an opportunity to see a classic story that you could watch whenever you felt down, Charlie's character was so believable and heart warming, he represented someone that a lot of people could relate to. The new version jumped around so much, you never got a feel for Charlie, as a matter of fact, the story seemed to be more about Willie Wonka than Charlie, unlike the original. Second, some of the most memorable parts of the original movie where the musical numbers, especially Willie Wonka, Charlie and the Oompa-Loompa's. The new version bordered on annoying. Third, Tim Burton dropped the ball on this one, it could have been a great movie if he would of gone with a sequel, instead of a remake. The story line was already there for him to follow, Charlie grows up and realizes that he is not a child anymore, so he invites five new kids to find one like himself when he was young to help him come up with new ideas. It would have been easy to come up with new characters and ideas with todays technology. Fourth, although I like Johnny Depp as Willie Wonka, I think he over played the character, which would not have been the case if this was a sequel, because then he would be creating his own character as a grown up Charlie, who would be about the same age as Depp now anyways. Gene Wilder is irreplaceable as Willie Wonka, like Marlon Brando as the Godfather or Al Pacino as Tony Montana. The Oompa-Loompa character was even more of a disappointment, the idea of getting one person and CGIing him into the scenes to create more of them was not only ridiculous, it was a disservice to the many "little people" who probably have trouble finding good work in Hollywood as it is. Last, I was extremely disappointed with this new version and even sadder to say, I definitely will not be adding this one to my DVD collection when it comes out. It does not even come close to reaching the classic status of Willie Wonka and the Chocolate Factory!
