In the end: if there's one thing that filmmakers need to learn, it's that you can't go back to Oz.

title: Bad Script, Poor Set Design, Any Director Would Do
review:
Pretty lame script and Depp kept taking me "out" of the picture because he was so...so...Johnny Depp weird!

And the set design inside the factory was just awful -- very much "Wizard of Oz" sound-stage -- and that was 70 years ago! Poor lighting, too.

And I think ANY director could have put this picture through its pacings -- even the audience (in NYC) was restless. You could tell we all wanted to enjoy ourselves, but it just went on and on and on, one poorly stages scene after the other.

And the word play and jokes? Fell on dead ears, as the saying goes.

With all the talent, and the wonderful story, this one really missed it.

title: Fantastic and endearing, while slightly creepy
review:
I am not a huge fan of the 1971 Willy Wonka movie, but found it entertaining, especially Gene Wilder's wildly mood-swinging portrayal of Wonka. His understated delivery of "No, stop, don't" has even found its way into my own lexicon.

So, when my teen daughter and I saw the trailer for Burton's Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, we both had the same response... Johnny Depp looks sooooo..... WEIRD!!!!!! We agreed we HAD to see it just to see Depp's performance. I was prepared for the possibility of disaster.

We saw it opening day, at the earliest matinÃ©e. I was impressed throughout, and laughed out loud at numerous times. The audience was mostly Moms with elementary aged children, so my mid-teen daughter may have felt a little out of place being there with her dad. But we both loved it! Interestingly, during some of the scenes where I was laughing, she would look at me and say, "What are you laughing at? That's SCARY!!!!!!" Which of course made me laugh more.

Forget all the talk about Depp channeling Michael Jackson. Maybe people have Jackson on the brain because he was recently in the news. I was aware of the Jackson comparisons before seeing the movie, and it was not at all a distraction. Depp was Willy Wonka. Not Michael Jackson, not Michael Jackson-as-Willy Wonka.

Go see this movie, and take your kids. Burton has made a movie thoroughly entertaining for all ages.

title: New Wonka not worth watching
review:
Watching Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is like eating a sugar-free chocolate bar: It looks delicious, but it leaves a funny aftertaste, and the overall experience is unsatisfying.

Johnny Depp's low-key, effeminate portrayal of Willy Wonka is the worst and cannot even be compared to the Gene Wilder's brilliant performance in the 1971 classic Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory. Depp is a good actor, but Wilder was a comic genius. Wilder's Wonka was a manic, frenetic, menacing, scrumpdiddleumptious delight. Depp's creation is just sad and creepy.

Naturally, the whole film is done in Tim Burton's dark/gloomy/Gothic style. Sure, the effects are better than the 1971 film, but the magic that thrilled kids of my generation is disappointingly missing in the new film.

The regally lovely Helena Bonham Carter is wasted as Charlie's mother. Burton decided to make her look gruesomely dowdy and her make-up includes gray and gunky teeth. In fact, everyone's teeth looked nasty in the movie, and looking up at them on a giant screen was making me sick. What's up with the close-ups on the ugly choppers, Tim? Jeez! Danny Elfman's score was predictably good, and his attempt to update and out-do the Oompa Loompa song and dance routines was the best part of the movie.

I still have vivid memories of the fantastic performances turned in by the child actors from the 1971 film. Veruca Salt screaming, I want it NOW!" Mike Teevee's shrunken voice saying, "Am I coming in clear?" Violet Beauregarde's gum-snapping, snappy comments. Those kids embodied the bad habits their character's represented. The kids in this new batch don't even come close.

title: Uneven and creepy
review:
This movie seems to veer from being sweet and old-fashioned to modern and mean-spirited, with periods of being thoroughly creepy as well. I would not have thought that I could be more disturbed by this second film adaptation than I was by the first, given that I was approximately four years old when I saw the first _Charlie and the Chocolate Factory_. However, I found this new version to be very disturbing at times.

The four stars that I have given it are primarily for the first third of the movie. There are some very funny moments, an excellent cast, and a certain style that I have to admire. However, I wouldn't recommend this movie, and would suggest that parents of very young children not take the little ones to see it.

title: What is the opposite of amazing?
review: Whatever it is, it is definitely not the description for this charming, amazing and spellbinding take of the classic story directed by the brilliant mind of Tim Burton. After reading the whimsical book by famed children's author Roald Dahl and watching the Gene Wilder film, I just felt that the film was missing an important element that the book had. But in this film Burton catches that element and milks it for all it's worth. The factory is not the land of OZ as it was depicted in the Gene Wilder version, the Oompa Loompas are not happy go lucky leprechauns and Mr. Willy Wonka is not Mr. Rogers, he is, if I dare say it, a brilliant mix of J.D. Salinger's anger towards society and Howard Hughe's longing for a sanctuary. Once again, Johnny Depp takes us for a wild thrill ride as he did in Pirates of the Caribbean. Freddie Highmore sprinkles some his dramatic charm as the impoverished Charlie Bucket. Danny Elfman sends chills up the audiences' spines with his forebodingly poetic and eerily delightful score and Tim Burton strikes out with his imaginative design and brilliantly dark direction. This film is one of 2005's best so far and I hope it is up for an Oscar.

title: Great version of story
review:
I liked everything about the movie except that the Oompa Loompa singing was somewhat annoying. It was so high-pitched it was hard to understand the lyrics, although the parts I COULD understand were very clever.

The Depp/Burton version is more reflective of the dark humor characteristic of Dahl's writing.

The references I've seen to Michael Jackson are simply reflections of our time. Willy Wonka was actually the opposite of a pedophile, if you examine him more closely you'll see that he didn't really care too much for children. That's part of the irony of it being a "children's story."

title: I am ridiculously impressed with this movie! Just got back from the theater, still amazed, but not speechless, so read on!
review:
I have been anticipating the release of this movie since I first heard about it, over a year ago, both being a huge fan of Tim Burton, and the amazing Mr. Depp. I had counted down the months, weeks, days, and then hours till I got to see it, pumping myself up in the extreme, and I have NOT been disappointed!! Tim Burton's "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" is easily one of the best films I've ever seen.It was humorous, touching, and of course, as with many Burton films, very strange at parts.

The Oompa-loompas were all played by one man, the same who played Mr. Soggybottom in Big Fish. These Loompas have the singing roles after each child's disappearance, just like in the 70's version, but this time they use the lyrics that were in the book. Danny Elfman provides all the voice talent, and is amazing as usual.

The kids are also excellent portrayals of the children described in the book. Each child nailed his or her part perfectly. Of course, Freddie Highmore as Charlie is particularly delightful, since he's so adorable and charming. I especially liked Violet Beauregarde's portrayal, it seemed so dead on as what I envisioned in the book when I read it when I was younger.

Another amazing aspect of this movie was the humour. 50%of the time, I was in stitches from laughing so hard. This is by far the funniest Tim Burton film EVER. This version of "Charlie..." is 100 times funnier than the 70's version. And almost all the humour is family-friendly.

The visuals were stunning, it's a real treat for the eyes. So much colour! Everything was really surreal looking, it was beautiful. I loved the camera angles. Also, the Bucket's house is pretty interesting, still can't figure how it was standing.

And I can't finish this comment without commending the AMAZING performance by Johnny Depp as Willy Wonka. He played such an eccentric, immature, and sometimes distant version of the chocolatier, quite different from that of Gene Wilder's Wonka in the original. I think it was a really great thing that he didn't try to play the character the same way, because Wilder's portrayal would have been VERY hard to match.

Anyway, yes, I must stop rambling, just SEE THE MOVIE!! You will NOT regret it!!

title: Get up and go watch it....it is AWESOME
review:
All I can say is WOW, I went to see the movie today and everybody that was making the line wanted to see Charlie. Of course I had to be one of the first to see it and i loved it. I mean for those that are questioning about the 1970's version, this explains it all, why is he like that, where does the Oompa Loompas come from and why, etc. The songs were very cheerful, specially the first song "Willy Wonka" and its a very touching movie. I think choosing Johnny Depp as the Willy Wonka was an awesome idea because that's how Willy Wonka is suppose to be, full of secrets, not so nice, and weird. So I recommend everybody to see this movie, even if you think its not going to be good, you'll totally change your mind. I think personally it is SO freaking much better than the 1970's version. So go and see it....

"Chewing gum is really gross, chewing gum I hate the most"

title: Loved it- different from the first, but still good.
review: I really loved the new "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory". It was Tim Burton "dark" in places, but it wasn't too dark. My 8 year old and I saw it today and thought that it was different enough from the original that they can compliment each other well, but be judged on their own merit. The characters were true to the original for the most part, with a few small changes. The situations were a little different, some were a little funnier I thought. Willie Wonka revealed a little more of himself in this movie. The oompah loompahs are funkier and we find out more about where they originated. They all are identical this time, but they weren't in the first one, I don't think. Check the credits this time- I think there was only one! Aren't computer graphics wonderful?!! Go see this movie...it's worth the time and money.

title: Wonderful take on an old classic...
review: I really enjoyed the first Willy Wonka as a child. As an adult, I truly liked the different 'take' on Willy Wonka that Tim Burton chose. I thought the flashbacks that Willy had concerning his childhood made the story seem more real. I not only felt sympathy for Willy, but it was interesting to note why he was so 'bizarre' with his guests...In the original, you did not know about the background of W.W. Why did he choose to be a candy maker, etc. No, it's not like the first movie and for those who want it to be, may be disappointed with this version as the movie focuses more on Willy Wonka then on Charlie and his family. Johnny Depp gives us a fresh perspective on the W.W. character albeit a much different one that the great Gene Wilder gave us in the original.

title: it was AWESOME!!
review: I thought Johnny Depp did an amazing job as Willy Wonka. his facial expressions were awesome and had the whole theater laughing. i went to the midnight showing last night and everyone was laughing and i think everyone enjoyed it. Johnny Depp seriously did a good job and i think he did an excellent job. because he made the character his own. he nailed the darkness of him, the joyfulness of him, the part that didn't care about the children. him interacting with the 5 children is would be worth seeing the movie even if it wasn't great. i loved it. he did a great job bring the guy to life. also Freddy Highmore, the boy who plays Charile was so amazing. i loved him in 'Finding Neverland' and he did disappoint me for this film either. he is a talented little actor and him and Johnny interacting with one another was great.

title: Incredible
review: One of the best Tim Burton films in my opinion and very nostalgic

title: Funnier than 1971
review: This movie is a lot more funnier than the 1971 version, especially because (Not to be racist) the Oompa Loompas were black instead of orange and they sing a lot better than Justin Bieber. It was funny how Augustus fell into the chocolate river and was screaming. It was funnier when his momma was crying for help and acting like it was the end of the world. The funniest part of the movie was where Violet because fat as hell. That's what she gets for being mean and selfish! Veruca deserved what she got, too getting mauled by squirrels, of course! I wish I can shrink, the fun thing Mike Teavee can do while being tiny is befriend Arrietty Clock.

title: Very Good!
review: I'm tired of all the people saying oh, the old one was better. It wasn't. In addition, this one was far closer to the book, and the acting was far better. It made you dislike the four brats more, and Johnny Depp beat Gene Wilder easily. This one was directed better, music was better, jokes were better, just about everything was better. Although this one did add in a back-story for Willy Wonka, that was one of very few differences from book to movie. I thoroughly enjoyed the movie, and I don't see why anyone would prefer the old one. Do people simply believe it's more honorable to prefer the old to new? I just don't see the sense in it. I would suggest taking a new look at this, with non-judgmental eyes, not thinking about Gene Wilder, and just realize how good this movie is!

title: The Greatest Movie Of This Generation, and Way better than the original
review: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is the most original, most outrageous, creative, funny, and clever stories ever told. it was so well done. the scenery was amazing! Thanks to Tim Burton. the cast is Great, Johnny Depp is the perfect Willy Wonka, and the Nasty children are so awesome. and don't let anyone convince you that it isn't good or it ruins the original because this one is way better. it is so true to the book, unlike the original and it just beats the original in every way and every other fantasy movie. Charlie and the chocolate factory is the perfect movie because it isn't a heartwarming story and it isn't meant to be. it is a dark comedy that is brutally entertaining. If your gonna see a movie, see this one!

title: Roald Dahl & Tim Burton = Awesomeness
review:
One of my favourite directors, Tim Burton, adapts a story that was written by one of my favourite writers, Roald Dahl. Thus, I was expecting nothing short of great. It's been ages since I last saw Mel Stuart's 'Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory' and I don't remember much but even though I disliked

Burton's more recent 'Alice in Wonderland', I thoroughly enjoyed 'Charlie and the Chocolate Factory'. The movie is best enjoyed with the family and I must say that one should have some chocolates nearby when watching it because this film induced some strong cravings. Thankg goodness there was some chocolate cake.

Tim Burton once again creates a unique world and his use of colour reminded me of 'Edward Scissorhands' where the interiors of Edward's house was dark while the neighborhood was filled with colourful houses. Here Willy Wonka's factory is full of colour but the neighborhood outside has a gloomy look. It works because it reflects the impoverished family life of Charlie that is lit with his family's optimism and it also accents the greed and hypocrisy among the rich. Burton does a delightful job in representing Dahl's story. 'Charlie and the Chocolate Factory' is full of imagination. The art direction is stunning

and the special effects department have done a first rate job. The songs were also wonderfully adapted and visualized. Even though they sound rather modern, it doesn't feel out of place. Cinematography is excellent and editing is brilliant.

Ideally a children's film, adults can enjoy it just as much, as I did with my family. In a way 'Charlie and the Chocolate Factory' awakens the child inside us and gives the viewer an opportunity to walk down memory lane. August has written a splendid screenplay. There are plenty of laugh out loud moments and not a single boring sequence. The suspense is very well maintained.

And the acting: Johnny Depp is remarkable as the quirky, somewhat childlike, Willy Wonka. His interpretation is quite different from that of Gene Wilder and while Wilder's Wonka was more suitable for Stuart's film, Depp's wacky Wonka is the requirement of Burton's adaptation. The supporting cast that includes Christopher Lee, Helena Bonham Carter, Noah Taylor, David Kelly, Deep Roy and Missi Pyle are great. Freddie Highmore does an adequate job. The kids who play the hateful contestants do a fine job in irritating the viewer (which is intentional of course).

'Charlie and the Chocolate Factory' is among the director's exceptional works. Tim Burton has spoken to the child inside us. I'd recommend everyone to watch it with their family and celebrate the kid inside while having some chocolate.

title: Scrumptious
review: Burton and Dahl are one of those natural matches which are destined to work - as he's proved before. It's not simply unfair to compare this to the Gene Wilder film, it's pointless, since it's making no attempt to be like it. Criticism of this film I think has largely been by those who've seen the other film but not read the book. Had there been no previous filming of it, this would have been immediately proclaimed as the masterpiece that it is. So for those of us who love the sharpness of Dahl's book but are less keen on Wilder's manic Wonka, this is a dream come true. As you'd expect from Burton, it's visually stunning and Willy and Charlie both have the look of the original line drawings from the book. The songs use Dahl's own lyrics - albeit in a marvelous variety of genres - and the script is great. Best of all, where the gentle moments might lean towards schmaltz, Burton's sinister touch keeps the saccharine at bay. Depp is a wonderful, paranoid, androgynous recluse - part Howard Hughes, part Edward scissorhands - and he's delightfully unpleasant to the vile, vile children. In short, this film is just like chocolate should be - bittersweet and dark, no artificial sweeteners and beautifully presented. Oh and beware of the squirrels.....

title: Wow!!
review:
From the moment I saw the names Tim Burton, Johnny Depp and Danny Elfman all accredited to the same film, I knew it would be a fantastic movie..............I was not disappointed. When you combine the pure genius of Burtons visuals, with Depps acting and Elfmans musical genius, it is impossible not to create a magical, enchanting and thoroughly memorable film.

Burton and Depp have worked together a few times now (Edward Sissor Hands, Ed Wood and Sleepy Hollow), this is their fourth film together, and they just keep getting better (The Corpse Bride came after the film I am discussing). This film is much truer to Roald Dahl's classic book than the original, resulting in a darker film, even slightly disturbing in places, but it is all part of the fun. Burton and Dahl are so alike in their eccentricities and quite warped imaginations, that Burton is the obvious choice to direct the film. The visuals are stunning and will leave you wanting more. Wonka, at times, appears a little twisted, yet somehow he is likable and you end up caring about the two main characters; Charlie and Wonka. This is mainly due to Johnny Depps original and touching portrayal of Wonka. Depp has worked with Freddie Highmore (Charlie) before, in Finding Netherland. These two actors have amazing chemistry, and the bond that slowly forms between them throughout the film is utterly believable.

I saw this film on the big screen, then bought it asap on DVD, I can not get enough of it. If you want your senses stimulated then this is the film for you, it has fabulous music, amazing visuals and you can almost taste the chocolate. This is a film for all the family, the children will love the fairly simple plot and breathtaking scenery, but the grown ups will relish the innuendo's and intelligent but subtle adult humour. I implore all those with any imagination to speak of to watch this film, you will not be disappointed.

title: Nothing Could Possibly Be Sweeter.
review:
I was just amazed when I saw this movie in theaters. This movie was truly something spectacular to me. It just blew me away to see how well Johnny Depp acted as Willy Wonka. His costume, his voice, and facial expressions were what totally made the character. I was practically laughing every minute. This movie is about 100% better than the original. I loved all the rooms, especially the Inventing Room which is one of my favorites and I loved the new Oompa-Loompa songs. Those songs just cracked me up. It was like a miracle how all those squirrels were real and they trained them so well for the movie. I always laugh when the squirrels knock on Veruca's forehead to test to see if she's a bad nut. I laugh at the parts when something bad happens to all the rotten children.

I love the way that Willy Wonka reacts to every situation. He seems to say all the right words for the movie. Johnny Depp and Tim Burton just blew me away. The performance of the characters were awesome and totally matched the characters. This is more accurate to the classic children's book written by Roald Dahl.

If you are a big fan of Johnny Depp, Tim Burton, Freddie Highmore, or all three then this is a definitely a must see!!!

title: Entertaining, mesmerizing and lingering - in a fabulous way
review:
The brand-new "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" is nothing like the 1971 version starring Gene Wilder. If you're a fan of the 1971 version, you will either be awe inspired and hate Johnny Depp for doing better than Gene Wilder, or you will be horrified by the fact that you could like the 1971 version when the new one is so much better. (I don't mean to be judgmental, but this is most likely how you will feel about it) The first sign that this would be a good movie came simply from the name: "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory". Ahhhhhhh. What a relief to those of us who love the book and love it's name. The version from 1971 is known as "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory" - this should give you a few hints as to what it's like.

Now that I am done complaining about the first version of Roald Dahl's classic film, I can go on to praise the new one. First off, major props to Tim Burton for creating such a mesmerizing and lingering yet entertaining film. This movie has so many layers and therefore, such a broad audience. If you want something light and carefree, go ahead and see "Charlie". You can just scrape the surface and enjoy the comedic side of the film. But if you want something a bit deeper (but not overly dark), see it as well and dive on in to the mind of Willy Wonka - candy maker extraordinaire. The frequent flashbacks to Wonka's painful childhood are not featured in Roald Dahl's story, but they are very good all the same. Without them, this movie would be a mere shadow of what it is context wise.

Enter the astounding character created by Johnny Depp. Can you say Oscar nomination? He is both wonderfully funny and painfully sad, all in a moment's glimpse. You find yourself loving him and then hating him for being so utterly blind as to what is right inside of him. Nice job to Freddie Highmore, too. Of course, Johnny carries the movie but Freddie doesn't do so bad himself.

No matter who you are or what you want from a movie, "Charlie and the Chocolate" factory is the movie for you. You will leave the theater knowing you saw something amazing. It is mesmerizing and beautiful and will linger with you for days to come. This is guaranteed to become a classic in its own right.

title: Brilliantly done!
review: Perhaps it was that I thought Johnny Depp would spoil this thing and thus had low expectations, but this thing was AWESOME!! I love that this movie was not made after "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory" but after the original book "The Glass Elevator" and thus does not follow it but is authentic. What a commentary on society! What a thought-provoking piece! What brilliantly concocted cinematography. I loved the Oompa Loompas! I loved the ending. The way this story was told made sense. Depp did a fabulous job in this, as did everyone else. The way it starts--"Charlie Bucket was the luckiest boy in the whole world, he just didn't know it yet"--reminds me of Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet which starts with a spoiler. I cannot tell you just how pleased I am!! It's wonderful film for kids, although I think one of its aims is to get those "grown-ups" in the audience to remember and actually feel what it's like to be young.

title: Sweet and Sour
review:
Sure, the remake already tells you "bad", but actually take the time to see this movie, just! Even if you're not a Johnny Depp fan, or you're not the type to sit and watch a marathon of Tim Burton movies, sit down and take the hours to watch this remake of the 1971 version.

We all know what goes on, but for those of you who have never read the book or even saw the original, here's a quick summary. Eccentric chocolate factory owner Willy Wonka holds a contest which he has placed 5 golden tickets in a special candy bar called a Wonka Bar (that's 1 golden ticket in only 5 bars). They can be all over the world, and in this case, if you win one, you get the chance to tour the factory with Wonka himself.

But, its centered around a young boy named Charlie Bucket (Freddie Highmore). Bucket's family is poor. He lives with his grandparents (from both of his parents), and his father works at a toothpaste factory, but he doesn't have such a good job, as he's the one who screws the caps on the toothpaste, and obviously, the person who screws the caps doesn't make much money. So Charlie lives in a "shack".

As you already may have guessed, Bucket gets a Golden Ticket (by luck of the draw by buying a Wonka Bar), and gets into the factory, as well as 4 others, and blah blah blah blah. You know the rest.

The entertainment for this film is one of the best for a remake. You laugh, you cry, you'll be frightened, you'll get grossed out, freaked out, every little thing is in there. Johnny Depp is terrific as the eccentric Wonka, who nails down the role of a mysterious man the way Burton would have wanted it, in any other way. Despite having damaged the funny and quirky dance numbers done by the Oompa Loompa's, they aren't all damaged, and are redone in a way to try and repair the damage, but it's already done.

The factory itself is as enchanting as it can get, and all roads (sweet ones) lead to happiness, which isn't always the case, as Wonka adds more than we thought. He has a disgruntled relationship with his father, and he has bad communicating skills (quite evidently present), which raises the stakes a bit more, and adds more flavor in the movie than the original ever would have done. Terrificly added by Burton.

A spoon of flavor, a Cup of taste, a Tablespoon of joy, and a stick of wit, and that's the recipe for the new version of the remake. ENJOY!

title: I haven't seen the original. As it is, though... this movie is *awesome*
review:
Just like "Big Fish" before it... "Charlie" is so warm, sweet, and enjoyable, I do believe Tim Burton is my favorite movie director ever.

The lessons to be learned in this charming story are many, and the story is simply fun. Johnny Depp is creepier than Michael Jackson at times (his acting is fantastic). Luckily, he can be left alone with kids without lawsuits flying all over the place. The kids are perfect stereotypes for the Oompa-Loompas to trick. The scenery and stages are perfect - full of colour everywhere, yet as dark as any Tim Burton movie out there. The whole movie is a bit dark, although in a cheery kind of way. It seems as if the main characters have a ray of sunshine guiding their actions all the time, so even if you sense the desperation in Charlie's parents, and the sadness of Willy Wonka, somehow you know everything will turn out all right.

Even if it's a bit slow during the first part, this has to be one of my favourite movies of the year.

title: Bitter Chocolate
review: Looks like I'm a lone voice in the wilderness here but those are the breaks. If I want to see a fantasy involving a boy named Charlie I'll stick to Cedric Kahn's charming 'L'Avion' made for probably a 20th of Burton's budget and barely a special effect in sight. I've never been much of a Burton fan - unless we're talking Richard - though I appreciate and accept that each generation needs an eccentric/rebellious/avant garde call it what you will figure and Burton seems to be this season's Godard. Okay, I don't have to go to his movies if I don't want to and mostly I don't want to but this time I read all the hype and thought well, why not, he has to make a half-decent movie SOME time so maybe this is it. Alas! I'm not much of a Depp fan either so I had a lot of prejudice to overcome but I gave it the old college try only to find myself falling asleep. I haven't seen the original Gene Wilder version so I have nothing to use for comparison but I found it screamingly obvious from the initial shot of chez Bucket, a blatant 'steal' from the National Theatre production of 'An Inspector Calls' to the 'cute' homilies 'my family is more important to me than anything' and only WE the audience can see these Addams Family first-drafts as the grotesques they are. I guess I saw it on an off day: My seat was facing the screen.

title: MINOR Spoiler - more a reassurance for book lovers
review:
In 1970, I was given a copy of Roald Dahl's book "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory". It was instantly my favorite book, only supplanted by "The Hobbit" in 1972.

I am a great re-reader of books. The Hobbit for instance holds the record  40 times. Other favorites such as Orwell's "1984" have been read 10+ times.

"Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" was a book that I read and reread at least a dozen times in two years. I was enthralled, not only because of the story, but the writing itself. Mr. Dahl doesn't treat his readers like 'children'. The story could be downright grim in sections, but always  ALWAYS rung true.

Thus, when my mother told me they were making a movie, I was excited. I was out of my mind the week before opening.

Then I saw it.

On the way out my mom asked me, "What's the matter? Didn't you like it?".

"It was okay, I guess, but it WASN'T the book!" I replied  completely, irrevocably disappointed at what unfortunately proved thru the years to be a Hollywood pattern  butchering books.

The movie was the story at a shallow level, but bastardized and worse still dumbed down, with all the edginess sugarcoated away.

Gene Wilder is NOT Willy Wonka. Great performance, but NOT the Willy Wonka of the book.

And so thru the decades I ignored the movie. Yes, I have watched it a few times since, but always seeing what SHOULD have been and always disappointed in the end.

I was very excited when I heard that Tim Burton was directing  "PERFECT DIRECTOR for the material" I though to myself.

I was horrified by the asinine rumors that Marylin Manson would be cast as Wonka. Luckily they proved to be just that "asinine rumors".

Johnny Depp  there's an actor I trust!

Then came the controversy  the so-called purists railing against remaking a classic!!! I considered- no, HOPED  it was Hollywood making it up to us book fans  the REAL Charlie fans after all these years.

Assurances from Burtin that he would be faithful to the book  gave me hope.

And so with quite a bit of anxiety, Lil Hob, Mrs. Hob and I ventured to the cinema this weekend.

And.in the immortal words of Grandpa Joe

"YIPPPEEEEEEEEEE"

They did it!!! They REALLY did it!!! They made my book into a movie and kept the spirit of the book alive!!!!!

Depp's Wonka is not perfect  I doubt anyone could be  but I will say that he is far FAR truer to the character than I could have hoped and certainly superior to Wilder's "Wonka-be" version.

This time they created the OompaLoompas RIGHT!!!

This time Burton created a cinematic version of the book that made me tear up with joy  the little boy inside elated that someone in Hollywood understood the material  at last!!!

Okay  they DID add some stuff to it  specifically, the Wonka backstory. But it was in the SPIRIT of the story and I think Dahl might have approved were he alive to see it. (I hear he also HATED the original butchering).

The book  the whole book  INCLUDING the Oompa Loompa songs are here.

This one is spoiler free, because those who love the book know what I am talking about. And those who don't  well you probably only know the original sin and may even love it. If so  forget about seeing this  because this version is the REAL version and is vastly different from the 1972 atrocity.

Instead of seeing this version, read the book FIRST, then see it.

I am so happy that Lil Hob is oblivious that there is any other version than this one.

Mrs' Hob never read the book and while she liked this  she couldn't get over the fact that it was GRIM in places and not as insipidly "sweet" as the first.

ONE SPOILER 

Tim Burton made a CHOCOLATE RIVER THAT ACTUALLY LOOKS LIKE A CHOCOLATE RIVER!!! Unlike that diarrhea-like abomination in the '72 film.

title: Burton surpasses all my hopes and dreams
review:
Willy Wonka: Everything here is eatable. I'm eatable, but that my children is called cannibalism and it is frowned upon in most societies.

OK Charlie and the chocolate factory This was my most anticipated movie of 2005 so excuse me if i sound a little bias....OK johnny depp is the best choice they could've made for willy wonka....his mannerisms, movements, and voice just make the character....Willy wonka seems to be a mix of Marilyn Manson, Michael Jackson and Mr. Rodgers...all mixed into one.....unlike gene wilder.....but really.....if it came down to it.....johnny depp is my favorite willy wonka....this movie goes into detail of how willy wonka became a chocolatier....from his days as a boy to his days as a corner shop owner....this film is somewhat darker than the 1971 version.....wonka no longer sings....he does dance a little and he does smile more but when he does....it seems like he wants to take the children to bed.....but their is no more slugworth.....there is actually one mention of him but thats it.....so the kids aren't vying for the grand prize.....which isn't a lifetime supply of chocolate...(every kid gets that).....there's no mention of snausberries and in the tunnel theirs no chicken getting its head chopped off....mike teevee isn't taken by his mom and violet beugarde isn't taken by her father....rather their dad and mother respectively....Charlie has a father in this movie which i thought was really weird....and it does show how his family makes a few dollars.....but the film used so much time showing why Willy wonka did what he did and how Charlie found the ticket that the whole chocolate factory seemed rushed and there were a few scenes missing from this version.....there is no more fizzy lifting drink there is just one mention of everlasting gobstopper......all in all this is definitely a movie worth spending the 12.50 to see it at an IMAX or the 8.00 to see it at cinemark.....so watch it and enjoy....

title: Loved It!!
review:
Saw it in IMAX this morning (a wonderfully unexpected surprise and my first-ever IMAX experience - if you can believe that! *L*) No spoilers, but being a Disneyland nut, I was in hysterics during the bit for the "Welcome Song." It's an absolute, twisted riot! I loved all of the odd '60s/'70s cultural references, and felt kinda 'privileged' in a weird way, knowing that a lot of folks probably won't 'get' them (I'm in the 45+ age group. ;-) And Johnny Depp is FABulously demented and sweet and quirky... Just they way his fans like him! Oh...

And I know I'll get blasted by a few of you for this, but this version is being referred all over (TV/Newspaper reviews, etc.) as a "remake" and it is. Fans of the first one (like me) will notice that many of the actors' lines are almost word-for-word.

Tim Burton did REAL good... His die-hard fans should be very happy. I hope to see many more of his films and hope that he and Mr. Depp will continue to work together - they are a priceless combination.

Enjoy all!

title: Charlie and the Chocolate Bomb
review: What a freakin' creepy movie! Okay, so some might think that the first one was kind of creepy. Personally, I do not think so, but I am willing to accept this idea. What I am not willing to accept is that this movie was in anyway a decent movie. All the jokes seemed to die right at the punch line. None of the points of the book are carried through to the movie. Instead, all we got was a 2 hour barage of bad jokes, creepy looks and depressing story lines. It was clearly a Tim Burton movie....dark, witless humor and feigned emotion. Willie Wonka, rather than being this insanely happy chocolate maker is only an adult with a broken childhood. Charlie did play that typical role, and I did like the change of the Mike TV's character. But the particulars of the movie were really ridiculous. So Feruka wants an ordinary animal, no golden duck (I don't consider this to be a spoiler) and gets all fussy about that? No, that can't be right. This little girl is spoiled, and she is entirely too spoiled to want something as common and vulgar as a rodent, no matter how well it can shell nuts. The oompas, while true to the characters in the book, go off on these extremely lame songs (lame even compared to the original) and the whole movie just seems to lead up to Charlie being the only one left, which wasn't the point. If anyone remembers the book or the original movie, the point was that Charlie was such a good boy in his actions that he deserved to be rewarded so. A big part of this plot line had to do mainly with the fact that Willie Wonka hired Slugworth to test the true nature of the children that were entering the factory. I won't say what they do instead but this point of the story was sorely lacking. So from now on, any remake that Hollywood does of a genuinely good classic I will recognize as being pointless, promotional crap. Seriously, movies need to stop being nothing more than mindless dribble. (Aside: How many inconsistencies did you find in the movie? I found 10 then ran out of fingers.) Its just a shame that writers get paid for this low caliber of writing when there are people that are clearly capable of doing a decent job.

title: A brilliant adaptation that will stand alongside its predecessor as a classic!
review:
From the introductory sequence in Tim Burton's Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, it is established that the film you are watching will be completely different from the Willy Wonka you know from your childhood.

The basic story is familiar: poor Charlie Bucket lives with his family in a run-down one-room shack within a stone's throw of the most mythical and mysterious chocolate factory in the world. Against the odds, Charlie wins one of five Golden Tickets to tour Willy Wonka's factory, and we join Charlie and the four other ticket winners in a whirlwind tour hosted by the eccentric candymaker Willy Wonka.

It's difficult to review this film without comparing it to the original, so I'm not even going to try. The original film is a classic; this one will be a classic, as well -- but in an entirely different way. Befitting Tim Burton, this film is much darker (and supposedly, much closer to the original book) than its predecessor. This time around, we get to go inside Willy Wonka's head on occasion; this is a good thing, as this Wonka is a social retard.

The film is well cast: of course, there's the brilliant Johnny Depp, who turns in a delightfully quirky performance as Wonka. Grandpa Joe is wonderfully played by David Kelly (probably best known for the Irish comedy Waking Ned). The four other ticket winners are nearly clones of the actors from the first film: Julia Winter is Veruca Salt, Philip Weigratz is Augustus Gloop, Jordan Fry is Mike TeaVee, and Annasophia Robb is Violet Beauregarde. Each of them plays their characters pretty much identically to the kids from the 1971 film, although this seems to be a deliberate choice by Burton. The characters are updated slightly for modern audiences, but not so much that it takes away from the classic feel of the film. The rest of the cast is rounded out with performances by the likes of Helena Bonham Carter, Noah Taylor, and Christopher Lee.

Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is stolen by two casting choices, however: Deep Roy delivers a wryly brilliant performance as the Oompa Loompas (ALL of them!), and more impressively, Freddie Highmore completely owns this film as Charlie Bucket.

Once again, Danny Elfman delivers the music for Burton. This score is rich and mesmerizing, with slight exceptions that I will note below in the spoilers section.

*** SPOILERS FOLLOW ***

Johnny Depp has a way to mine his characters and come up with source material that no other actor seems to be able to find. Depp's Wonka is a tortured genius that owes much of his eccentricity to his estranged relationship with his father (a dentist played by Christopher Lee). Unlike the maniacal command of Gene Wilder's Wonka, Depp's Wonka lacks self- confidence and social grace.

The score by Elfman is rich and inspired, but the songs are weak and unmemorable. Yes, that's right: I said "songs". Despite this movie being billed as "non-musical", the Oompa Loompa songs are still there after each child meets his or her demise. The numbers are busy and overproduced, obscuring the lyrics and the message. They accompanying visuals are also filled with modern cultural references which are sure to date this otherwise timeless film for future generations.

Charlie's dad is present in this film, as well, and he's portrayed capably by Noah Taylor. Helena Bonham Carter is merely set dressing, as are the other three grandparents.

Noticeably absent from this version of Willy Wonka is the legal document subplot, and with it the corporate espionage bribery by Slugworth (the corporate espionage element does make its way into the storyline in this version, albeit in a different manner). On the surface, this doesn't sound like much of an omission, but it does alter the payoff at the end considerably. In the first film, the fact that Charlie returned the Everlasting Gobstopper despite having lost everything due to a contract violation (and a frighteningly disturbing tongue-lashing by Wilder's Wonka) won him the factory, which we discover during a magical ride in Wonka's Great Glass Elevator. This go 'round, the payoff is different and more complicated, but ultimately just as rewarding...and it's not just the characters that get the big payoff: the audience is rewarded with a wonderful variation of a familiar classic.

One of the most memorable scenes from the original film is the introduction to the Chocolate Room, where everyone enters an incredible, edible landscape. While that scene is present in the new version, it's not nearly as magical or awe-inspiring. Instead, Burton chooses to use that scene to establish the characters of the children and their parents. Probably a wise choice, since that scene is already entrenched in popular culture from the first film.

Other negligible differences from the original film include switch-ups in gender for a couple of the kids' parents (Violet Beauregarde brings her mother along, while Mike TeaVee brings his dad) and a change in one of the rooms visited (a squirrel-filled nut sorting room replaces the goose-laden golden chocolate egg room).

*** END OF SPOILERS ***

I enjoyed this film immensely, and I consider it to be a complement to the original, rather than a replacement. Both are sure to remain classics for many years to come. Burton has created an entirely new film that preserves the magic of the first film, but also manages to create some new magic of its own.

As a side note, my five-year-old daughter had been looking forward to seeing Charlie and the Chocolate Factory for months (referring to it as "Willy Wonka 2"), and I saw it with her last night. She was not disappointed. ;)

title: If you have seen the original...don't bother
review: I think most of the comments saying how fabulous this movie is are from those who never saw the original. The original and the songs really captured the innocence of the book. This version while contemporary does miss a lot of the original subtleties of both the book and movie. I thought the original Veruka Salt was much better. Although in all fairness this Agustus, Mike Teevee and Violet are better. Actually Violet in the original was pretty good so it is a toss up. The parents in the original were all much better. Now for Depp vs. Wilder, depends on your age. I will take Wilder although Depp did do a decent job with lots of originality to a very structured character.

title: The buzz on this film totally misses the mark
review: First this film promised to be a radical interpretation of the source material. Outside of a few tweaks and twitches, like the squirrel scene which I loved (the moniker gives that much away), this is very similar to the original in many ways. I prefer the kids in this version, they're saucier and better cast but I'm not sold on Depp's Willy Wonka. He's not in the same league as Gene Wilder. Wilder's Wonka (say that three times fast) came off as smarter and his reason for being so reclusive and gradually more misanthropic were better. Sure he was warmer, I think Gene Wilder is incapable of not emanating warmth, but it makes his performance that much more striking when he does have an outburst or a callous moment. Depp's stunted development and dislike of p p p parents falls short of expectations and the opening sequence just comes off as disturbingly anti-union and paranoid. Wonka has little humanity in the remake and rather that being "eccentric" he just seems childish, simple and cold.

title: A True Cinematic Event
review:
I was greatly anticipating seeing Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, but I couldn't have imagined it being as good as it is. I figured there would be some aspect of the film that I would find rather unfavorable, but Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is a true work of art. I cannot imagine finding it to be better with any part of it altered.

It is a true film of pure imagination and vision. It's not your average movie. From Johnny Depp's and Freddie Highmore's performances, to the stunningly beautiful sets, to the outstanding soundtrack, it's brilliant. Those are my favorite aspects of the film, actually, but everything is just beautiful.

A film like this comes along once in a great while. It's a film everyone should see at least once. I would say it has something everyone can enjoy. It's semisweet, after all, just like Willy Wonka. It has a bit of a macabre edge to it.

See the film, read the book, and then see the film again and again. Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is movie magic at its finest.

title: not a remake, but a re-interpretation
review: Depp is a superb actor whom more often than not chooses roles for their unique character and not for how well it will do at the box office. Willy Wonka is one of those roles. Undoubtedly, the movie will do very well in theaters as well. Depp brings a humorous and sometimes dark side to Wonka that the character was begging for. I would like to compare Wilder to Depp but their is no comparison. Both men have played this character in such a way that Wonka comes to life. They play them very differently but splendidly, all the same. This movie is not a remake of the original, Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory. It is another interpretation by a marvelous director, Tim Burton, of the book, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory. If you have not seen this movie, I must insist that you do so at once.

title: Ehh...
review: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory... I loved the book, I loved the original. I walked into the theater optimistic, but expecting to see something that would, essentially, rape my childhood. The film opened well enough, and although I liked the first act, I was constantly anticipating the appearance of Wonka himself. When he finally showed himself, it became apparent that the film was not going to get any better with him in it. Not to say it was bad; I liked a lot of it, in fact. And although I usually like Johnny Depp in anything I've seen him in, he just didn't really deliver this time around. At times it seemed like the movie I was watching was not the movie he was acting in. At the end of the film, when he is reunited with his long-lost father, I felt a pang of relief; not for the character, but because I could finally stop watching the film that, for all intents and purposes, had ended seven minutes before.

title: Tim Burton - Strong as Ever
review:
The last Tim Burton movie I saw was that mess about monkeys, a planet, and an astronaut who needed flying lessons. Yuck. 1/10. But with this movie Mr. Burton has returned to the inventive, and singularly genius vision that is uniquely his. Wonderful.

What added to his great vision is the cast! All exceptional. There was one miss - Helena Bonham Carter* as Mrs. Bucket. I knew she didn't fit. The rest of the family seemed so warm and charming, yet Ms. Carter so harsh cold and distant. But she had a very small part and hurt the movie only slightly.

Deep Roy was wonderful - he played his part according to the direction - perfectly. Mr. Burton's decision to "clone" Mr. Roy as all of the Oompa Loompa was a great idea, and the tunes were really wonderful. (I hated the original "Wonka" movie - it was so annoying and "old.") But I really enjoyed these dance numbers performed by the "cloned" Mr. Roy.

As I have always said, to make a great movie, everything has to be great - crew cast director and production.

Here's a big kudo out to the cast - if I could Iwould throw them all a big cast party! :)

Christopher Lee .... Dr. Wonka

Johnny Depp .... Willy Wonka

-Zafoid

title: Not your father's "Chocolate Factory"
review: CHARLIE AND THE CHOCOLATE FACTORY (2005) *** Johnny Depp, Freddie Highmore, David Kelly, Helena Bonham Carter, Noah Taylor, Missi Pyle, James Fox, Deep Roy, Christopher Lee, Annasophia Robb, Julia Winter, Jordan Fry, Philip Wiegratz, Adam Godley, Franziska Troegner. Filmmaker Tim Burton's dark comic twist to the children's classic novel and the cult film "Willy Wonka and The Chocolate Factory" and Depp's gleefully misanthropic channeling of Mr. Rogers, Carol Channing and Michael Jackson make a Dynamic Duo again for the most part with Depp as a mad-as-a-hatter Wonka inviting 5 guests to his globally famous chocolate factory and Highmore (his co-star from "Finding Neverland" and proving to be a real talented find) as the titular tyke attempting to compete against four other spoiled brats. The true star is the amazing production design concocted by Alex McDowell that overwhelms the visuals and Danny Elfman's hit-and-miss re-interpretations of Roald Dahl's novel's lyrics to the fate of the guests. What is misbegotten is the additions of a familial flashback by adapter John August in 'explaining' Wonka and the hyper extended exponentialism of the creepy little Roy as the Oompa Loompas.

title: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory - Sweet and SOUR
review:
When I was growing up I watched the original Chocolate Factory everyday which led to the VCR breaking down. Fast forward 22 years and you can imagine how much I've been looking forward to this remake by the consistent Burton and excellent Depp.

I watched the 2005 version last night and I've got to admit I was very disappointed. The plot remains mostly the same and for the majority of the movie it was like visiting an old friend.

Firstly I'll give credit where credit is due. The sets where amazing and the musical scenes where excellent. There was no way Depp would be able to live up to the original performance of Gene Wilder but he doesn't try to. Depp breathes a different life into Wonka portraying him as a vulnerable idiot instead of unhinged genius that Wilder managed to capture.

To justify my 5 out of 10 there will be an element of SPOILING so if you want to ruin the movie now and be disappointed instead of going to the cinema and being disappointed then please read on.

They always do it with the remakes so why not this? The film didn't need it but they have added a whole new back story for the Oompaloompas and Wonka that does nothing more that slow the movie down and take away from the magic. Do we really need to know how and where he found these little guys? During the movie I found myself feeling more and more frustrated that some of the classic moments that made the original memorable where either missing or tampered with. Gone is the classic fall come forward roll, when we first meet Wonka, along with the memorable freaky boat trip in the tunnel. Also the Oompaloompas are all played by the same guy and aren't as mystical as they should be. Other changes are Charlie now has a father, the children are no longer given everlasting gobs toppers and Charlie and his Grandfather no longer steal a sip of the Lemonade. All of this plus more has been changed to accommodate Willy Wonkas new back-story which ultimately gives the film a completely different ending which centres around him.

Yet again credit where credit is due the kids will love it but I feel this remake is tough to swallow. Beautifully made but can't compete with nostalgia.

title: Not dark...enough.
review:
This was somewhat of a disappointment for this movie goer. I expected all the hype to at least be marginally accurate. "Darker," "Scarier," "more true to the book..."

While it was more true to the original literary work, this director walked up to the bell, but did not have the wherewithal to ring it. His Michael Jackson imitation went a long way to give you a good feeling for the true nature of the character, but it fell short of accomplishing anything in the way of demonstrating the true darkness found within Wonka's heart.

There were Oompa Loompas, yes. One. He was duplicated and layered over and over to a laughable effect. While all the other graphic effects were wonderful, their "cast" of Oompa Loompas was just disgusting.

I was disappointed.

7/10

title: Depp does delightful disdain.
review:
"Everything here is eatable. I'm eatable, but that, my children, is called cannibalism and it is frowned upon in most societies." So says Johnny Depp as Willy Wonka in the new Tim Burton film, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory. That statement is an emblem for a dark and ambivalent version of the Roald Dahl novel, Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory, and its original film version (1971) starring Gene Wilder as Wonka. Is the film funny or cynical, eccentric or malevolent? Both probably. I'm still thinking about the answer because, while Wilder certainly showed genial and grim sides of Wonka, his sides were clear and amusing. Depp is mostly grim.

Part putative pedophile Michael Jackson, shameless shock rocker Marilyn Manson, and redoubtable recluse Howard Hughes, Depp's Willy seems caught in combat with all three and no clear personality the winner. Director Burton, of course, savors the misanthropic side of Willy with nary a sympathetic character except little Charlie and his Dickensian poor but virtuous family. Depp does delightful disdain of the children, who are mostly, with the exception of Charlie, stereotypes of fat, overindulged, malicious, and fawning spoiled brats.

Burton catches the current fascination with the dark childhoods of leading characters, such as Christopher Nolan's lonely Batman. The film seems to be saved from Burton's uncertain tone by the ending, which reaffirms family life, even for Willy, who can barely utter the words family or parents through most of the film. Burton emphasizes, then, the clichéd solution to misery and poverty and avoids, in deference to the novel, what might have been a promising premise, namely that not all children are redeemable and not all families can count on love to get them through tough times.

Willy warns the visiting families not to touch the squirrels' nuts, another signal of the nutty film's ambivalent tone and point of view. I just wish Depp had portrayed Willy with a clearer understanding of the wit and wiliness of Wonka.

title: Pissed me off (2005) i like it (2018)
review: Charlie and the chocolate factory. Sttaring this time Johny deep as wonka this film pissed off a lot of fans and im not gonna lie it pissed me too. But now i kindda like it. Ironnicly the Wonka film focuses more on Charlie and the Charlie one on Wonka. I have no problem with Deeps performance like many people have but i think Charlie in this film is borring.So you can understand that i understand both sides an i think it diserves a 7.

title: This is not appropriate content for children.
review:
I watched the new Charlie in the Chocolate Factory movie last night and I came to the same conclusion of the other super heroes.

Warner Brothers was like "Let's put a main character on the screen who imitates every dangerous pattern of a child predator with everything he does and says, but create a storyline justifying it. That way children who are allowed to watch this PG movie think when they see this behavior in an adult that adult just needs their love and compassion so they can help him overcome his childhood problems."

I'm not saying it was intentional, but it was super creepy.

title: A classic, whacky and fun adventure for the whole family!
review:
This movie is a true classic. One you can watch over and over again and discover new things and never get bored! The story has good morals, the atmosphere is fun and there is good acting to top it off. Wonka is so wonderfully whacko yet likeable and all of the other characters are played well such as: Charlie, Mr & Mrs Bucket, Grandpa Joe and the parents of the feisty children. We even get a backstory of some of them such as Mr. Bucket, Willy Wonka and the Oompa Loompas and how he met them and got them to work for him in the grand Factroy.

Each of the children are played on-point and they are all memorable in their own ways.

Visually it's a wonderful treat and the catchy soundtrack by Mr. Elfman compliments everything onscreen so well.

If you're looking for a movie that the whole family can enjoy, this one is it. Don't bother with the old, inferior version. This one has much more character to and varied atmosphere that will stay with you into your adulthood. I HIGHLY recommend everyone gives this movie a watch or FIVE. :D

title: A bit too dark, needs a drop of sweetness
review:
There is a darkness and eeriness to Roald Dahl stories that makes them a perfect match for Tim Burton's style of production. Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is particularly sinister and really, this should have been a masterpiece.

However, Burton indulges himself a little too much with some strange plot alterations and dubious casting choices. I really don't enjoy Johnny Depp in this role whatsoever and that alone ruins the movie for me. He brings no charm or charisma to the character and instead is just creepy and cloying.

Honestly, this could have been great but there is already a very serviceable screen adaptation of this book that features a masterful performance by Gene Wilder. A remake needed to take advantage of improvements in editing, costumes and special effects while preserving the warmth and wonder of the original. For me, Burton fails to achieve this and the whole production just feels self-indulgent.

title: Poor depp and Burton.
review: This is such a terrible movie. I like the actor I like the director. But whoops. This sucks. Bad follow up to big fish. Also wtf was depp thinking about. Also shame on the producers.

title: Deep messages, hilarious & performances
review:
Great things about the movie: 1. Great lessons: parenting, family, and sins. 2. Amazing performance by Freddie Highmore as Charlie Bucket. 3. The production design of Wonka's chocolate factory is gorgeous. 4. The music by Danny Elfman is fantastic. 5. The costumes are colorful and lovely. 6. Johny Depp's performance as Willy Wonka is unique, although not really pleasant. Deep Roy is hilarious as Oompa Loompas. The choreography is interesting.

The visual effects are not smooth, although visually interesting. Representation is also weak, because the children and parents are white and either from Europe or America.

Debatable holes: 1. There was no explanation about how and why Wilbur's house was moved (in just 1 day). 2. Physics did not apply in the elevator. 3. It was very coincidental that Charlie lived very near the chocolate factory. Otherwise he would not be able to attend. 4. The golden ticket was only sent to Europe and America.

title: I want to have a chocolate factory
review: After watching this film, my biggest feeling is that I also want to have a chocolate factory, I think

title: Amazing imagination
review: Lucky Charlie and another meaning unlucky Willy, successful chocolate factory, unlucky Willy's childhood, be worth to thinking.

title: Amazing imagination
review: Willy, another definition of an unhappy childhood, it's unlucky, but it gives him another fortune, like imagination, successful factory proved his talent, like this character!

title: As a child? As an adult?
review: This movie can be said to be a movie that impressed me when I was a kid. I still remember the scene I watched for the first time, what a beautiful scene, and who didn't want to own a chocolate factory like that. But when I went to watch this movie again as an adult, I have to say that under the appearance of fairy tales, the movie actually has a lot of irony, and even some places have a feeling of horror. At first, the scene of the chocolate villain melting can give I was very impressed. Of course, if we just use it as a children's movie, we can not talk about what metaphors are. After all, I didn't think of so many things.

title: The Start of the Burton Slide
review:
I used to be a huge fan of Tim Burton. His eccentricities and oddball imagination made him a true visionary artist and his sense of humour was sufficiently askew to make his work not only funny but pleasingly strange and refreshingly unlike that of any other Hollywood director.
However, increasingly these days, his work is (I want to tear my tongue out for saying this) stale and samey, and the trademark Burton humour seems to have been replaced in large part by a need to show just how eccentric and weird he can be.
This trend, I think, began here, with Charlie and the Chocolate Factory.
Rather than being warm, charming and funny with just the right amount of weird darkness, which used to be the way of things when it came to Burton projects, this movie, as far as I can see, has dispensed with a lot of its predecessors' warmth and charm, instead opting to put the onus on the strange.
Depp's performance here, too extracts the intimidating aspects of the character of Willy Wonka together with any interesting traits of the character that have made him such an appealing and intriguing figure, and just kept the unsettling weirdness.
The positives here are that, in the main, the acting is pretty good; the look of the thing, as always with Burton, is lovely; and this version of Roald Dahl's novel is a lot closer to the source material than the 1971 Gene Wilder version.
In the end, as films in general go, this is probably about average, but, as Burton films go, it's below par, or rather, it was when it was released. Now I'd say it's there or thereabouts in terms of what to expect from Tim Burton, and that makes me sad.

title: The New Classic.
review: I love this film so much. Great performances from all of the cast and Johnny Depp delivers a career-best performance. It was great when it was released in 2005 and 15 years (how?) later it's still fantastic.

title: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is my number 1 all time favorite Tim Burton movie.
review: This movie is also my number 1 all time favorite Roald Dahl movie.

title: Very good
review:
A Fantástica Fábrica de Chocolate is a 2005 fantasy movie directed by Tim Burton. It is the second film adaptation of Roald Dahl's 1964 British book of the same name and starring Johnny Depp as Willy Wonka and Freddie Highmore as Charlie Bucket. The film shows boundless mined children who, because they always have everything in their hands of their parents who are abusive until they disrespect, children who have lost innocence and whose sole purpose is to pass over others, except of course Charlie, only one with any thread of innocence and humility. A part of Willy Wonka's story about his story was unconvincing to me so the third movie is in development will tell from the beginning to where it came from! So my movie score would be 7.0 (great) dropped (very good) from 8.0.

Movie seen on April 25, 2019

title: Look into the future
review:
This film is one of the most successful roles of johnny Depp. And perhaps one of the most successful works of Tim Burton.
Sorry, but for 2005 the flying Elevator IS GREAT!
Such special effects. Small people with the element of combined filming.
The plot is very interesting, sometimes fantastic. Styling is great. And with regards to "look into the future" the scenery is stunning.

title: What were they thinking?
review:
I have no idea what Depp was going for in this movie. I have heard he played Wonka as a stoned George Bush but i don't see it. He plays him like a special needs child. His charachter is just terrible, and I'm a Johnny Depp fan.
On the upside, they do make it reminiscent of its roots by using all the vibrant colors.

title: Horrible! Just because you can doesn't mean you should.
review: What was wrong with the original? Great actors! Gene Wilder nailed Willy Wonka! The children were amazing. I love Johnny Depp but he makes Willy Wonka creepy and most unlikable! There's no moral to the story at all. The original taught us something! The oompah loompahs were there to teach! Like I said just because you can remake a movie doesn't mean you should.

title: Lacklusture effort
review:
Compared to the 1971 Gene Wilder version, this one beats it on visuals. And on music, if you like dance/pop music as the oompa loompa songs. The plot is also more true to the original source than the 1971 version. However, this one is inferior to Gene Wilders in every other way.

The films biggest weaknesses is WIlly Wonka. Something about Johnny Depps performance is off from start to finish. He tries to behave in a weird, eccentric way, but unlike Gene Wilder he fails to add any charm to the character. He comes across as a rude and socially inept character. His whole performance seems forced, an amazing contrast to how natural Depp is playing Jack Sparrow. Someone else should have been cast as Willy Wonka.

Charlie is also a problem here, he's a perfect saint like character, a Gary Stu. The charlie in the 1971 version was a good kid but he wasn't perfect. That makes him easier to relate to than the charlie in this version, who would never break any rules and altruistically puts everyone else before himself. Too goody two shoes, ugh.

Veruca salts actor also comes across as forced. She's a spoilt brat but she never shouts or loses her temper, in contrast to the 1971 Veruca. This one just says everything in the same, monosyllabic tone. The other golden ticket winners come across more naturally as bad kids, as they should do.

This film has some positive aspects, it looks impressive, the chocolate room in particular looks gorgeous, the ever lasting gobstoppers actually look like gobstoppers and it uses squirrels instead of geese. Violet turning into a blueberry is pretty hilarious. Unfortunately the film doesn't have enough hilarious moments. It plays very much as a "box ticking" film, it follows the source material competently but doesn't have much pure imagination of it's own.

As someone who grew up reading Dahls books, i expected a bit more.

title: Not a bad film.
review: The visions of Dahl and Burton perfectly complement each other (please see Wes Anderson's Fantastic Mr Fox as a point of direct contrast here) and the film is therefore faithful to the book in a modern transposition (for instance the updating of Violet Beauregarde and Mike Teevee are prefect, and fully faithful to Dahl's characters). It is acerbic, funny, unsettling, with a good fondant centre, immeasurably superior to the Gene Wilde version I grew up with. However, the British accents referring to 'candy' grates massively: please choose one or the other.

title: Missing a sense of place and time and focus
review: It was hard to figure out what place in time the movie was occurring. A family of four grand parents, two parents and Charlie living in one dilapidated hovel in the middle of 21st century England? And they are white English living in terrible hardship? At the same time, modern video games exist, and a post industrial Japan also exists. What an odd mish mash that made the movie completely awkward from the get go. I could believe it if it was pre-war, war time, or post war England, but not the 21st century. The character of Willy Wonka played by Johnny Depp was another major problem. He was played (and also written) as a sociopath child - man. A kind of Peter Pan meets Michael Jackson meets eccentric foppish dandy. While this would be okay if he was a boy lost in a man's world, he is not in a man's world. He's leading a group of (mostly) wayward unruly children. It's like the blind, leading the blind. Johnny Depp's character provides no judgment or focus that the group on this adventure badly needs. Also, as everyone says, the Ooompah Loompahs are terrible. I enjoyed some of the visual production design elements. Those were fun to watch.

title: Pure imagination taken to the extremes.
review:
Who else but Johnny Depp could capture the magic of the character of Willy Wonka? Playing the character more childlike then Gene Wilder, he lacks Wilder's sarcastic asides, being more the broken little boy trying to find the list dreams of his childhood . Tim Burton's variation of the Ronald Dahl children's tale is perhaps darker and closer to the original from what I have read, but it is missing some of the innocence and fun of the 1971 musical.

The musical numbers here, with the Willy Wonka theme, are rather annoying after a while. The film is incredibly fun to look at, but the four nasty kids are ten times as obnoxious as the originals, although Veruca Salt is pretty close in brattiness. The Oompa Loompas aren't as mysterious as the original ones, and after a while, they remind me of a few of the ensemble numbers from the original movie version of "The Wiz".

This is obviously more about style than substance, and while the original had some strong moral lessons attached, this one weakly presents one perfect little kid with a feisty grandfather whose past at the Wonka factory is a nice tie between him and his local community. But, there seems to be some filler added, with Christopher Lee added as a Vincent Price cameo and a strange reference to a Buddhist temple made out of 100% milk chocolate that obviously melts in the first heat.

Helena Bonham Carter has little to work with as Charlie's mother. Freddie High more seems too perfect for Charlie, lacking the wide- eyed innocence of Peter Istrum. David Kelly is missing the old vaudeville style spark that made Jack Albertson so brilliant. Depp could charm the almond out of the Hershey's kiss and not melt the chocolate, but some of Tim Burton's work seems to be rushed without regards to the structure. Depp's hairstyle and costuming are a variation of a Bette Davis drag queen (with a Marilyn Monroe voice attached), and at other times, he appeared to be channeling Annie Lennox.

Impressive sets, odd costumes and bizarre make-up and hair styles don't mean bupkus if you ain't got a sensible script. The edible park set was gorgeous, and the boat scene on a giant gummy bear was frightening. Watching Violet turn into a giant berry was fun, as was seeing nasty Veruca being attacked by squirrels. The character of Augustus Glupp is just absolutely disgustingly presented, as is his porker of a house frau. At least in this one, the kids are glimpsed leaving the factory, but it doesn't appear that they are any the wiser. Hopefully, their parents are. It's a decent attempt to modernize the look if the classic style, but all is not creamy and milky in this chocolate bar.

title: Should not watch after original
review: OK, so the well known crew Burton/Depp/Bohnam-Carter decided to do a remake: to be more weird and technologically improved. Did they succeed? Yes. If you did not watch the original Wonka, fine. Acting is fine, scenography is fine. But, if you watched original, you spoiled the whole thing. Because the script mostly follows the original one. You know what is going to happen. They did put a "one more candy" to trick us when Charlie gets the card, but still, everything is so predictable, I don't see a good reason to watch this one if you've seen the original version. Also, I believe the whole concept of this movie is so 60-70's and that it is hard to bring it to our time, despite the effects and stuff.

title: Consistent to the book but still not as enlightening as The Gene Wilder Version.
review:
Yes exactly this is consistent to the Book Title and all but The Gene Wilder Version is/was and always still be more enlightening.Not just because it is but This version has immediately gone to a 4 DVD Set.

This version has some musical tidbits here and there of which may make it a little bit enlightening but it still it just isn't anywhere nearly as good as The Gene Wilder version of "Willy Wonka and The Chocolate Factory." One example in consistency to the book is that There are squirrels who after gnawing on Veruca find that she's a bad nut and so they then had dispensed with her.While in the Gene Wilder Movie they have Golden Geese and Veruca was a bad egg and upon standing on the Egg-dictator gets rejected for being a bad egg and so then her Father follows to catch up with her.Upon being asked a question Wonka then says that that very incinerator is only lit every other day and so they may have a good sporting chance.

Freddie Highhmore as Charlie and Johnny Depp as Willie Wonka do another great teaming like they Did in "Finding Neverland."As The boy named Peter and J.M.Barrie.Each of whom were The Inspiration for the Play of"Peter Pan."of which later got to became a book.J.M. Barrie wrote the story and The Boy Peter who he knew was possibly the inspiration for first name of the character of Peter Pan but as you'll see in this movie they each expressed that each other were more Peter Pan like than the other.

Truthfully,Stephen "Steve" G. Baer a.k.a "Ste" of Framingham,MA,USA.

title: I love this film
review:
I do love this movie. The acting is great, even the kids are all great. I love the colourful imagery, the setting.

The songs are fantastic and the dancing too. It cracks me up each time my daughter gets up to copy the oompa loompahs.

Johnny Depp, as always gave a brilliant portrayal of Willy Wonka, although a little bit creepy. But he does give lots of comedy too. Some actors have the ability to convey with their eyes, their expressions and he definitely is one. I love the way he really takes on every character he plays. He has never disappointed me.

The story line is great (Roahl Dahl at his best) and I think Tim Burton has done a magnificent job with this adaptation. I think the ending is very humble and the message it delivers to kids is a good one.

title: Likable family entertainment, yet full with major flaws with the screenplay and the acting
review: Tim Burton's weird adaption of Roald Dahl's novel is a partly hilarious movie that stars a fantastic Johnny Depp as the maverick chocolatier and Freddie Highmore as the eponymous boy who is allowed to pay a visit to the former's mysterious chocolate factory. While the funny, yet not at all musically complex musical numbers are a welcome and amusing gimmick and Depp provides all-ages-entertainment at its best, very little of this movie stays in memory. The production design and the costumes are impressive, but it's the 21st century and a creative director like Mr. Burton could've really made more out of the source material. Furthermore, most of the movie's cast is miserable and extremely overacts their parts. The bad performances are also bred by the utterly silly screenplay that may contain good laughs for pre-school kids, however, is oftentimes boring and really cheaply written. I can't help myself but think that Mr. Burton didn't even utilize half of the potential that the original story has. But besides that, it's a very enjoyable family movie that has truly humorous scenes for both kids and adults.

title: If only Roald Dahl had been alive to see this
review: If only Roald Dahl had been alive to see this. One of the greatest children's authors of all time, Roald Dahl, wrote the story of "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" in 1964. In 1971, a musical film adaptation was released with the title "Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory". Unfortunately, Roald Dahl himself hated the film, so much so that he refused to allow them to adapt his sequel. Tim Burton didn't like the original either and, as he does so well, he put his own familiar spin on it. Johnny Depp was the perfect casting choice as the lonely Willy Wonka, with similarities to his earlier character, Edward Scissorhands. I saw this film in the IMAX theater with its release in 2005 and instantly loved it. I have enjoyed it just as much every time since and I still smile when the Oompa Loompa's sing and when Willy Wonka presents to the children his chocolate room. Although I was one of the many who actually liked the original, I find this one better because with the absence of the unnecessary musical numbers, among other things, this is closer to Roald Dahl's story in tone and in content. I believe if he had been alive he would have enjoyed it, as I did, and I hope you do too.

title: Like dark chocolate, it's a personal thing.
review:
With the release of Frankenweenie in the near future, I am going to take a look at the last few Tim Burton movies to see his fall from grace. I will not be reviewing Sweeney Todd as I have not seen it yet. Let's begin with what many people consider a bad movie, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory. Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is a movie I don't understand all the hate for. The movie is slightly less inventive then the 1971 version,but that was a very tough act to follow. The good things in this movie outweigh the bad and the bad things are problems in most to all Tim Burton movies but are just more noticeable here. The story of this movie is one everyone knows. The great candy man Willy Wonka puts out five golden tickets to take a tour of his until now closed factory.
