This movie is a firework of pictures and ideas. Its finish is that of polished chrome, while it is funny for both kids and adults. Johnny Depp as Willy Wonka adds lots of humor, bizarrness and depth.

For me, one highlight was the scene which is an homage to Stanley Kubrik's "A Space Oddyssey".

One thing to add is that the movie features snow, cold and poor, which makes it also Christmas-compatible.

Don't miss it.

title: Chocolatey Good!!
review: This is a very good movie, when I got it I was so happy I wanted to watch it right away! All of the actors and actresses including the kids are very good! This movie to me is much much better than the original Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory! I wasn't disappointed at all with this movie, actually it is a lot better than I thought it would be when I first heard about it. After I watched this movie I had a major chocolate craving, this will probably happen to you too! This movie is also funny. EWverybody else in my family that saw it liked it too. You will most definitely like this movie! I would recommend this movie for any age groups.

title: I like it.
review:
Very smart story. There is something to learn form it. I like the idea about the future TV. When the boy have get inside TV tube. Also very good production. I recommend it to everyone. Even the oldest one.

The thinks I didn't like: I don't like musical, make me sleepy or nervous when the really action will start... I usually use forward button... who watch the musicals anymore?

And as I heard the story is devolved from the original old movie? So probably was easy to write it? Is it audience really like to watch new movies based on the old ones? That is the reason I did not vote here? Do I must vote for a cast, production or a screenplay?

title: I Actually Liked This Version Better(SPOILERS)
review:
SPOILERS

I actually like this version better than Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory. Don't get me wrong, I loved the original, but I just liked this a bit better. A lot of people say that this is just a remake of Willy Wonka, but this one is definitely different. This one is much more dark than Willy Wonka. I mean, yeah, sure, the boat ride in the original was much more freaky and disturbing than the boat ride in this one, but the whole back story of Willy Wonka being a son of a dentist is really freaky. Plus, the Oompa Loompa songs in this are way more like the book. In Willy Wonka they just go Oompa Loompa Boopadeedoo over and over again and it got quite annoying and weird, but the songs in this are really catchy and fun.

I sure everyone probably knows the plot, but here it is anyway. A little boy named Charlie Bucket wins a Golden Ticket to the factory of Willy Wonka. Willy Wonka makes chocolate. Despite being poor Charlie gets a Ticket, and so does four more snobby and mean children. When he goes to the factory he is amazed at what he sees. The only thing is that all the children have something happening to them. Augustus Gloop is sucked into a chocolate tube, Violet Beuraguard turns into a human blueberry, Veruca Salt is attacked by squirrels, and Mike Teavee turns into a ant-sized kid. When only Charlie is left Wonka says that he gets to have the factory, but Charlie doesn't want to leave his family. After a while, they put his small house inside the factory.

Overall, this is a much, much darker movie than Willy Wonka. It is also much, much, much more faithful to the Rhoald Dahl novel. And how could you not love this film? I mean, Johnny Depp is in it! Anyway, this is definitely a fantastic film to watch with your family. By the way, this is not a musical like the one with Gene Wilder. This is not even a musical. The oompa-loompas sing some songs, but you do not hear anybody saying that the candy man can.

9/10

Recommended Films: Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory.

title: Burton & Dahl: A marriage made in heaven
review:
I didn't exactly know what to expect going into this movie, except for the fact that it would surely feature Tim Burton's distinctive visionary directing skills and also that I knew for sure Johnny Depp wouldn't let me down (since he has never done that before). And, as to be expected, I got all that, but also a whole lot more out of this movie. Of course I knew the story already and I had seen fragments of the 1971-version with Gene Wilder when I was a very little kid. But this fantastic candy-trip into chocolate wonderland succeeded all the expectations I might have had.

I'll just keep this short and sweet, because I don't think I can add anything that hasn't been written before. Here are some things that managed to surprise me in an utmost positive way. For one thing: Danny Elfman's score. Now, calling me not a big fan of musicals would be something like the understatement of the year. But here the songs didn't annoy me at all. In fact, they were great. Elfman and Burton went all pretty nuts on this one using a lot of different musical genres. My favorite song must have been the one in the "Invention Room"-scene. The style of the song features characteristics of Blaxploitation themes, P-funk and even some of that rocky funkiness The Red Hot Chili Peppers used to have. The other songs are very different in tone, and they only come up whenever a child meets its 'demise'. So the fact that there are only 4 songs in the movie, also helped to appreciate them a little more.

Another thing that amazed me was how great the acting performances from the 5 kids were (something I wasn't too impressed with in the first HARRY POTTER-movie, for example). Especially Freddie Highmore (Charlie), Julia Winter (Veruca) and AnnaSophia Robb (Violet) were amazing. No doubt about it that a successful acting career lies ahead for those kids. Johnny Depp's portrayal of Willy Wonka was simply delicious and the whole cast for that matter was excellent. I didn't mind some of the side characters weren't fully drawn out, because to me this movie is about the 5 kids and Willy Wonka (& his Factory). I also liked the side-plot about Wonka's childhood and the relationship with his father (portrayed by Christopher Lee). It sort of drew the whole movie a bit more open and made Johnny Depp's character more human (because all the scenes inside the Factory made him extremely surreal, which I liked of course, but still...). The things writer John August & Tim Burton added to the screenplay seemed to stay really true to the spirit of Roald Dahl's original story. Dark & twisted, yet friendly & humorous.

And then, of course, the set-design & set-pieces were amazing. It simply is every director's dream to work with a crew that talented. CGI was put to good use (sometimes you couldn't even tell what was there on the set and what was created with the computer). The "Squirrel"-scene was highly memorable (using real trained squirrels, puppetry & CGI, which all blended together fabulously). And the ending was satisfying too. A little detail I liked was the way some kids came out of (or survived) the Factory at the end. It reminds you once again that this is a Tim Burton-movie and not a Disney-flick. I was contemplating giving this movie 9/10 (I don't even know why really, since nothing in the movie annoyed me, and it seemed completely flawless to me), but then I saw the second DVD with the extras (it contains a little documentary about the life of Roald Dahl, some very interesting 'making of'-features and some funny & silly games you can play with your remote control). And because of all that, I generously donate that extra point that will make this movie a Burton-masterpiece.

title: Mildly amusing at times
review: There were some good lessons for children included in the movie. These lessons were not just hinted at, but negative consequences were shown and even commented on during the movie; I enjoyed those. The 2005 C&CF is its own movie as it should be. I wasn't looking for a duplicate with only updated special effects. I didn't like how the Oompa songs were difficult to understand at times and were not funny, memorable ones and were poorly done. Set to rock/metal music? Are you kiddding? (OK OK I'll compare it to the original: ~"like the Oompa-doompas doopity do", the original movie had those songs you would find yourself singing long after the movie). I checked the "spoiler" box because I also want to say Willy Wonka was not really funny or simply quirky, but was rather creepy. And he's ~35yo and searching for a replacement (for retirement)? I doubt I will watch it again, **I was rather disappointed**. I would love to watch the Original again.

title: Excellent!
review:
This film is very good for both children and adults, Johnny Depp is excellent and you want to watch his performance over and over again, Deep Roy will also gain many fans after his performance as all Oompa Loompa's.

The film follows the book very closely and some of it even word for word, there are subtle difference but in my opinion only for the better and the inclusion of Willy Wonka's dad is not in the book version at all. The only irritating part is the Americanisation of the story, always referring to chocolate as 'candy' is one example that makes you want to scream! On the whole the story has been modernised with regards to the awful children who come a cropper and thankfully that element was not toned down.

title: Great, but a little too wacky
review: OK,bottom line a great movie. The effects were great, and in perfect condition. The actors were decent, but Johnny Depp and Freddy higmore were definitely the best. The props...the best I had ever seen. But heres the problem I had with the movie, it was almost totally different than the original characters and movie. The characters were all spin-offs of the originals, but they were all totally different. The story line was pretty much almost totally different too. The oompa loompas looked the same, there was no originality. Another thing that was argued with me was Willy Wonka. He was bouncy off the walls happy and wacky, he sounded gay! He was a little too peppy for me. The movie though was hilarious.

title: Another goof
review: It seems to me that nobody noticed an oddity about the Iraqi flag displayed in the flag room. It is established in the movie that 20 years ago, when Grandpa worked for Wonka, Wonka was already an adult (played by Johnny Depp). In the flag room scene, however, we see Wonka as a boy walking past the Iraqi flag that contains the words "Allahu akbar" between the stars. As we all know, Saddam Hussein added those words during "Desert Storm" (on 14 January 1991, to be precise), which was less than 20 years ago. Or is this an indication that the movie actually takes place in the future? Did I miss something? I automatically assumed that the movie's present was close to our present...

title: A largely faithful sweet treat
review:
Having read the book, and seen the film starring Gene Wilder, I was pleased with the new film, and the fact that they stayed pretty close to the Roald Dahl book. The pluses were the chocolate garden, the pre-story Oompa Loompa scene in their natural habitat, and the squirrel scene (far better than the golden goose in the old film). Not so good was the flash-back to Wonka's father, or the reuniting scene, which didn't appear in the book. Also I feel Tim Burton missed a trick leaving no way for the sequel film following the book.

Unlike "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory", which as I type is being televised and looks very dated (pinned at all corners to the 1970's), I feel this 2005 version will remain timeless and a classic suitable for the audience the book was intended - children of all ages. The casting was excellent, with good use of the big name stars, particularly Johnny Depp as the most excellent Willy Wonka. The dirty city scene was so fitting for Charlie and his family, and the iconic chocolate factory in the midst of it.

However, one word of caution. Before you let your younger children see the movie, I suggest they read the book first. The morals of the story will not shock when seen in all their graphic glory in the film. But even if your children don't read the book, I would commend it as a good stand-alone view just so long as you explain the somewhat real-looking nasties are not real at all.

I do admire Tim Burton's work. When your little urchin is older, do see Corpse Bride!

title: I love that!
review:
Funny and entertaining movie indeed. Dramatic screen and story was really impressive.

Johnny Depp seem to enjoy starring, actually he is quite natural as the strangest person "willy wonka" His job is always beautiful and no trace of artificiality for the interpretation.Also did in the film.

You can expect fantastic visual world.Because it's a completed Story, Musical, techniques, humor... in many view. I think child's character and theme song is also significant on the real society.

You may not take your eyes off the screen. And will buy a chocolate after seeing that,like me.

title: a great movie
review:
I have seen Willie Wonka now about 10 times. I have always loved Johnny Depp, and I think he was the best man for this part. His facial expressions said so much! He knew already who was coming on the 'tour', for they had them all on TV. The only one we didn't see interviewed was Charlie, and perhaps he wasn't since he won the day before. I thought ALL the actors were truly well picked for their roles, even the grandparents were a hoot.

I think people say this looks like Michael Jackson because of Johnny's makeup. My daughter thinks the same thing, and can't understand what I love about this movie. I thought the ump loompas were funny too and clever that they had them all the same person.

I never did see the original movie, nor read the book, but I wonder if I could ever enjoy the first make of it after seeing this version. Maybe it is because I just love Johnny Depp's acting.

title: Winner!
review: Yes! This was worth waiting! This was the film that surpassed all the bravest expectations. Mr. Depp is probably the greatest living actor in the world now, along with Al Pacino, De Niro or Julia Roberts or Jodie Foster. He is the ideal choice for a role of a real freak, like Willie Wonka is supposed to be. He plays Willie in such a cool, unbeatable way, that you only must applaud his mastery and talent. His Willie is a real freak, kind but cruel at the same time, vivid and languid, as if drunk and very sober. He is a walking enigma and he is a true King Of The Weird. The scene where he commands one of his nut squirrels to check a head of a naughty girl is merely cruel, but so funny. It is not only Depp, then, there is a very god part of Mrs. Bonham Carter, and then, all the actors are a good, brilliant choice here. And the colors! From a gray, dull scheme of Charlie's poor shabby hut to the warm, psychedelic rainbows of Willie's world! Awesome work of the crew and the film maker... Excellent work, all in all.

title: welcome back Tim!!!
review: After a few not so good movies(to be honest "the planet of the apes" and "sleepy hollow" was so far from his aptitude's as a filmmaker)this wonderful director teach us how you could done a fantastic picture without apart from your particular vision of art. Burton combines his own extravagant thoughts with an admirable Johnny Depp's work, who creates an amazing and definitive version of the Willy Wonka character by using all his sources and abilities at the serve of the movie. It's also to remark the Freddie Highmore's performance as the poor but honest and charming Charlie Bucket, he capture the attention of the audience in each scene who start. The music, again by Danny Elfman as in other Burton work's like Edward Scissor Hands or Batman, was expectacular and completes the movie and turn it in a half-musical marvelous show. All this things should made of "Charlie and the chocolate factory" a new classic for all ages, that surely continues been sweety for a long, long time

title: Johny looks like a child~
review: When I came to Colombia and met Korean friends, they suggested me to go to see this movie. they said it is based on a novel. I have never seen the original novel, but when it began to film, the movie gave me a pleasure. Tim Burton shows his comical acting and situations by using many actors and actress. The children who was chosen to go to Mr.Wonka's factory are five. They have their own characteristics; pureness, greed, instinct, none-bear, persistence. Except pure child names Charlie, others got failed their touring. Finally, Charlie got the special worker in Wonka's factory, but he chose his family first. This decision makes Wonka find his old family;his father, Mr.Wonka. In last scene, it is said that Wonka and Charlie's family lived happy ever after. In the original fantasy novel, The director adds the other moral teaching; how family is worthful. The Charlie's family who help him to be chosen the Wonka's party and Mr.Wonka who seemed he hated his son, but loved him very much show that teaching. With this new version of 'Charlie and Chocolate factory', Tim Burton made the other masterpiece of fable.

title: Family
review: The main idea at the end was really perfect. Family is the best thing in the life. The messages which was trying to give were also good. Forexample the spoilt girl whose father gives everything she wants was really in bad condition at the end, or the mumbler boy. To be good person, good family is needed. Although it is a children movie, I could find some clues about life:). Also I liked when Willy Walker had hair cut he saw one silver hair and he felt that he is old. But I feel that something was missing when I was watching the movie and I always guessed what would happen in the next scenes also I did not like the flashbacks of finding new tastes and the dentist father.

title: Keep Up To Good Work Tim!!!
review:
First off I want to say that I was very excited to see this movie. I had read the book in my youth and loved it...I still do. Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory was a horrible piece of trash. It trailed off from the book too much. I can understand perfectly why they changed the squirrels to geese, but all the other changes were ridiculous. The highlight of the movie was Gene Wilder who portrayed Wonka fantastically. The 2005 re-make is something I had been looking forward to for years.

I must say it all payed off. I remember seeing this film on opening day for a 3:00 show. The theater was jam-packed, the crowd had so much energy, my friends and I had snuck in Wonka candy bars. This was the movie that made my summer complete.

I love Tim Burton and most, if not all of his films. Charlie and the Chocolate Factory was a perfect story for him. The look and feel of the film was right. The casting was right. The Oompa Loompa songs were funny and wonderful, and last but not least Johnny Depp was amazing. He certainly brought a dark tone to the character, which the demented sense of humor that is present in the book.

Every second of the film had my eyes glued to the screen. It was like a dream come true. Tim Burton had proved himself once again to be one of the greatest directors of my time. The score and songs made it even better. The Oompa Loompa songs were actually the lyrics from the book. And Charlie actually looked like a poor and starving boy.

On top of the this cherry sundae there is on more joy...the visuals. The special effects on this film were truly amazing. I especially enjoyed Veruca's departure down the garbage chute.

If you liked the book, this movie is for you. If you enjoyed the old one, you may enjoy this one very much. If you loved the old, I'd stay away. This is more true to the book. Tim Burton has done an excellent job on sticking to the source material. Keep up to good work Tim!

title: Am I the only person who knows what Willie Wonka is supposed to be like?
review:
This version of Roald Dahl's brilliant book begins beautifully. It does a wonderful job of creating a sense of wonder and excitement about the chocolate factory and Charlie and his family are quite appealing. And like all Tim Burton films, there is a great visual sensibility.

Then Willy Wonka shows up.

There have been two film adaptations of the book, and both have radically altered the character of Willy Wonka, who in the books is an affable elderly man. In the first movie, Gene Wilder played Wonka as sinister and hostile, while Johnny Depp plays him like a children's show host who has lost his mind (or, as many people have pointed out, as Michael Jackson).

Both of these portrayals were completely off the mark. Dahl underplays Wonka, and that makes him very funny. He simply acts like nothing particularly odd is happening and genially goes on with things as a series of disasters strike. But for some reasons, film makers want a more malevolent take on the guy.

Burton compounds this by making the movie more about Wonka than about Charlie. He gives Wonka a tortured past and drags out the story's ending, giving it a fairly absurd last minute and also making Charlie the only character who is not tempted by anything during this tour, which I'm sure Dahl would have considered an unacceptable change.

Still, the movie is really good looking, the acting is generally good (even Depp, I suspect, if you aren't familiar with the book), there's a lot of clever stuff in there and the original Oompa Loompa lyrics are used, and are musically quite good. The movie moves fast and it's generally entertaining. It just happens to be a movie made by someone who has decided to replace Dahl's sensibility with his own, and while Burton has made a few great movies among a bunch of overrated ones, he is not in the same class as Dahl.

Dahl's book is so descriptive and straightforward that really, all a director needs to do is take what's there and make that movie. I hope someday someone who really understands the source material takes a shot at this.

title: Booo: Give me Gene Wilder any day!
review:
When I first heard that Depp was doing this film, I was excited. I was such a big fan of Gene Wilder, and Depp seemed like the only guy who could pull off the remake.

What a disappointment. The new one sucks out loud! Everything from Depp's freakish character to the troll like little demon, Deep Roy(oompa loompa). Oh, and Tim Burton...yuck.

Another unfortunate remake. Will someone please think of something original, and stop ruining my favourite old movies! I am seriously sick of Hollywood crapping out poorly done remakes: The Wicker Man comes to mind.

title: A Movie More for Adults than Kids
review:
I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. In fact, I like it more every time I see it. This version is truer to Dahl's book than the original movie, starting with the title. Of course, the special effects are terrific and Johnny Depp's performance is wonderful. (It disturbs me that people see similarities between Depp's Wonka and Michael Jackson - including Roger Ebert himself!)

That being said, I have to convey the opinion that, while this film can be considered a family film, I think it appeals more to adults than children. There are a lot of "hidden" jokes and innuendo that children would not understand and which may be, some perhaps would say, inappropriate for kids. It is a little more violent and certainly much darker than the 1971 film.

I would also go so far as to say that this is not a remake of the 1971 Gene Wilder film, but a different adaptation of Roald Dahl's book done brilliantly by Tim Burton, of whose films I am a great fan.

In short, a great film with brilliant performances. But I would think twice before classifying it as a "kid" movie. It's so much more!

title: Excellent Film! A MUST SEE
review: As many people are still glued to the original, i think this one has much more in common with the book. It is really funny and will keep kids glued to the screen from beginning to end. Directed by the famous, Tim Burton with an all good cast, the amazing Johnny Depp(Willy Wonka), Freddie Highmore(Charlie Bucket), AnnaSophia Robb(Violet), Julia Winter(Veruca), Jordan Fry(Mike) and much more. It is about 5 kids who find golden tickets in their candy bars and are aloud to visit Willy Wonka's chocolate factory. They go through all these rooms and on each stop something happens to one of the children. Whoever is the least bratty gets to have the chocolate factory. I will not give out the whole storyline because i do not wanna spoil it too much. It is a must see film. Great for kids and even adults!! I hope you enjoy it as much as I did!

title: What a delightful movie.
review:
Tim Burton & Johnny Depp have recreated Roald Dahl children's fantasy into an absolute delight. John Augest wrote the screen play.

Johnny Depp portrait of man-child Willy Wonka is another gem, He has yet to give a less than perfect performance.

Freddie Highmore (the lad from Finding Neverland is a fine Charlie & David Kelly is magnificent as his grandfather. Helena Bonham Carter & Noah Taylor are his parents & as usual are very good. James Fox & a very young looking 84 yr old Christopher Lee prove once again what fine actors they are, even in a smaller role.

Tim Burton's direction is is exciting as any of his other films.

Now you are all saying--look at the high praise he is giving but he only gives it an 8 rating.---there has to be something the matter.

Yes, dear readers there is; the film is about 25 minutes too long.

Seeing various versions of the same point was somewhat boring.

Now I know the film cost many millions of dollars & much of it is on the screen. I could have used less & would have raved much more.

There are a few mildly scary scenes, as typical of Mr. Burton BUT any one over 8 will not he troubled,

Rating: *** out of 4;;;; 88 points out of 100 ;;;; IMDb 8 out of 10

title: Although Johnny Depp is one of my favorites actors...
review: Johnny Depp is one of my favorites actors. I feel he can play the part of almost any character. However I did not enjoy this movie very much. In my opinion, Depp's portrayal of Wonka was quite dark. I feel this movie would have been much more enjoyable to watch with either Jim Carey or Paul Rubens playing Willy Wonka. I feel the vibrant personality and energy of either actor would have brought the role of Willy Wonka more to life. Also, the Oompla Loompa's singing and dancing routines were pretty dull as compared to the original. Am I the only one who shares these opinions or does any else feel the same way ? Please share.

title: A film with all the Chocolatey goodness, but no sticky, sickly sweetness
review:
Having looked through a number of websites and read lots of reviews on this film, I decided that the time had come for me to submit my own viewpoint. I can hardly start to sum up this film, but I shall give it my best shot: WOW! I found that many bad reviews come from the fact that it is being compared to the so called "original", as if this is a remake of the Gene Wilder version in the seventies. That's the wrong way of looking at it; it is simply a different interpretation of the same story. I have been reading Roald Dahl since I was five years old, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory was only the third book I ever read to myself, and one of my favourite things about his books is the dark, perverted, somewhat macabre sense of humour he has. His books are not "pleasant", not "sweet", not always for little kids. And yet a review I discovered just the other day rebuked the 2005 version for being too "dark", and the songs "not having the same pleasant tune". My dear friends, we forget that these are the lyrics that Roald Dahl himself wrote in the original books, and also we must remember that this is Roald Dahl we are talking about. Darkness and dark humour was the key to his books.

I always found the original too "twee" for the story they were interpreting, and it always bugged me that the Bucket family in the original were Americans, whereas Roald Dahl himself was very British. I have never come to terms with an American Bucket family, not that I have anything against Americans.

I think Johnny Depp is fantastic as Willy Wonka. He takes the character Gene Wilder portrayed and gives it a twist in the right direction. No more niceness, just creepy, dark humour, and I love that. It's straight out of a Roald Dahl novel, just as it should be. Freddie Highmore; well you gotta love Freddie. He is an amazing actor, he brings an averageness to Charlie Bucket, a sense that he is just a poor, normally, kindhearted boy like any other in the world, which really makes him believable. And the rest of the supporting cast were also fantastic, especially David Kelly as Grandpa Joe...and how can we forget Liz Smith as the dippy Grandma Georgina??

*Takes off hat in appreciation*

I really have hated the reviews where people have said "the effects are not very realistic" and someone said "too much blue screen so that the actors aren't as amazed as they should be", or words to that effect. From the programmes I have seen, I know that the whole of the chocolate room, the inventing room, the TV room, and all the other rooms that were visited were built especially for the film. That is why the effects do not look CGI at all, something that some people have interpreted as it being really bad effects. No people, it's just real life set, thats why it doesn't look computer animated. And I think the fact that the horrible children don't look at all bored is a product of great acting; if I had been there I wouldn't have been able to stop looking around and going "woah, this is so huge!". The kid actors really must have tried really hard to look as bored and as horrible as their nasty little characters must have been.

The background given to Willy Wonka **SPOILER SPOILER SPOILER** seems to be straight out of a Roald Dahl novel, and I applaud whoever thought up the idea. Tim Burton has that same dark bubbliness that Roald Dahl had in writing, and it really brings it to life. The idea that Willy Wonka's father was a dentist who hated chocolate, and Willy himself a kid with the misfortune of having a huge brace on his head is just...such an imaginative background for such an extraordinary character. And the ending reunion with his father, and the subsequent acceptance of the Bucket family into his factory, is the only really sweet bit in the movie, but not so sweet that it leaves a sickly aftertaste in your mouth.

All in all, a much more satisfying interpretation of a much loved story; NOT a remake of the 1971 version. I would recommend it to anyone because I LOVED IT! 10 stars out of 10, most definitely.

Yours...Phantom Phan (^)_ ^

title: My Charlie and the Chocolate Factory Review.
review:
Before I start this review, I want you to take every idea you have in your head about the first Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory movie and forget you ever watched it. That's right. No comparing Gene Wilder to Johnny Depp; No looking at how closely or different the movies are; No talking about this as a remade movie. It's not. Got that? Good. Now, the review.

Tim Burton's Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is at it should be-- Beautifully creative with that slightly dark undertone lying beneath it. This movie is just oozing with creative minds at work.

Now, over the course of years, it seems as though people have forgotten the purpose in which movies were made, which is to entertain. And there was not a second of C&tCF where I wasn't entertained. Did it have it's flaws? Well. Yes. All movies have flaws, but looking back, I didn't mind them very much. I walked out of the theater smiling in excitement.

First of all, this movie is breathtaking. Absolutely beautiful. In some scenes, I got chills watching it. I can honestly say this is one of the most visually pleasing Tim Burton films I've seen recently. And that's saying something. The sets are elaborate and surreal, just as I imagined it to be in the book.

Like many people, I was afraid I wouldn't like Johnny Depp's portrayal of Willy Wonka. To be honest, it wasn't what I imagined Willy Wonka to be like in the book. But I can't help but laugh every time I see Johnny Depp's goofy smile.

Willy Wonka is a recluse. He is out of touch with reality, and you can sense that. You really feel as though this character really did create all these amazing candies and invent this entire factory of fantastic inventions. He doesn't know how to deal with people, which I loved about the character. As for Willy Wonka's past Personally, I liked it. It was a nice little back-story to the mysterious person. I really just enjoyed every scene with him in it.

Do I have any complaints about the film. Well, like I said, yes. All films have minor errors. What bothered me was the fact that occasionally, I didn't feel like Charlie was the focus of the film. When thinking back on the film, Charlie was the last person I thought of. Willy Wonka out shown him on the screen. Which, technically, I guess isn't Johnny Depp's fault, nor Freddie Highmore. No, Freddie was perfect casting. Charlie was just normal, and the rest of the cast was anything but normal.

What about the other kids? Absolutely perfect. I was so pleased that each and every one of these kids got what they deserved. Mike Teavee especially sticks out in my mind, because he was a perfect portrayal of the video game-kids out there. I know kids like Mike Teavee, who think they know everything. And Violet Beauregard and her mom? Great! Not to say anything of the other horrible little children.

Oh, and Danny Elfman's music? WOW. Danny, you've done it again. The Oompa Loompa songs were perfect (I laughed so much with some of them!) and the score fit so well in every scene. Danny's a genius.

Personally, I liked the ending as well. It made me feel all cuddly inside. (Scary, huh?) So, in all, I say that I am very pleased with the film. I walked into the theater expecting to be maybe a *bit* disappointed, but it was just the opposite. I was thoroughly entertained throughout the whole film. And the more I watch this film, the more I absolutely adore it. And I'm sure children will adore it too.

Many people have criticized this movie for the mere audacity of making another movie based on Dahl's book when the first movie was a classic. But this isn't a remake. In my opinion, a remake shouldn't be about making money or updating graphics. It's about re-imagining a story, adding a new twist to it. Tim Burton had a vision to Roald Dahl's tale that he wanted the world to see, and he made a highly imaginative and entertaining film.

title: Imaginative, Charming, Creepy And Entertaining
review:
Tim Burton's remake of the 1971 version of "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory" is imaginative, sweet, sour and stylish all at the same time. The movie stays faithful to the original but still maintains it's own originality within itself. Burton just seems like the perfect director for this film. He has a fantasy imagination to make Roald Dahl's dark, humorous tale come alive. Since he's directed movies like "Beatlejuice," "Edward Scissorhands," and his animated "A Night Before Christmas." He has the talent to creep audiences out, while still make the characters colorful eccentrics. He blends creepiness with a subversive humor that is always alive with energy, and his visuals always astonish.

As the movie opens, our eyes are filled with snow covered houses and the main streets of a town with all of those old candy shops and small vintage stores. Freddie Highmore stars as Charlie who's family is poor and living in a house that has Burton's artistic vision all over it. The house is slanted on each side and looks like it could fall at any second. Charlie's family (The Buckets) are all charming eccentrics. David Kelly is wonderful as Grandpa Joe, he puts an charming, eccentric spin to the character that is very charming and sweet.

He explains to Charlie that he used to work for Wonka and he was fired when Wonka closed his factory gates "forever" because some of his employees were secretly stealing the secret recipes for all of the candies. He was no longer the original candy maker because the scam artists sold the recipes to all of the candy stores possible. After a while he re-opened his factory, but no human workers were allowed in and everyone wonders why no one comes in or out of the factory but the candy wrapped and sealed ready to be sold.

This movie is correctly titled because it's called "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" and it is mostly about Charlie. I always wondered why the original was even called Willy Wonka because it was mostly about Charlie.

This version follows the same basic storyline of Wonka deciding to allow five children and one member of their family inside his factory that get the golden ticket that could be anywhere around the country on any five selected candy bars. The story gets followed on the news around the country on T.V. and radio.

There is the same concept of the five characters. Charlie is the humble sweet kid, the girl who is a perfectionist and a compulsive competitor, the fat boy who eats countless candy bars, the spoiled rotten little girl who is indulged by her father and a kid that plays too many video games. Some particular traits of the characters have been changed to match up with the present day and the contemporary choices; though little, separates the movie from the original.

When we see Depp as Wonka, he makes some strange choices on how to play him. He looks like a woman. His hair looks he borrowed a wig from a woman, and his tone of voice and the way he carries himself is like Michael Jackson. I think Depp made the right choices and maintains the quirkiness and mysteriousness of Wonka, although sometimes he sounds too much like a woman, but for the most part he has a certain creepy likability that disarms that.

The way the factory looks inside is breathtaking. The sets are expertly done and it's eye candy: literally. Burton's artistic touch is felt all around the factory, the colors, the lighting and a look that we could have in our dreams. The movie is wondrous in it's look and creepy when the children are punished for their wrong-doings in the factory. As in the original, the children are penalized for their own misbehavior in the factory and learn their lessons for what they're doing wrong in life. Of course, there are the Oompa Loompas who have their side of the story told and that answers who's been running the factory.

It is a joy to see that this movie isn't just a complete remake, shot scene for scene and taken word from word. The screenplay by John August is very well constructed. This time we see Wonka's side of the story. There are flashbacks that show his childhood and what drove him to be this candy-loving loner, which are effective, revealing that little Wonka had daddy issues, on the account of his father was in the dentist profession.

The movie is a delight to watch, it is entertaining, sweet, stylish, funny in spots and a little creepy because just like the original we get the suspicion that Wonka is planning all of this and knows something we don't. Is it too scary for kids? I don't think so. The tone is lightened nicely by Depp's quirky performance that disarms the creepy moments into light, mild humor. Unlike the original, this movie actually has scenes of the kids leaving the factory after they've been rejected and those scenes mock the characters in the style of lightweight mockery. "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" is a nice treat of a movie. Does it live up to the original? No, but this remake is like a sweet desert that you are eagerly anticipating right after dinner. IMDb: 7. Stars: 3. Grade: B

title: A curious movie...may or may not appeal...
review:
A well-realized cleverly constructed movie. The sets are very imaginative as one would expect from Tim Burton.

The main thing this movie has going for it is that it is amusing and even funny at times, unfortunately only at times. It also tries too hard, and most of the musical numbers generally suck. The digitally cloned dwarf dancing is positively corny. Also there's something a little dark and disturbing about the Willie Wonka character that I didn't like.

The movie ends on a positive note- but still failed to move me very much. Ultimately, the rather simple message ( nice kids finish first ) comes across too conventionally and predictably.

title: A magnificent tale for children.
review: Charlie Bucket is the son of a very poor family, but he is full of hope and each day, he falls asleep with the dream of the chocolate factory near his poor house, the Willy Wonka's factory, the factory of a man full of genius. Charlie's father was a worker in this factory, but now he is unemployed since the day the factory has closed his doors and fired all his workers. Nevertheless, each day many trucks leave the factory with goods for the whole world and nobody knows how the shop is be able to produce these goods. But, on day, Willy Wonka decides to open his workshop for a visit to five children, each of them that have found a golden ticket in a chocolate tablet. Charlie is one of the winners. During the visit of the factory, the four other children that are bad ones encountered problems and Charlie remains the only one to win the final reward: the property of the chocolate factory. But for that, he might leave his family and he refuses the reward to remain with his parents and grandparents The movie is a brilliant and amusing tale, full of inventiveness and of special effects that is refreshing movie for children, but also for all adults who have preserved their childhood soul.

title: Stands on its own merit, still prefer the original
review:
I'll admit upfront that I grew up with and love the original Willie Wonka. I was prepared to dismiss this film, except for two things: Tim Burton and Johnny Depp. That combination has always resulted in interesting, if not great films. I was pleasantly surprised to find the new film entertaining, though no more faithful to the source material than the original.

Depp is fun as the off-kilter Wonka, playing him as a wonderful eccentric, much like Ed Wood. I could have done without the ridiculous unresolved father issue (shades of Spielberg!), but it was nice to see Christopher Lee. Freddie Highmore is good as Charlie, capturing the right note of honesty and wonder. The rest of the kids are fine, but don't quite compare to the original cast. Julie Dawn Cole is still the ultimate Veruca Salt. Francesca Hunt was waisted as Mrs. Salt. Her background facial expressions were wonderful, but she should have had lines. James Fox was fine, but I miss Roy Kinnear. David Kelly was fantastic. He has been a favorite of mine since I saw him in Fawlty Towers.

The convention that Deep Roy is the sole Oompa-Loompa works well and he is a great performer. However, the musical pieces just don't have the same flair as the original. Oh, they're entertaining, but they lack that magical sparkle.

Visually, the film is a treat and the advances in effects works allow it to look better than the original, but I still felt the candy room in the original was more awe-inspiring. Here, it looked too artificial. The design was good, but it seemed a bit lifeless.

On the whole, the film is very entertaining, with some nice moments. The younger generation will probably have a greater love for it than people of my generation, but there is much to love for us old fogies. It lacks the charm of the original, and the sense that the unexpected could happen at any moment. Still, it looks great and keeps your attention. The performances range from adequate to great, with no real bad turns. The inclusion of Charlie's father is nice, and the squirrels are welcome. If only Burton could have spent less time focusing on the bizarre and more on the charm of the story, it would have been so much better. Roald dahl is still a tricky author to capture on screen. Kids will love the film and adults will find much to please them, as well.

title: I don't like musicals
review:
First off, you need to know that I absolutely detest musicals, and I couldn't stand the version with Gene Wilder. However, I love Johnny Depp, so I thought I'd give this film a shot. I must say I was pleasantly surprised though Johnny's impersonation of Michael Jackson was a bit eerie.

Charlie Bucket is poor, yet at the same time he is the richest kid in the world because he has a family who loves him. Though they have no money Charlie is a happy child. His only wish is to visit the chocolate factory where his grandpa Joe used to work, but it has been closed for the public for years. The eccentric owner Willy Wonka, played by Johnny Depp, has not been seen by anyone in the town for years.

Then as if someone granted his wish, Mr. Wonka writes out a contest. Five golden tickets are hidden in the Wonka bars that are sent out all over the world. Charlie has very little hopes of finding one of the golden tickets because he only gets one bar a year - for his birthday. But low and behold, Charlie manages to get two more Wonka bars this year and actually finds the last golden ticket. He takes his grandfather to the factory where they meet Willy Wonka himself. And odd things start to happen.

A lot of effort and energy has been put into this film. It is definitely a signature Burton film, which is a good thing in my book. Johnny Depp is fantastically eccentric and eerie, his performance is up to par as per usual. He is funny, yet at the same time he manages to give you the heebie jeebies, and on the other hand he doesn't have that hysterical thing Gene Wilder had going in the previous version. In this version I felt sorry for Willy Wonka, whereas in the 1971's version he just freaked me out.

The Oompa-Loompas in this version are cute, but started to annoy me when they burst into song and dance. Plus the fact that the Oompas are all played by the same actor is kind of annoying. Miss Julia Winter does an excellent job at portraying the spoiled brat Veruca Salt, and I believe we'll hear a lot from the boy who played Charlie Bucket, Freddie Highmoore, in the future.

Would I watch it again? Perhaps. If someone held a gun to my head. I did really enjoy it, but I just don't understand the concept of musicals. Therefore I think it'd be wise for me not to try and watch it again.

title: Noooooooooo...
review: Tim Burton: great. Johnny Depp: great. Roald Dahl's book: a classic. The 1971 Gene Wilder original: great. This version: terrible. Problems: Depp's performance (embarassing), replacing the original Oompa Loompa song with a succession of ill-conceived attempts at a 'Best Original Song' OscarTM (God, no), changing the story (Charlie's 'test' of the original is dropped and replaced with an awful 'happy families' ending). There are some good points, such as the performances of Deep Roy and David Kelly, and the occasionally fabulous CGI; but in summary the film is an over-stylised, incoherent mess. If you have any fond memories of the book or the Wilder version, then don't go there.

title: Don't expect to much of Ronald Dahl's magic in this film
review: I saw the movie but it wasn't as good as the 1971 musical version with Gene Wilder. Even when this version has a lot of special effects in it. Also the 1971 version was more of a children's movie with all the songs in it and the simple special effect for those days used. Which I think is better understood by children than the heavy music tracks, fireworks and machine guns when they fly in the elevator used in this film. Also the fact that Johnny Depp tried to be funny in some parts of the movie when he wasn't at all. Also the story is a little bit twisted. In this film Willy's dad is a dentist?? I prefer the musical version especially for kids. For fans for the special effect you might like it ! But don't expect too much of Ronald Dahl's magic.

title: What was the point
review:
When I first saw that a new rendition of Willy Wonka was coming out I was somewhat hopeful for a new and improved rendition. However, I was also skeptical of how (and why) you could improve upon such a unique masterpiece as the first.

Finally, after months of slow somewhat conscious but mostly unconscious personal and psychological preparedness to subject myself to this unknown feature of Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, I sat down just last night and viewed this improved (I assume improved being that there really should be no other reason to re-make a movie unless it is going to be just as good if not better than the original) version of Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory.

OK, if you haven't seen the first one you must see it. If not, then I'm sorry, because you simply won't know what you could have had in comparison.

First off, the character of Willy Wonka was boiled down from the dynamic and eccentric character of the original Willy Wonka, played by Gene Wilder, who was convincingly the genius behind the wonderful world of the chocolate factory, into a girlish speaking imbecile. I can't say for certain how much creative license Johnny Depp had behind the lines he spoke in the movie, but for his sake, I hope he was forced to read verbatim. The lines spoken were fully transparent and lacked the dynamic cleverness of the original. It was as though whoever it was that modified the screen play was too confused (and perhaps frightened) by the intellectual jungle gym of the original movie so it had to be watered down to something that could be more appropriately understood by a five year old. This modification in the lines spoken and the overall character of Willy Wonka was a grave injustice to the original and reduced/undermined the viability of this being an improved rendition tenfold. Lastly, never did I feel I needed a background on where the Oompa Loompas came from nor did I need to know that Willy Wonka had a troubled past that he would frequently flash back on.

The Oompa Loompas were a sorry mix of computer generated Brittany Spears wanna be's. Their songs were horrid pieces of writing and composition. Their clothing was comparable to anything you would find on late night video - all flash and no show. And they lacked the riddles of the original. The songs told a story, which is far better for the viewer than riddles, right? I mean, who would want to have to think through a riddle while watching a movie? WRONG. The riddles the Oompla Loompas created in their songs in the original were part of what made the movie what it was- 3 parts Gene Wilder, 3 parts Oompa Loompas, and 10 parts awesome.

The boat ride in the original was an event that transported you to a hypnotic realm of Gene Wilder's singing and of colors, fear, and so much else. It was a memorable moment that made up a full section of the movie in and of itself. You literally felt as though you were transported during the boat ride and the range of thought, emotion, and imagination was huge. In contrast, in this new rendition it was simply a boat cruising somewhat out of control down a chocolate river - nothing more, apart from a couple of attempts towards cleverness, one being a highly confusing riddle.... hmmm, let's think about this... a cow being whipped? What could that be? In case we didn't understand it, Charlie gave us the answer with Whipped Cream. But to elaborate, Willy Wonka had to explain that whipped cream could not be whipped cream if it had not actually been whipped. Whew, thanks, I needed that - I was really confused before the explanation. The notion of a tautological argument still confuses me. NOT. Oh wait, but I get it, it is a pun, OMG - get it? .. whipped, there is more than one way to use the term. WOW!!!

Lastly, Charlie never had fallen into any mischief as had happened in the original movie. Nor had Willy Wonka played the final test on Charlie.... I suppose in our society such a dynamic act and test of character is actually manipulative and dishonest and generally unliked and should have been eliminated all together, which it was. But, Willy came to terms with his troubled past and found some closure.

Granted, of all else that was watered down, it seemed that the whole thing was enhanced computer graphics with particular attention to lighting (wow!!! all of which was truly amazing, because that was exactly what was missing from the first. NOT.) The result of all the watering down of riddles, intellectualism, characterizations, and with the lights turned down a notch with some angles other than overhead, along with some added CG, is a horrid rendition of a movie that didn't need fixing.

title: Wow! A decent Tim Burton movie
review:
Normally I liken watching a Tim Burton movie to going to the dentist, but for the first time since "Batman" i was pleasantly surprised.

The original is legendary, so it was always going to tough work for Burton , but he did a solid job. The movie isn't an exact remake and is quite different in many regards, and surprisingly often for the better. There's a solid cast who all do a solid job. Many dedicated fans of the original were horrified when they heard Johnny Depp was playing the main role of Willy Wonka, but I feel he did a good job. It was quite a different Wonka than in the original, wisely, and Depp did a good job.

I wasn't a huge fan of the second half of the original as the story really wanes, and not much was done to rectify this in this remake. This is one of the few flaws of this movie. Otherwise a decent family for the whole family.

title: Willy What
review: Willy wonka, i watched the original. That was a good movie, fun for the whole family. This one did not really follow the whole original very well. Though I heard that this one follows the original book much better. Of course the songs are the best part of the whole movie. They acailly kept the original lyrics which was nice. Though the songs were quite different, one was catchy, to me. Johnney deep had a really interesting character to play, which he did pretty well. You see this movie and see the really wacky and silly comedy. I was weird though cause all the umpa loumpas all looked exactly the same. That guy really must have been like whoa, I'm everyone lol. It turns out to be quite a decent movie, supposed to be for the kids, but I a little dark if you ask me.

title: Go Willy Wonka!
review:
I just LOVED Charlie and the Chocolate factory!!!I loved the first one.When I first saw the sneak preview on t.v. I was like,"Why is Charlie so evil?" I didn't even know there was a book out there. So I thought everything was starting all over and Charlie was giving away the factory.(I "believe" in characters so I may call Depp,Willy and Freddie,Charlie, etc.) After that, I read the book and plan to read all of Dahl's.

Anyway,let's talk about family.Even though i'm devoted to be #1 fan, I thought there should have been more of a connection between Charlie, Grandpa Joe and his parents. It's just kinda "okay here's his parents. They do this. Next!" I thought Grandma Gorgina was hilarious! "I love grapes!" Ha!Good portraying the family. They work so well and look like a family. Beautiful.

Casting was excellent.The townspeople were idiots,though.Not that it matters.All the kids and parents were perfect for the part,but the moms had WAY to much make-up on.Freddie is so pure to the part.He could've been a little more outgoing as Charlie but overall:9! It's a good thing Freddie and Johnny are best friends because it's easier to portray their subtle, slow-building friendship.Everyone on and off the screen had so much playing their parts and working together,which makes the movie much more spectacular.

I love Johnny, and he's so perfect as Willy.No one can beat him. No one can replace him.EVER,or else.Willy Wonka does NOT look ANYTHING like M.J.!He's so cute in a vaguely creepy, insecure way. He's funny,intense,dark,passionate...everything put together! "Bravo!Well done!Aren't they delightful?Aren't they charming?" "That all seemed rather rehearsed." "Like they knew what was going to happen." "Oh, poppycock!"

The film is SUCH an adventure. You never know what you're going to get.Especially with Tim,Johnny,and Danny(Elfman). They're so fascinating and so brilliant.

Flashbacks are very important to the film.The flashbacks explain that his father was "so mean" so he hates family and how the oompa loompas came in,etc. Without them, it wouldn't be a Tim Burton film.

Burton's sets are incredible!Burton wanted to keep the cast and the audience excited so it wouldn't be just one thing.He uses variety.He has passion in all of his films, and i thought this was his best, right next to "Edward Scissorhands."

Danny Elfman made the best songs for the film!I have the soundtrack, DVD, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory everything.My favorite of the soundtrack is Mike Teavee: Awesome! Very nice.

Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is fun for the WHOLE family. Everyone laughs through the whole film.There is comedy,adventure,and everything in between for all age groups to enjoy. This is a must see for everyone! You have got to see it! It rocks out loud!!! I love you Willy Wonka! Go Willy Wonka!

title: Sweet stuff
review:
Tim Burton has taken something that was good, and made it brilliant. This movie is touching, funny and dark in all the right places.

Johnny Depp played Willy Wonka as an excitable eccentric adorned with a superbly styled bob cut which made him every bit more weird. The children were all as horrid as ever (Charlie being the exception of course) and the parents of the brats were played extremely well as pushy, eager people who each want their "lovely" child to win the lifetime supply of chocolate. Deep Roy created a fresh new face for the oompa loompas and was delightful. The new oompa loompa songs are fantastic and I found myself bopping along to all of them, particularly Violet Beauregarde's song.

"Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" is branded with Tim Burton's Gothic/fantasy world feel as are most of his films. I thoroughly enjoyed this movie and it's beautiful colours, sets, music and wonderful actors. I would strongly recommend this movie to anyone who enjoys a slightly dark comedy that still has it's share of laugh out loud moments.

title: Liked better the original Wonka scoop of chocolate!
review: Oompa Loompa Loompa Di Du.. OK, I will fall short from singing the infamous catchy tune from the celebrated children's classic film "Willie Wonka and the Chocolate Factory". Unfortunately, the song was not included in the Willy Wonka remake "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory". That is not the only reason why "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" was not able to surpass its predecessor. For those of you who are not familiar of the chocolate dark side of this sweet fable, here it is: Charlie Bucket is a sweet destitute boy who gets a golden ticket in his Willy Wonka chocolate bar which enables to him to get invited to the mesmeric Willy Wonka Chocolate Factory. He takes his granddaddy along and encounters other golden ticket raffle-winning children who are definitely not a bunch of sweet vanillas. Wonka himself is an eccentric who probably had too many nuts in his ice cream as a child. Johnny Depp stars as Wonka; it is wilder than the original Gene Wilder "Wonka" performance. However, wilder does not necessarily signify better. Even though Depp was "depplicious" at times with his nifty verbose, it still did not satisfy my taste buds because of the unnecessary slapstick that was instilled in his character. Director Tim Burton does create a compelling Wonka World but he did have his "rocky road" in direction by sinking too much into Wonka's mundane childhood. Child actor Freddie Highmore was able to find neverland in his affecting performance in "Finding Neverland", but he did not exactly melt me with his inflated "Charlie Angel" effort. The rest of the cast: David Kelly as Grandpa Joe, Noah Taylor & Helena Bonham Carter as Mr. & Mrs. Bucket, and Christopher Lee as Dr. Wonka was not the supporting acting dessert I was craving for. "Charlie and The Chocolate Factory" is not exactly a "bucket" of . , but I would also not spend too much golden money to get a golden ticket to see it. *** Average

title: Disappointing adaptation of Dahl's classic
review:
As a movie per se, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is commendable, replete with the quintessential Burtonesque visual richness and imagery, as well as Danny Elfman's music. As an adaptation of the book, it was lacklustre; this is my personal opinion - others may not have minded the distortion of the original novel in the film - but I was sorely disappointed with this Burton-Elfman collaboration, which was nowhere as good as Nightmare Before Christmas, or even Corpse Bride.

The side plot of Wonka's family background is never in the original book, and adding it to the movie seems to have little relevance, apart from explaining Wonka's eccentricity and lack of self-esteem, and for greater effect in the family reunion ending of the film. It detracted from the main storyline and that reel time could've been better spent on more stunning vistas of Wonka's amazing factory.

Johnny Depp was, intentionally or not, a hideous travesty of the Wonka we all loved as kids. Willy Wonka is enigmatic, dotty, yes, but he is also intelligent and funny! He is NOT the blundering, stuttering effeminate and neurotic man in the movie. Moreover, his Oompa Loompas were hideous; I mean, ugh, those garish leather suits and oily slicked hair. They weren't lovely and funny as the book suggests - laughs from the antics of the Oompa Loompas were few and forced. I was hoping that Burton would capture the scene of happy Oompa Loompa families as depicted in the novel too. The songs were creative, but amidst the cacophony, they were barely decipherable and that's a shame. The music, whilst commendable, was pedestrian in some parts and definitely not Elfman's best (such as those in Nightmare).

These were my major bugbears, but they detracted so much from the movie that I didn't really enjoy it as much as I'd have liked to. Again, how much you enjoy this movie will depend on whether or not you have read the original classic (but you must have already, right? How can you not have read Dahl!) and how much of a purist you are.

title: Awesome
review:
My friend was the first one to see Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, and from what she had told me, it wasn't very good. But I wanted to see it for myself... and I have to admilt, at first, I thought it was the dumbest movie ever. I could've started an "I hate CATCF" club... here's a little advice for first time viewers of this movie: if you didn't like it the first time, see it again. It was so much better the second time I saw it. I never would've thought it would be my favorite movie, and now I'm completely obsessed with it.

Shortly after I saw it for the second time, I read the origianal book by Roald Dahl, and CATCF if definitely true to the book. Especially the Oompa-Loompa songs that were actually from the little poems Oompa-Loompas say in the book.

Another thing that makes this movie so great is the acting. Willy Wonka just wouldn't be Willy Wonka if it weren't Johnny Depp weren't playing him. He is absolutely perfect for the role. Some people who think Willy Wonka should be more father-like should read the book... the Willy Wonka in the Roald Dahl book is very quirky and weird as well, which is another reason this movie is so true to the book.

The music by Danny Elfman is great, and fun to sing along with. Nothing could be better.

The only thing that bothers me is the Oompa-Loompas, but you have to admit, they're just hilarious.

title: Finally a version of Charlie & the Chocolate that is true to the book!
review:
I had no doubt when I heard about Tim Burton making his own version of Charlie & the Chocolate Factory, that it would be wondrous, as well as a little on the dark side. After reading the book when I was in 4th grade and being infatuated with the story, as well as the quirky way Roald Dahl tells a story, I found myself disappointed in the first movie, "Willy Wonka & the Chocolate Factory," with Gene Wilder. It was toned down quite a bit from the book, and having also a musical made me cringe.

This new version shows not only the connection between Willy Wonka and Charlie Bucket, but also shows just how strange Willy Wonka was portrayed in the book. No one else but Johnny Depp could have done such a wonderful adaptation of the character. Let's face it, he was bottled up in that factory for 15 years living with no one else but Oompa-Loompas, and that alone would make anyone a little strange. Mr. Depp showed him as wary of adults, as well as children who would not understand his genius mind. An eccentric as he was in the book made his taste for clothes very lavish, and his being cut off from the world for so long made him think that his hairstyle was "cool!" Yet Johnny Depp was able to also portray a caring side of Willy Wonka, wanting to find an heir to take over and take care of his precious Oompa Loompas, and continue his work. And being able to find a family he could love and be loved by.

People shouldn't compare the two movies in any way. This is not a remake of the original, but a "TRUE ORIGINAL." The sets are wondrous, the casting superb, and the adaptation of the story even more fun! Thank you Johnny Depp, Tim Burton and Danny Elfman for a fun filled, quirky, ride with twists and turns that only a reader of the original book could enjoy.

title: 2005's cinematic Highlight
review: I'm so happy I decided to watch this one. Great mix of sarcastic humor and fantastic story. Well, the main Character is a little boy called Charlie Bucket. Charlie is of a very poor decent but there's one thing Charlie really likes: Wonka chocolate bars. Willy Wonka is an eccentric Chocolatier who owns the biggest chocolate factory in the entire world. One day Wonka decides to give 5 children the chance to visit his factory. Tis is one of the best Tim Burton movies. Well,I did expect a good movie but this was more than good. The acting was well done. The effects were spectacular. Great score. A must see for all ages! 8/10 Stars

title: Fascinating
review: As for someone whose memory of the book and original film are so far back as to be dust, I thoroughly enjoyed Tim Burton's creation. As a fan of his earlier work (Edward Scissorhands, Nightmare Before Christmas), I am not at all surprised at the production value and beauty of the movie. As most everyone already knows the premise, the brief outline is that rich hermit Willy Wonka decides to allow five children to visit him in his factory for one full day, with one child winning a special prize. To select the winners, he hides five golden tickets in five bars of chocolate which are sent out across the world. Each child that finds a golden ticket represents a different vice, from Violet to Augustus to Charlie, who is the only one that has a genuine heart. The acting is strong across the board, the Oompa Loompas delightful (all fx'd in multiple by Deep Roy), though the background story of Willy and his father make this otherwise children's film more adult.

title: Very good film, incomparable to the original
review:
This is the second time I've seen this movie, and I enjoyed it just as much as my first viewing. I wont say if I thought it was better or worse than the original, as it was an entirely different movie, and largely incomparable to the 1971 film. Depp was great as always, his Wonka was so crazy that it was almost scary in some parts. The supporting cast was great as well, including many Burton regulars such as Helena Bonham Carter, and Deep Roy as the bizarre new Oomp-Loompas. Christopher Lee makes a nice appearance as Wonka's dentist father. Lee never disappoints, and while his part is rather small, it is one of the highlights of the movie in my opinion. Very good movie with phenomenal effects, if you haven't seen it yet, go rent yourself a copy.

8/10

title: An enjoyable eccentric story
review:
About an enjoyable eccentric chap named Willy Wonka played wondrously by Johnny Depp. The changes made from the first Willy Wonka back in 1972 are well accepted. The oompa's seem less frightening and their riddled songs are less punishing. Err is to be human.

Unlike the God complex of Willy Wonka, Charlie and The Chocolate factory aims more for the effects of an oppressive childhood. Depp's resemblance to Michael Jackson is too coincidental for it to be a Make Up Artist's inspiration. Willy is a good guy and unconventional, living a reclusive life within a wondrous and magical Chocolate Factory. He learned the art of entrepreneurship and grew wealthy as he mentally remained a child. Oh those youthful pains that plague the soul for eternity. Like trick or treating we must learn to get over it and lean to your family who have always known your child spirit, to remind you to get over it.

Charlie is the key to freeing Wonka's inner child and stepping outside the box. Charlie is such a good Boy and he captures the heart. Home is where the heart is...

title: I had my doubts, but...
review:
Tim Burton has absolutely nailed this film. Granted, he does add a subplot that was not in the novel, but I was amazed by how closely he stuck to the book with this latest adaptation. Some big changes were made from the 1971 film, but the vast majority of them were in the book to begin with. I was particularly tickled with the inclusion of the Prince Pondicherry story.

The verdict on Depp as Wonka? It gets better with repeat viewings. The reports of his character being based on Michael Jackson simply don't ring true, as he comes across more as a children's show host with a sadistic streak.

Probably the most substantial difference between this film and 1971's Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory is the focus, which is rightfully returned to Charlie Bucket. Charlie has more depth in this film and gives you more reason to root for him. Peter Ostrum was fine in 1971, but was constrained by the limits of the script. Freddie Highmore does much better, but largely because he's given more to do. The rest of the cast is spot-on as well, and the family dynamic (largely absent from WW&TCF) gives this film an altogether different dimension.

In short, I really liked the 1971 film, and it's still difficult to choose between the two, but I have to give the edge to Charlie, largely because it hews more closely to how I imagined the book when I read it as a child.

title: My childhood has come back.
review:
Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is by far one of the best adaptations of a book I've ever seen. And who better to put together than Roald Dahl and Tim Burton? No one, really.

THough the 70's version, "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory," is regarded as a classic, it simply did not do the book any justice. My dad raised me on Roald Dahl (and Beatrix Potter), and those children's tales are timeless. The trouble is that most attempts a film versions of Dahl's work have been disappointing at best (Matilda would be a good example here). They simply don't capture the fun part of the magic that Dahl put in his books.

"Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" has corrected that history of error by being an outstanding work of genius. Tim Burton's inclusion of even the tiniest of details makes the movie shine, such as Dahl's original Oompah Loompah song lyrics (highly abridged, though still much better than that weird chant from the 70's version), and the inclusion of his "whipped cream" room (but can anyone explain the pink sheep part?). This one also captured the characters much better than the 70's version. Gene Wilder made Wonka out to be a hermit-like wizard who had no connection with children, and was as stiff and stern as a rail. Johnny Depp's portrayal of the character was much truer. Willy Wonka is supposed to be a little off his rocker, and Depp personifies that perfectly.

Yet for all this wonderful creation, Tim Burton has still managed to smudge the original story. Whether by his own devices or some obligation, the screenplay strays from the original book. It has mostly to do with Charlie helping Wanka re-awaken memories of his childhood, and his cold-hearted father (brilliantly played by Christopher Lee) that he has long suppressed. But it also made the same mistake as it's predecessor by extending the story. The books ends right as they crash through the roof of the factory, which sets up for the sequel, "Charlie and the Great Glass Elevator," an entirely ridiculous book which has our heroes mercilessly suspended in orbit around the Earth for the majority of the story. Of course, I understand why it's more logical in a film sense to find a suitable, sequel-free ending, but part of me wishes that there would be a film about Charlie and the Great Glass Elevator. The second foul-up on film's part is the actual physical appearance of Mr. Wonka. He is quite clearly described in the book as a strange little man with a goatee. Neither film version has Wonka as either short or bearded. This is easily overlooked, but still distracting if you think about it too much.

All in all, this movie is incredible, and it will remain a timeless classic for quite a long time.

title: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is a Sweet Treat For All Ages!
review: As with most trailers I see in the theater, when I see a trailer for a remake, I wonder why are they doing this. I heard good things from critics and I wanted to see Johnny Depp's new characterization of Willy Wonka. I just have to say that I loved it! Tim Burton creates not only memorable characters but also a visually amazing film. I have to say that the most memorable aspect of this film, as with many other moviegoers are going to say, is Johnny Depp's character. His Willy Wonka is eccentric, creepy, and a social misfit. Depp gives another memorable performance as with his Jack Sparrow in Pirates of the Caribbean. Tim Burton has created a great fantasy film with great performances with its cast. I'd also like to mention Danny Elfman, musical composer for this film. He created some very memorable new oompa-loompa songs for this film. Tim Burton pulls off a sweet treat for audiences who I'm sure will love this movie.

title: Definitely New and Improved
review:
When you think of the magical, the fantastic, the imaginative, one name consistently comes to mind: Tim Burton. The man has made a career out of directing fun-loving fairy tales of many sub-genres, his most famous of course being the surreal "Edward Scissorhands", which, as everyone knows, featured long time collaborator Johnny Depp. In 2005, Depp and Burton team up yet again, this time for an adaptation of the Roald Dahl children's classic "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory".

Everybody knows the story: a famous, fictional candy factory, run by mysterious and eccentric "chocolatier" Willy Wonka (Depp) and renown for producing magical confectionery, unexpectedly announces that hidden in ordinary Wonka chocolate bars are exactly five golden tickets, each of which guarantees an all day tour in the long-secluded factory. The five ticket finders are all children, all but one of which harbor some horrible characteristic; Augustus Gloop (Philip Wiegratz), the greedy, gluttonous German boy, Violet Beauregarde (AnnaSophia Robb), the aggressive and competitive gum-chewing girl, Veruca Salt (Julia Winter), the obnoxious and spoilt brat, Mike TeaVee (Jordan Fry) a television-obsessed and revoltingly sarcastic little know-it-all, and lastly Charlie Bucket (Freddie Highmore), the little English boy who lives in poverty and is the only decent ticket-holder amongst them. When all five of the children, accompanied by one parent each, actually enter the revered chocolate factory, however, the fantastical and bizarre experiences therein give them much more than they bargained for.

The original film adaptation of Dahl's book, Mel Stuart's "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory" starring Gene Wilder, has undoubtedly set a precedent by which many fans will judge and perhaps condemn Burton's version, but there's no denying that the original was an infinitely softer interpretation of the story. This remake, while having changed a few things here and there, has what one can't help but call a delightfully sinister undertone, enhanced in no small measure by Danny Elfman's exciting score, and essentially makes it a lot closer to being a traditional Roald Dahl tale than Mel Stuart's version.

The reason for this is that Dahl's style, while never varying from children's stories, would always balance somewhat on the edge of maliciousness; he was prone to premises that somehow involved slightly sadistic, even if inadvertently so, punishment of young children, such as the abusive aunts in "James and the Giant Peach", or the recollection of his school-day beatings in his autobiography "Boy". Nonetheless, his stories were never truly disturbing or horrifying, because they interspersed the darkness with its equally fantastic antithesis and always resolved happily. Luckily "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" remains true to Dahl in this regard as well; even if somewhat perturbing, there is tremendous amounts of fun to be had along the way.

The enjoyment seems to be mutual between viewers and makers; not only has Tim Burton obviously had a ball with making this colorful candy film, but Johnny Depp seems to be thoroughly enjoying himself too. Almost unrecognizable in appearance and voice, Depp's interpretation of Willy Wonka is both very different from Gene Wilder's and unlike anything he's ever done before (if drawing rather obviously on Michael Jackson). He really brings out the eccentricity in the character, accentuating his anti-social genius mentality and throwing in a missing father complex to accompany the film's B-story about Wonka's dentist papa. If for no other reason than he thought it might be fun, Depp's performance is one of the most interesting things about this tasty treat of a film.

The children, its worth noting, also give very sweet performances; Freddie Highmore, having worked with Depp previously on "Finding Neverland", captures a caring innocence that even the original didn't match, although perhaps this has something to do with the omitting of the famous "soda scene". For the other children, what impresses most is their willingness to simply be horrible; an aspect of acting that is second nature to adults but implies a professional maturity when found in actors so young, mainly because in doing so they perpetuate stereotypes at their own expense. Jordan Fry and AnnaSophia Robb, particularly, are very convincing in their respective roles (see if you can spot Robb in her many upcoming projects; the young lady looks very different without her blonde bowl-cut and blue jumpsuit).

Perhaps the idealistic wonder of "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" that was present in the 70's version is subdued by the subtle darkness that comes with Burton's vision; but all round this is still a creative, faithful and most importantly enjoyable adaptation of an iconic classic. A colorful film that brims with all-age enjoyment and truly deserves the title of rewarding, family fun.

title: Wow...
review:
Charlie and the Chocolate Factory was my favorite book as a child. I've probably read it a million times, and I still love it with all my heart. Roald Dahl is my all-time favorite author for his amazing imagination and wonderful books. When I first heard that Tim Burton (one of my favorite directors ever) was directing the newest movie version, I literally was ecstatic.
