I was surprised that people brought their children while waiting for the film to begin, yet the film proved to be true to it's PG rating. The only thing is most of the jokes are better appreciated by viewer's old enough to understand irony, the social awkwardness of Willy Wonka, the sassiness of the grandparents, etc. But I found that the kids in the theater would laugh at different outcomes of the children, and one adorable boy next to me gasped with horror and suspense when Charlie attempts to open the candy bars. Each actor did a fantastic job, from Depp to the Ompaa Loompa, played by one guy. I thought the children were cast perfectly. Freddie Highmore is incredibly precious, and notably I thought the girl who played Veruca Salt was perfect. Stylistically, it's pure Burton, and every single shot and scene is so detailed and constructed with such visual stimulation, nothing is left out. I'd see it for that purpose alone! Adding a background to Willy Wonka's life seemed risky, but in the end made the character much more endearing, less odd. Depp does a really great job at making him come to life, and what's so great about Johnny Depp as an actor is despite the fact that he's a huge star, I don't feel like I'm watching a big name actor try to be someone else. He is still able to turn himself into the entire character. I knew the movie would be entertaining, but I did not think it would be so funny. I laughed out loud at so much. The oompa loompa songs are actually quite catchy, and the oompa loompa are not as creepy as the first film. Furthermore, the music composition by Elfman is of course, genius. Overall, you can see a lot of effort was put into the film and it truly paid off. I really hope for some Oscar nominations for this one, even if it's a silly movie, everything was done beautifully.

title: amazing
review: I have been waiting for this movie since I heard about it almost a year ago. I seriously have been searching for pics.. and all this stuff on the factory for over a year. And let me tell you.. the movie was worth the wait. It is definitely in my top 3. Johnny depp does a very good job in playing the role of Willy wonka. I like how in this movie they go more into the story on how Willy wonka became. Following the books storyline was a much better decision than to try and remake Jean Wilders movie. Although I hate to say it.. I believe that Johnny Depp is a better Willy Wonka than Jean Wilder. He has more of a Dark sense to him in this movie. You can see a gleam in his eye when some things happen and he just watches in awe instead of minding the madness. I definitely think that if you are a fan of Tim Burton and or the old movie.. you should for sure check this one out. It's awesome. I went to see it on the first night I could see it.. Just when it turned the 15th at midnight.. basically that Thursday night.. I saw it. Man.. was it great. A job well done!

title: I had to many expectations for Willy Wonka
review: i'll admit that i was very excited to see the new remake of this Wonka movie, but when i finally got to view it i became bored by it. Yes the colors were beautiful and Depp was nothing short of amazing, but the movie has no flow. The flashback interrupted the movie and kind of sent it in another direction for those few minutes, when they were over it sent you back into the movie wondering where you left of. The parents of Charlie were great, they looked like if they really would be his parents. As for the oompa loompas they look like modern oompas, and they're songs were boring. I'm a BIG Tim Burton fan but i prefer Big Fish over this. I'm not saying not to watch this, because i still think people should experience this visual beauty- just don't have high expectations.

title: Amazing!
review: I never expected this to be a good movie. I love Gene Kelly, & the 1971 version of Willy Wonka, so the only reason I wanted to see it was because I love Johnny Depp's acting. I am now so sorry that I doubted his acting abilities. Everything was amazing! I and all my friends that came along laughed constantly, and hard, and were very impressed. To quote Dallin, "That is the *BEST* movie I've seen in a very long time!" I agree whole heartedly. There are many many memorable quotes, and many new ones. Even if the oompah-loompahs aren't traditional & the songs aren't quite the same, this movie is a must see! I'm going to buy it as soon as it comes on sale. Everything was original, unique, modernized, while still holding on the traditional ideas of who Willy Wonka is. And yay for the glass elevator!

title: Tim and Johnny score again!!
review: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is ten times better than Willy Wonka and the chocolate factory. Johnny depp plays a cunning and marvelous portrayal of Willy wonka. He molds to his character and plays him perfectly. It is safe to say his performance in this movie is just as good as his performance in pirates. Just another example that he is the best actor of our generation.Not to mention the child actors are equally excellent in their roles especially Freddie Highmore.Deep Roy also looks like a perfect oompa loompa. Tim Burton does an excellent job with the visuals in the movie and makes everything so realistic.This movie is surely going to be one of the biggest hits of the summer. I will definitely go to theaters and watch it again!

title: Lovers of the original, beware!
review:
When I first saw the previews for 'Charlie', I swore to never watch it. As a big fan of Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory, I couldn't get over the fact that Tim Burton, of all directors, was going to try and "remake" such a classic! However, on 'date night' my husband cast aside interesting choices such as "Fantastic Four" and "Wedding Crashers" and gave me a choice of "Charlie" and "War of the Worlds". So admittedly, I dragged my reluctant behind into the theatre.

Not being a big Tim Burton fan, I was a little worried.

Let me just say if you love the old version, DO NOT COMPARE 'WILLY' and 'CHARLIE'! They shouldn't be compared, they should both be embraced as incredible masterpieces. Roald Dahl's book is fabulous, and both movies have that flair.

That being said, it's absolutely impossible not to compare the two.

While Gene Wilder brought an eccentric and enjoyable Wonka to the screen, Depp's character spins an oddly perverted Wonka and just rubs you the wrong way. He never quite looses that vaseline-tooth smile, or that "Where the hell am I?" look in his eyes.

Charlie was horribly cast. I'm sure that after Finding Neverland, Burton felt that Depp had true stage chemistry with Freddie Highmore, but I don't think that's the case. Charlie had no soul, he just stood there, breathing through an open mouth. And just as a personal annoyance, when you find $10 in the street and spend $.25 on a candy bar, get your change. Your eating cabbage soup for dinner 7 nights a week and you are going to leave $9.75 on the counter at the newspaper stand? Ugh.

Grandpa Joe was horribly cast. He and Charlie didn't interact at all, he was just there to take up space on camera.

If you've ever seen a black and white photograph digitally "colored", you'll know what I mean when I say Augustus Gloop looked just like that. His skin was perfect and pale, his lips a luscious pink, his hair golden blonde. Way too much make up and/or digital enhancement. Why they spent so much time on Gloop, I'll never know. Veruca was acceptable as a bratty snot. Violet was acceptable as the gum chewing, competitive type - in fact her 2005 character was a lot more competitive than her 1971 counterpart which helped tremendously. Her mother had that odd, recognizable yet unplaceable look to her - until I IMDb'd her and realized I knew her from Dodgeball as Fran, the unibrowed Slavic woman. Ewww. She did nothing but make googly eyes at all the men on screen, well as googly as you can make the eyes of a psychotic crazed killer on crack. I don't know who creeped you out more - Violet's mom, Wonka or worse yet - the two of them flirting in the most deranged manner I've seen since .. since .. well, ever. Oh, and does any one really care about Mike Teavee?

Which is more expensive, paying 50 little people to paint their faces orange and dance around, or digitally multiplying the same little man thousands and millions of times? I don't care about the answer, nor do I care for the latter.

And the songs, oh Lordy Lordy the songs.

While neither movie is entirely true to the book, the films choose different parts of the book to highlight which I think is fabulous.

That being said, Dahl's Charlie is probably the only film that not even Tim Burton can ruin. I give it 7 out of 10 stars, would recommend it to anyone and will never watch it again.

title: Inferior to the original
review:
Tim Burton's Willie Wonka was a typically fantastical treatment of an old favourite. Burton did not disappoint, and the movie had that Edward Scissorhands/Batman feel to it; bright colours and new and fewer songs. The kids were cast perfectly. The grandparents were fine, and as for Charlie's parents, what's Helena Bonham Carter doing in the film? It's a vacuous role for her, and she has Tech Support as a husband which distracted me somewhat.

The movie is great, but there is one obvious flaw. In the original, spies approach all the kids before they go into the factory, and offer the kids huge amounts of money if they betray Wonka's secrets to them. In the end, Wonka turns a mistake Charlie made against him and asks Charlie to leave the factory. Charlie has to make a decision, and he returns Wonka's Everlasting Gobstopper. Because of this virtuous act of Charlie, he demonstrates that he is worthy. The spy turns out to be fake, and it is reveled that it was all part of Wonka's plan.

I thought that Burton's movie was going in that direction. His Wonka seemed a little tipsy, and I thought it was part of a plan to make the spies think he was going crazy. That would explain why he kept emphasising how the waterfall churns the chocolate; like he wanted the rotten apples to tell the spies that. But in the end, Wonka really was crazy. He has to go to therapy to understand Charlie's virtuosity. What does Charlie do to earn the factory? Apart from not abandoning his family (a virtue demonstrated by the original Charlie), nothing. He's just the last one left of the bunch. The original was a lesson in good deeds and integrity. Burton's was an opportunity to use special effects not available before, and to give Depp another nice character to play. That is a pity. Burton is capable of delivering a strong message through strange characters. Just look at Edward Scissorhands.

title: Why darken a light movie??
review: With today's technology and acceptance of many different creative directions in film art, this movie does have it's accomplishments. Trying to "remake" the fantastic Willie Wonka movie in Tim Burton style was a downer for me and my party. Many things seemed out of place --"why did he put that in there??" and many characters and elements of the original movie where duplicated in a strange sort of way that I'm sure Burton enjoyed, but...what about the rest of us. Yes, it's fashionable to say "I liked it" But deep down, I think about half of those that said they enjoyed it thoroughly, deep down had their doubts. See it. Don't buy it.

title: Could have been much better...if they didn't add Hollywood Sugar
review:
It could have been so much better...if they only left some needless stuff out. Not that it is a bad movie (I can't figure out people that gave it a 1!), but could have been so much better.

The artwork is magnificent, and the story itself is great. Tim Burton made some weird decisions (all oompa-loompas are the same actor, for example), but it is supposed to show a weird and magical universe. The dance pieces are over-the-top Hollywood-style, which I personally hate.

Comparing Jonny Depp to Gene Wilder is like choosing between different types of candy (clever me...) - each has his own favorite. Some scenes worked better in the old version, some better here.

However:

*** here come the spoilers ***

(if you can call them by that name) adding Wonka's dad just distracts and doesn't give anything. And the sugary ending about Charlie giving up the factory for his family, just to get it back after Willie Wonka learns about the importance of family, is just plain awful. You don't need to shove this upon us - they just kill the magic.

*** end of spoilers ***

bottom line:

a disappointment. big one.

title: Just genius!!!!!!!!!
review:
I've always been a fan of Roald Dahl books with Charlie and the Chocolate factory my favorite. So when I got the chance to see the movie, I took it with open arms and I loved it.

Johnny Depp playing the eccentric Willy Wonka did a terrific job giving hilarious one-liners during the movie. Sometimes he is strangely similar to Micheal Jackson, but we can all laugh this time around. Wonka was a little bit more evil and crazy than I can seem to remember of the book, thus making the movie even funnier.

And those Oompa Loompas surely were incredibly fun to watch. They were stylish. Their songs and dances were great and even hilarious and without them, the movie would be complete.

I truly enjoyed the movie and can't believe that there are people out there who say otherwise

title: A Little Nonsense Now and Then Relished By the Wisest Man
review:
There are two ways to take Charlie and the Chocolate Factory with respect to this review's title: a line sung by Gene Wilder's Wonka in the original, Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory. The first is that even though the remake is largely nonsensical (not just a little bit), it is still relishable when placed in the spectrum of all of life's gravity.

Indeed, Johnny Depp's impish characterization of Wonka plays very well to children--much better than to adults; though, I heard plenty of adults laughing at the pure slapstick of his walking into the invisible doors of the glass elevator....twice! While the visuals are quite remarkable, there is little to hold the movie together besides the storyline of the Dahl book, which honestly, I cannot easily separate from the original movie.

Yes, the same thing could be said about the original; we go from chocolate room to inventing room to golden egg room to TV room with little alacrity. The tonality of those original settings is as disparate as the settings of the remake. The difference--and it's an appreciable one--is that the masterful quality of Gene Wilder's Wonka holds it all together. Even if we feel like we're on a jarring ride in the original, Wilder's cool and collected Wonka assures the audience that it's going to be alright: even if we cannot see how. And in the end, we all are a little wiser for it.

Which brings me around to the second way of taking the subject line: the way Wilder sang about it in the original. We can relish the nonsensical parts of the original because they are juxtaposed so finely by the menacing wit of the rest of the movie. This juxtaposition simply isn't possible until the very end of the remake.

Johnny Depp's characterization of Wonka isn't bad, so much as his character is written too shallowly. This is never more apparent as when he repeats a none-too-acerbic observation of Mike Teevee's mumbling. Yes, we are led to believe that Depp's Wonka is scatterbrained--as is demonstrated when he launches into a scripted welcome of his guests after the same welcome had already been extended. But this just adds to the remake's inauthenticity, because Depp's Wonka seems acutely incapable of running a chocolate factory: something I never felt about Wilder's Wonka. The redundancy of lines via the scatterbrained characterization of Wonka felt like an intentionally lazy (or impotent) turn by the remake's writers.

There are more loose ends tied up in the remake than the original. We actually see the nasty Wonka kids leaving the factory in their altered states. We find out a little more about how Charlie's family actually makes the move into the factory. We learn how Wonka got into the chocolate business. And, we learn more about the Oompa Loompa's origins; though the surreal nature of the Oompa Loompa's identical appearance makes me almost wish I hadn't. *laughs* All in all, the remake is a little bit of tasty nonsense which I will only relish now and then: not persistently like the original.

title: Agustus Gloop digitally created?
review:
My wife suggested to me during the movie that Augustus seemed like an animated character so we were both paying very close attention to this during the show. Neither of us had heard this mentioned from anyone prior to the seeing the movie. It is very suspicious that there seems to be no other information available about this so called Philip Wiegratz. Apparently, there is also some confusion about his age and where he is from. It would be very politically correct and believable that Hollywood would create a digitized character for a child who is ridiculed to this extent. The whole thing seems very "simone-esque".

Anyone know anything?

title: A fun summer movie with enough humor to keep viewers of all ages entertained.
review:
It probably bears mentioning at the onset that this latest creation by director Tim Burton (of Edward Scissorhands and The Nightmare Before Christmas fame) is not a remake of the 1971 movie, but rather a fresh reinterpretation of children's author Roald Dahl's original book, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory.

I've only seen parts of the older movie years ago, but from what I've heard, Burton's take is somewhat darker and more bizarre. If so, it's not necessarily a bad thing; after all, Dahl was known for writing about nasty things happening to children in all his stories. That said, I enjoyed Burton's style of visual design, which made for plentiful eye-candy (no pun intended maybe) from start to finish.

The movie started off strongly with a fantastic score by Danny Elfman to accompany its title sequence. In fact, I wish we could have heard more of that one particular part of the score throughout - an energizing composition of broad orchestral instrumentation coupled with mechanical effects that so perfectly encapsulated the mystery, mayhem, and mischief of the factory.

In contrast, I wasn't terribly fond of the Oompa-Loompas' musical numbers or their costume design. Give us quirky characters dressed in their native garb from the book, please, not clones in skin-tight plastic suits!

Actors Johnny Depp and Freddy Highmore, who were last seen in Finding Neverland, team up once more to form a believable rapport on screen. Depp, true to his character acting form, is reported to have modeled his interpretation of Willy Wonka after part mad-genius inventor Howard Hughes and part shock-rocker Marilyn Manson. Highmore performed admirably, with some of his best moments in the beginning portion of the movie.

For some reason, they decided to shift the lead character focus from Highmore to Depp halfway through, loading poor Mr. Wonka with some unexpected emotional baggage. I can't decide whether I liked the change they made to the ending or not. Still, at least the movie was amusingly self-deprecating about it: "Sorry, I was having a flashback." / "Does that happen often?" / "Increasingly so, today."

While I sat for close to two hours with a grin on my face, I couldn't help but feel that something was missing or empty about it all. In part, it was because a linear storyline made the watching experience an exercise of counting up to five and then back down to one, but Burton and company are not to blame for it, as they stayed very true to Dahl's original tale. Moreso, any deviations they did make were for the purpose of attempting to add more depth to the story.

title: Good Intentions
review: I'd like to state first that I liked this movie. It just had a few minor issues. For some reason, Tim Burton has a sick fetish with Johnny Depp. He has now been cast in a leading role in one fourth of Tim Burtons films. Normally I wouldn't have a problem with that. I loved him in "Ed Wood" and thought he was perfect in "Edward Scissorhands". But he went too far this time. Johnny Depp is not what I would call a "comic" actor. His little one-liners began to annoy me about half-way through the film. I don't know if they were trying to capture the magic that Gene Wilder had in the original, but I think they failed miserably. I really have no other complaints besides that. I just wish Tim Burton would stop thinking that it is a requirement to have Johnny Depp in his movies for them to be good.

title: Decent but for a real treat noting beats the original's sweetness..
review: I respect Burton's attempt at re-shaping a classic. As re-makes go, it was alright but as a movie by itself, it lacked luster. Nothing was very memorable and Depp came off as a creepy, Micheal Jackson-like character who's weird ways in no way reflect the genius Wonka supposedly has. The Oompa Loompas (or the one guy playing all of them) were very forgettable, and made me long for the rhythmic rhyming of the 70's Loompas. The little comedy that Burton is famous for throwing into his films wasn't very apparent in Charlie and the Chocolate Factory and so dumbed down, the moments often went unnoticed. Overall, the film was basically trying to modernize an already great movie for the sake of dollars, banking on Depp's abilities, which unfortunately couldn't bring this rather boring copycat to it's full potential . Gene Wilder hopefully realizes he has nothing to worry about over his title as the one and only Willy Wonka.

title: Don't compare to the Gene Wilder version
review: Lest everyone forget, this movie is based on a book. The original movie with Gene Wilder was a creepy and devilish adaptation from the Roal Dahl version. The Golden Goose scene was never in the original book, neither was the whole "You drank the Fizzy Lifting drink, and therefore you lose!" Willy Wonka is not evil, and was never meant to be evil. I give Burton props for staying with the text. Also, the playfulness of Johnny Depp made me feel like I left Pirates of the Caribbean, not Sleepy Hollow. I am just sick and tired of everyone comparing it to the 1970s version. If they just remade that movie, it would be boring and unentertaining so back- off!

title: Reluctantly loved it!
review:
When I first heard Tim Burton was remaking this film, I thought it was a great idea. Then I started seeing the trailers with Johnny Depp, and I began to get a little disappointed. I wasn't very fond of the girlie bob haircut and high voice. I guess that was never the impression I got of Willy Wonka either from the book or from the first movie with Gene Wilder. However, the personality given to the character Willy Wonka by Johnny Depp turned out to be quite fabulous I must admit. It surely was a bit creepy, and a bit insane. Very well done I must say. I guess Depp did a great acting job based on the direction Tim Burton must have given him.

The costumes were tremendous, and Deep Roy as the Oompa Loompa was fantastic. Obviously the scenes with multiple Oompa Loompas were done with the help of CG, but it was done in such a way to almost make each individual move his own.

I can't exactly remember the plot of the original book because I read it about 30 years ago. So the plot of the movie may have been more true to the novel than the original film, I'm not sure. But both films were very similar, with regards to the character development, anyway. I also understand that the Oompa Loompa songs were from lyrics in the novel, too. There wasn't as much singing as the original film, either. Mostly just the Oompa Loompa songs. I rather thought Danny Elfman was going to either re-perform or re-write those songs, but gladly did not.

I went into the theater reluctantly, but was captivated with the drama and utterly in stitches with laughter (as were most everyone else) very early on. People were actually clapping at the end, an event I certainly did NOT witness at the end of Star Wars: Renvenge of the Sith. Definitely one to see on the big screen.

title: Will See Again!
review:
"Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" is certainly not a remake of the Gene Wilder version, but rather a reinterpretation of book by Roald Dahl. Although originally skeptical about the idea of Tim Burton directing, I am delighted to say that he did an amazing job. From the opening titles, Danny Elfman's musical score immediately pulls you into the world of Willy Wonka; Johnny Depp's performance was excellent.

The highlight of the film was its off-beat humor. Many of the jokes were geared toward an adult audience (e.g., when a child asks Mr. Wonka about the contents of the room Wonka responds, "Everything here is eatable. I'm eatable, but that my children is called cannibalism and it is frowned upon in most societies." Certainly not your typical fare for a nine-year-old.)

I highly, highly recommend it.

title: B+ to A- in viewing.
review:
This movie was a pleasant surprise. It wasn't as bad as I expected. I wasn't disappointed and actually watched this movie with excitement and pleasure. I believe it's better then the Gene Wilder version.There were some parts changed and that was a bit expected, yet startling. Also quite confusing, however it is something my friends laughed about.

I felt the acting was excellent..you would expect it as you read it in the book. It remains in point to see how it would do in the movie theater's this weekend, but I wouldn't mind seeing it again.

Quite different. Would like to see the second book adapted into a movie.

title: remakes
review: This was a great great movie, but whats with all the remakes. Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, The Longest yard, Dukes of Hazzard, The Mask of Zorro, Herbie Fully Loaded, King Kong, Fantastic Four, War of the Worlds, Bewitched, Bad News Bears and I'm sure there are a couple I forgot. Also, there are a bunch of sequels coming out/just came out like Star Wars, The Transporter 2, The Corpse Bride, Batman Begins and Duece Biggalow. Are film makers running out of ideas?? I've seen Charlie and the Chocolate Factory and Bewitched and those are great movies, and I'm sure a lot of the other new versions are good also but everyone already knows whats going to happen, so it kind of just takes the excitement out of the movie.

title: A thing of beauty is a joy forever.
review:
****Excellent

***Good

**Fair

*Poor

Allow me to begin this review by stating that Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory was and still is my favorite family film. Director Tim Burton is one of my favorite filmmakers and in a way I expected this film to top the original. I guess that's the letdown or disappointment of the film. Nonetheless, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is an amazing film in its own right. Burton is a great artist and once again fills the screen with great imagery. When I was a child I discovered Burton through wonderful films like "Pee-Wee's Big Adventure," "Beetlejuice," "Edward Scissorhands," and of course the Batman films. With Charlie a whole new generation will discover the brilliance of Mr. Burton.

The other highlight of the film for me was the music and songs by Danny Elfman. This is one of his best work in my opinion. The score was very good and the Oompa Loompa songs were great. And the dance numbers were awesome. You know, sometimes I think Tim Burton should do a musical. He always does a good job with musical numbers. Go watch Beetlejuice and even Batman for more prove.

Now, like I mentioned above, the original is still the best in my honest opinion. One of the reason for that is because of Gene Wilder's performance as Willy Wonka. I love Johnny Depp and feel that he did a great job as Wonka. As well as very funny. But, because of his Michael Jackson approach I think Wilder beats him. I also loved the fact that Wilder's Wonka was a lovable a-hole. Wilder's Wonka was horrible to those rotten kids and very sarcastic to the parents. I liked that approach a lot and he was actually a good person at heart. Wilder's Wonka was just mean to those kids and parents cause they deserved it. To Charlie and his family he revealed the real Willy Wonka. And...even though Depp went for the whole creepy Wonka approach I think Wilder beats him at that as well. How can ANYBODY forget the acid trip?

RATING: 4 STARS

Take your kids or younger sibling. The film is fun and I think everyone will enjoy. Then go and buy the DVD for the original film.

title: Not as good as the original, but still Magical
review:
I went to watch this movie not knowing what to expect. I absolutely loved the original Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory movie, and almost didn't want this one to be made because I didn't think anything could compare to the performance of Gene Wilder.

Johnny Depp as Willy Wonka was almost a perfect match, and I became, once again, amazed at his ability to transform into such unusual characters. But even though Depp gave a brilliant performance, Gene Wilder was born to play Willy Wonka and will remain the best-remembered Willy Wonka.

As a movie, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory was fabulous. It delved into the histories of the Oompa Loompas and Willy Wonka, which provided so much insight. I also loved the almost cartoon-like way all the characters looked. There was something in the editing that made the actors seem as if they were drawn.

The most incredible parts of the movie were the breathtaking sceneries and the squirrels. The set was actually built, and the actors weren't just standing in front of a green screen. Movies tend to be much more visually appealing when the set is real, and this movie is no exception. Moreover, squirrels were somehow trained to actually shell nuts while sitting on a little stool and discard the shells. It was amazing, and I doubt it would've had the same affect had the squirrels been all computer-animated.

The only parts in the movie that made me wince were the Oompa Loompas' song sequences. In the original movie there were a lot of songs as well, but the original movie was more of a musical. Everyone sang in it. In this one, it seems as if the movie stops for two minutes just so the audience can see a little Indian man regenerated fifty times, dancing to some bizarre disco music. It was just a little too much for my taste. Willy Wonka's flashbacks also became stale after awhile. Although his history was integral to the plot, I felt as if some more editing could have been done.

All in all though, this is a magnificent movie that everyone can appreciate. Tim Burton does it yet again, and this will probably end up being the movie of the summer.
